question: the previous question + the following question
answer: la question précédente + la question suivante

question: the next question + next month
answer: Generally: la question suivante + le mois prochain; Whether you use suivant(e) or prochain(e) depends on context. If a list or series has already been established then use suivant(e) to indicate the following item. If you are talking about the next time something happens in the future then use prochain(e).

question: the last question + last month
answer: la dernière question + le mois dernier; Use dernier/derniére for both cases. This adjective is irregular in that is is placed before the noun instead of after.

question: at the end
answer: à la fin ('fon') OR au bout; NB: au fond can also mean at the end but it is typically used when talking about depth.; Alternative: à l'extrémité DE...

question: at the end of his/her studies
answer: à la fin DE ses études

question: at the back (of a photo or piece of furniture)
answer: au fond; e.g. at the back of the armoire = au fond de l'armoire

question: the ending
answer: la terminaison

question: definite articles for masculine + feminine + plural nouns
answer: le/la/les; If the noun starts with a vowel then you replace le/la with l' and pronounce the verb as if it starts with L - ignore the apostrophe when speaking

question: indefinite articles for masculine + feminine + plural nouns
answer: un (masculine..make a smile when you speak it like 'aahn') + une (feminine...make a closed o-shape with mouth like 'oo-yn' and really pronounce the n separately it's almost like two syllables...like bier in german) + des (for all plurals regardless of gender; pronounced 'day')

question: femine masculine plural
answer: féminin masculin pluriel

question: What are some ways to determine if a noun is féminin?
answer: Ending with 'tion'; Ending in E is not a helpful because there are feminine and masculine nouns that end in E.

question: When should there be an apostrophe instead of spelling out le/la?
answer: when the noun starts with a vowel OR when the second letter is a vowel and the first letter is not pronouned (e.g. h); l'académie instead of la académie; l'ordinateur instead of le ordinateur; l'hôtel

question: Aside from a definite article (the) when do you use le/la/l'?
answer: These are also the pronouns for ils/elle when he/she/it is the direct object of a verb; e.g. I read it. = Je le lis. (I + it masculine + read conjugated in present tense)

question: a word
answer: un mot ('mow')

question: the vowel
answer: une voyelle ('voy-ehl')

question: a noun / a verb
answer: un nom / un verbe

question: things to do

question: Date of Birth (for forms)

question: birthday

question: marriage anniversary

question: engagement (to be married)

question: a funeral
answer: les funerailles OR l'enterrement

question: the nationality + the citizenship

question: What is your nationality?

question: I am American.
answer: Je suis américain (m) / américainne (f).; the 'n' is pronounced very lightly and only in the feminine version.; Names of countries are capitalized in French. Names of nationalities and languages are not capitalized in French.

question: You are French.
answer: Tu es français (m) / française (f).; masculine pronounced 'fran-say'; feminine pronounced 'fran-seZ'; Names of countries are capitalized in French. Names of nationalities and languages are not capitalized in French.

question: How is the name of a language related to nationality?
answer: There are masculine and feminine versions of every nationality. The language is always the masculine version.; e.g. Il est allemand. Elle est allemande. Elle parle allemand.; 'allemand' is how you translate German when you mean the language.; BUT the word for language is feminine (la langue). So if you want to say the entire phrase 'the french language' then it is a feminine noun with a feminine adjective: la langue allemande.

question: a french/argentine passport
answer: un passport français/argentin; Un visa is also masculine.

question: I live in New York.
answer: J'habite à New York.

question: I do not come from Paris.
answer: Je ne viens pas de Paris.; making a statement negative is done by 1) adding NE directly after the subject (pronouns never come between the subject and NE) and 2) adding PAS after the conjugated verb (or the auxiliary in the case of passé composé)

question: I do not live in Berlin.
answer: Je n'habite pas à Berlin.; If the verb starts with a vowel or the first pronounced sound is a vowel (no 'h' in france) then use N' instead of NE.

question: I have family in Sweden.
answer: J'ai de la famille en Suède.; AVOIR + 'de la famille' is an idiomatic way of expressing that some of your family is in a location.

question: I don't see well.
answer: Je ne vois pas bien.; Adding pas to an adjective totally negates it and makes it negative instead of neutral / not positive. e.g. pas parfait = the opposite of perfect e.g. pas formidable is very negative instead of just neutral.

question: I speak English.
answer: Je parle anglais. OR Je parle en anglais. Either is correct - like in english (I speak English. OR I speak in English.); NB: In french we always use an article in front of noun. Speaking a language (using the verb parler) is the only exception. When using parler we do not say/write... Je parle l'anglais. But any other time you use the name of a language (or any other noun) then you always add an article in front of it.

question: I do not speak Mandarin.
answer: Je ne parle pas mandarin.; Names of countries are capitalized in French. Names of nationalities and languages are not capitalized in French.

question: I speak a little Spanish + French + German.
answer: Je parle un peu espagnol et français et allemand.

question: a french class + a dance class
answer: un cours de français + un cours ('koohr') de dance;  NB: cours looks plural ending in S but it is singular.; Do not use 'classe' for this. Une classe refers to class heirarchy (e.g. 1st class) or the specific time that you are in school.

question: I go to french class. + I take a french class.
answer: Je vais EN cour de français. + Je prends un cours de français.; Do not use à for going to class. That is used for going to a city etc. - somewhere you visit.

question: a french A2 class
answer: un cours du A2; 'french' is understood

question: a class + a race + a yard
answer: All of these words sound similar but have different meanings.; un cours ('coor') = a class / a course of action / an errand; une course ('coors') = a race; une cour ('coor') = a yard / a courtyard

question: a messenger / a courier
answer: un corsier

question: the level + the levels
answer: le niveau + les niveaux; e.g. mon niveau de français = my level of french

question: a high level of skill
answer: un haut niveau de compétence; the skill = la compétence

question: a class at a good level (for me)
answer: un cours À un bon niveau

question: at most + at least
answer: au plus + au moins

question: several
answer: plusieurs

question: a bit + a little bit
answer: un peu + un petit peu

question: a lot / many
answer: beaucoup; If you use beaucoup as a quantity (e.g. a lot of fish / many fish) then you must add DE between beaucoup and the noun (e.g. beaucoup de poisson).; If you use beaucoup to modify a verb (e.g. We drank a lot.) then it is an adverb and must come before the verb (e.g. Nous avons beaucoup bu.)

question: There are a lot of hospitals and cliniques in this city.
answer: Il y a beaucoupe D'hôpitaux et DE cliniques à cette ville.; When there are two or more nouns (hospitals and cliniques) that refer to the same quantity (many / a lot of) then all of the nouns must be prefaced by DE.

question: not much (like when someone asks you what you have been doing and there is little to report)
answer: pas grand chose; Do not use the phrase 'pas beaucoup' - this does not make sense in french.

question: nothing extravagant
answer: rien d'extravagant

question: too much
answer: trop / beaucoup trop ('troh')

question: It was too much.
answer: C'etait trop ('troh').; Use imparfait tense.

question: There are too many cultures to count.
answer: Il y a beaucoup trop cultures pour les compter.

question: so much (stuff)
answer: tellement DE choses; Tellement is the word that adds emphasis like 'so' in english.; You have to explicitly state the object (choses).

question: so many activities
answer: tellement D'activités; Tellement is the word that adds emphasis like 'so' in english.; You have to explicitly state the object (choses).

question: idiomatic way to say: She's very very (sooooo) nice etc. (any adjective).
answer: Elle est tellement agréable.; Tellement is the word that adds emphasis like 'so' in english.

question: I do quite a lot of things.
answer: Je fais pas mal de chose.; NB: 'pas mal' can mean not bad but it can also mean quite a lot.

question: She eats apples. Which word is assumed in English but cannot be assumed in French?
answer: Elle mange DES pommes.; Partitive article is the name for the word that describes an uncountable or unknown quantity of something. In this case the partitive article is 'some'. She eats (some) apples. 'some' here is optional in English.; In French the partitive article is never optional.

question: What are the partitive articles (used for describing an unknown or uncountable quantity) in French?
answer: du/d' + de la/de l' + des/d'; They are all contractions/combinations of DE + le/la/les.; DU (de + le) is for masculine nouns. DE LA does not contract for feminine nouns. DES (de + les) is for plural nouns.; Do not use these if the quantity is specified in any way (e.g. un kilo de...) - then a different set of articles are used.

question: Is there (some/any) coffee / onion?
answer: Est-ce qu'il y a du café / d'oignon?; We must include partitive article (du / de la / des) when quantity is uncertain.; These nouns are masculine so we use DU. DU contracts to D' when the noun starts with a vowel.

question: Is there (some/any) meat / water?
answer: Est-ce qu'il y a de la viande / de l'eau?; We must include partitive article (du / de la / des) when quantity is uncertain.; These nouns are feminine so we use DE LA. LA contracts to L' when the noun starts with a vowel.

question: Are there (some/any) lemons / onions?
answer: Est-ce qu'il y a DES citrons / DES oignons?; We must include partitive article (du / de la / des) when quantity is uncertain.; The gender of the plural noun does not matter. DES never contracts when the noun starts with a vowel because DES ends with a consonant.

question: the water
answer: l'eau; eau is feminine. But la eau contracts to l'eau to avoid back-to-back vowels.; This is pronounced really strongly "loh".; -eau is pronounced as a strong 'oh' - like the words chateau and bateau.

question: two glasses of water (explain the pronunciation difference)
answer: deux verre d'eau; The O sound in deux is higher in the mouth. The O sound in d'eau is lower in the mouth; d'eau = DE + EAU. Use DE EAU instead of LA EAU because verre is specified quantity so we use the generic DE/DES without the definite article (la).

question: The water is good. + a glass of water +  + I drink water.
answer: These exhibit the three different ways to talk about water.; 1) L'eau est bonne. = The water is good. We are using the noun with its article (simply LA which contracts to L').; 2) un verre d'eau = a glass of water. The glass is a quantity so we use the generic preposition DE/DES without a definite article. (DE contracts to D'.); 3) Je bois DE l'eau. = I drink water. The verb BOIRE is always followed by DE but it is not a quantity indicator. So you also have to give the object of the verb (water) it's partitive article - LA (because water is feminine). DE + LA + EAU = de l'eau.

question: She eats a lot. + She ate a lot.; Note the location of 'beaucoup' in both cases.
answer: Elle mange beaucoup. + Elle a beaucoup mangé.; If beaucoup describes the verb (manger) - as it does in both of these sentences - instead of the object (e.g. beaucoup DE frais)... then beaucoup must follow the conjugated portion of a verb. That means that 'beaucoup' falls between the two parts of passé composé in this case.

question: You (informal) eat a lot of apples.; Which preposition is required?
answer: Tu manges beaucoup DE pommes.; 'A lot' in this case does not modify the verb (manger) here. It describes the quantity of apples (just like 'a kilo'). When quantity is specified we only use DE/D' (instead of the partitive articles) because gender and number do not need to be reflected.

question: He ate a lot. + He ate a lot of apples.; Note the location of 'beaucoup' in both cases.
answer: Il a BEAUCOUP mangé. + Il a mangé BEAUCOUP de pommes.; Both examples are passé composé so there are two parts to the verbs. In the first case BEAUCOUP modifies the verb (manger) so it must follow the conjugated portion of the two-part verb. In the second case BEAUCOUP modifies the object (pommes) so it must be placed after the entire verb.

question: There is coffee. + There is a box of coffee.
answer: Il y a DU (de + le) café. + Il y a un carton DE café. (le café); The former has an unspecified amount so we use the partitive article DU (de + le) for the masculine café.; The latter has a specified amount/quantity so we use DE (or D') which does not need to agree with gender/number.

question: There is salad + There is a pack of salad.
answer: Il y a DE LA salade. + Il y a un paquet DE salade. (la salade); The former has an unspecified amount so we use the partitive article DE LA for the feminine salade.; The latter has a specified amount/quantity so we use DE (or D') which does not need to agree with gender/number.

question: There is a jar strawberry jam.
answer: Il y a un pot DE confiture de fraise. (la confiture); The quantity is specified so use the general articles (DE / D') that do not care about gender or number.

question: There are a dozen cookies.
answer: Il y a une douzaine DE biscuits. (les biscuits); The quantity is specified so use the general articles (DE / D') that do not care about gender or number.

question: group words for: a dozen + a set of roughly 10 + a set of roughly 100
answer: une douzaine ('doo-zehn') + une dizaine ('dee-zehn') + une centaine ('son-tehn'); NB: These have equivalent meaning in English. For example: tens of thousands - tens here means roughly a set of 10.; If you want to communicate something that is greater than 10 and less than 100 then you could say: plusieurs dizaines = several tens (30 or 40 or 50 etc)

question: There is a handful of blueberries.
answer: Il y a une poignée DE myrtilles (les myrtilles); The quantity is specified so use the general articles (DE / D') that do not care about gender or number.

question: Explain how negation using an adverb is different from negation using an adjective.
answer: Negation (e.g. NE + PAS) can be accomplished by using a negative adjective: I see no cats. = Je NE vois PAS un chat. OR a negative adverb: e.g. I do not see cats. = Je NE vois PAS DE chat.; If you are using the negative word (like PAS) as an adjective then you just place it before the noun without changing the noun. If you are using the negative word (like PAS) as an adverb then you must change the article of the noun to generalize it. e.g. Il y a UN chat. changes to: Il n'y a pas DE chat.

question: There is milk. + There is no milk.
answer: Il y a DU lait. + Il n'y a pas DE lait.; DU lait changes to DE lait.; The first sentence has an unspecified amount so we use the partitive article DU for the masculine lait. The second sentence uses the negative word PAS as an adverb (adverb: I do not see X. vs adjective: I see no X.) So the object must become generalized in the second sentence.

question: There is oil. + There is no oil.
answer: Il y a DE L'huile. + Il n'y a pas D'huile.; DE L'huile (partitive de la) changes to D'huile (generic de).; The first sentence has an unspecified amount so we use the partitive article DE LA for the feminine huile. The second sentence uses the negative word PAS as an adverb (adverb: I do not see X. vs adjective: I see no X.) So the object must become generalized in the second sentence.

question: There are eggs. + There are no eggs.
answer: Il y a DES œufs. ('dez-oo'; fs is silent) + Il n'y a pas D'œufs.; DES œufs changes to D'œufs.; The first sentence has an unspecified amount so we us the partitive article DES for the plural œufs. The second sentence uses the negative word PAS as an adverb (adverb: I do not see X. vs adjective: I see no X.) So the object must become generalized in the second sentence.

question: Jean has (some) money. + Jean has no money.
answer: Jean a DE L'argent. + Jean n'a pas D'argent.; DE L'argent (de la) changes to D'argent (d).; The first sentence has an unspecified amount so we us the partitive article DE LA for the feminine argent. The second sentence uses the negative word PAS as an adverb (adverb: I do not see X. vs adjective: I see no X.) So the object must become generalized in the second sentence.

question: I play sports. + I do not play sports.
answer: Je fais DU sport. + Je ne fais DE sport.; DU sport (de + le) changes to DE sport.;  The first sentence has an unspecified amount so we us the partitive article DU for the masculine sport. The second sentence uses the negative word PAS as an adverb (adverb: I do not see X. vs adjective: I see no X.) So the object must become generalized in the second sentence.

question: In futur proche: We are going to play tennis. + We are not going to play tennis.
answer: On va faire DU tennis. + On ne va pas faire DE tennis.; Even when there is a double verb the noun following the last verb must be treated differently in the positive sentence vs the negative sentence because we added a negative word (PAS) and used it as an adverb.

question: She likes talking with clients. + She does not like talking with clients.
answer: Elle aime parler avec DES clients. + Elle n'aime pas parler avec DES clients.; In both cases we use the partitive article (le/la/les which transforms to du/de la/des) instead of de/d' because the eclients are sequestered away from the verb in a prepositional clause (with the clients). So when we negate the sentence the prepositional phrase is not exposed to change by adding a negative adverb (PAS).

question: We respond to emails. + We do not respond to emails.
answer: Nous répondons aux e-mails. + Nous ne répondons pas aux e-mails.; In both cases we use the partitive article (le/la/les which transforms to au/à la/aux) instead of de/d' because the emails are sequestered away from the verb in a prepositional clause (to the emails). So when we negate the sentence the prepositional phrase is not exposed to change by adding a negative adverb (PAS).

question: We are professors. + We are not professors.
answer: Nous sommes (des) professeurs. + Nous ne sommes pas (des) professeurs.; In this case we do not place the generalized DE before the object because we are using PAS as an adjective (literally: We are no professors.).; It's helpful to memorize: When a noun follows the verb ÊTRE...and when the statement is negated... then we do NOT change from a partitive article (le/la/les or un/une/des) to a non-partitive article (de/d').

question: You are an actor. + You are not an actor.
answer: Tu est (un) acteur. + Tu n'est pas (un) acteur.; In this case we do not place the generalized DE before the object because we are using PAS as an adjective (literally: You are no actor.).; It's helpful to memorize: When a noun follows the verb ÊTRE...and when the statement is negated... then we do NOT change from a partitive article (le/la/les or un/une/des) to a non-partitive article (de/d').

question: He never wants to go out.
answer: Il NE veut JAMAIS sortir.; JAMAIS (never) replaces PAS when negating. It is always an adverb.; NB: When JAMAIS is not paired with NE then it means ever (instead of never).

question: There are pears. + There are never pears.
answer: Il y a DES poires. + Il n'y a jamais DE poires.; .JAMAIS (never) replaces PAS when negating. Jamais is always an adverb so we generalize an object by replacing partitive articles with the generic DE/D'.

question: I eat an insect. + I never eat an insect.
answer: Je mange un insecte. + Je ne mange jamais d'insecte.; JAMAIS (never) replaces PAS when negating. Jamais is always an adverb so we generalize an object by replacing partitive articles with the generic DE/D'.

question: She never went to Vietnam.
answer: Elle N'est JAMAIS allée au Vietnam.; In passé composé (or any tense that uses an auxiliary) PAS/PLUS/RIEN/JAMAIS are placed directly after the auxiliary (the conjugated portion) - before the participle. PERSONNE is different in that it is placed directly after the participle.

question: She is never going to go to Vietnam. (use passé récent)
answer: Elle NE vas JAMAIS aller au Vietnam.; When there are two verbs (one conjugated + one infinitive) PAS/PLUS/RIEN/JAMAIS are placed directly after the conjugated verb. PERSONNE is different in that it is placed directly after the final verb (the infinitive).

question: They are always on time. + They are never on time.
answer: Ils sont TOUJOURS à l'heure. + Ils NE sont JAMAIS à l'heure.; JAMAIS (never) replaces PAS when negating. à l'heure is a prepositional phrase that is sheltered from the adverb JAMAIS so we do not have to change the À.; The inverse of toujours (always) is jamais (never). Jamais can also be the inverse of encore and déja.

question: Have you already lied to your parents? + I never lied to my parents.
answer: As tu déjà menti à tes parents? + Je n'ai JAMAIS menti à mes parents.; JAMAIS (never) replaces PAS when negating.; The inverse of toujours (always) is jamais (never). Jamais can also be the inverse of encore and toujours.

question: nothing
answer: rien ('ray-uhn') is the negative pronoun that means the absence of something - usually an action.; NB: rien typically follows a verb because it is typically used to represent the absence of a verb/action instead of the absence of physical things. e.g. Il n'y a rien à faire. = There is nothing to do. One does not say Il n'y a rien pommes. This does not make sense in French.

question: Three ways to say: There are no apples.
answer: 1) Il n'y a pas DE pommes. = There are no apples. 2) Il n'y a plus DE pommes. = There are no more apples. 3) Il n'y a zero DE pommes. = There are zero apples.; Do not use RIEN in this case because we are talking about the absence of physical objects (instead of the absence of action).; For physical objects use the classic NE + PAS negation. PLUS or ZERO can replace PAS.; PAS + PLUS + ZERO are being used as adverbs so we must use the generic DE before the noun.

question: She heard everything. + She heard nothing.
answer: Elle écoute tout. + Elle N'écoute RIEN.; RIEN takes the place of PAS in the NE + PAS negation syntax.; Rien (nothing) is the opposite of tout (everything).

question: We do not see anything.
answer: On NE voit RIEN.; RIEN takes the place of PAS in the NE + PAS negation syntax.

question: There is nothing to change.
answer: Il N'y a RIEN à changer.; RIEN takes the place of PAS in the NE + PAS negation syntax.

question: Nothing is on the table.
answer: RIEN N'est sur la table.; When RIEN is the subject we must still pair it with NE because it replaces PAS.

question: Nothing pleases me. + Nothing bothers me.
answer: RIEN NE me plaît. + RIEN NE me dérange; When RIEN is the subject we must still pair it with NE because it replaces PAS.

question: She said nothing.
answer: Elle N'a RIEN dit.; In passé composé (or any tense that uses an auxiliary) PAS/PLUS/RIEN/JAMAIS are placed directly after the auxiliary (the conjugated portion) - before the participle. PERSONNE is different in that it is placed directly after the participle.

question: He's not going to say anything. (use passé récent)
answer: Il NE vas RIEN dire.; When there are two verbs (one conjugated + one infinitive) PAS/PLUS/RIEN/JAMAIS are placed directly after the conjugated verb. PERSONNE is different in that it is placed directly after the final verb (the infinitive).

question: no one / nobody
answer: personne; Personne is a negative pronoun. It replaces PAS in the typical NE + PAS syntax. Even if PERSONNE is the subject of the sentence it is still paired with NE. If you used both PERSONNE and PAS that would be double negation - don't do it.

question: more people + nobody anymore
answer: plus DE personneS + plus personne; This is a tricky one. The presence or absence of DE and the plural determines meaning.

question: He sees everyone. + He sees no one.
answer: Il voit tout le monde. + Il NE voit PERSONNE.; If you are using the typical NE + PAS negation syntax - then PERSONNE replaces PAS.; Personne (no one) is the opposite of everyone (tout le monde).

question: I don’t know anyone here.
answer: Je NE connais PERSONNE ici.; If you are using the typical NE + PAS negation syntax - then PERSONNE replaces PAS.

question: There is nobody here.
answer: Il N'y a PERSONNE ici.; If you are using the typical NE + PAS negation syntax - then PERSONNE replaces PAS.

question: No one understands.
answer: Personne NE comprend.; PERSONNE is the subject but we still pair it with NE because it replaces PAS.

question: No one can help me.
answer: Personne NE peut m'aider.; PERSONNE is the subject but we still pair it with NE because it replaces PAS.

question: I didn't speak to anyone.
answer: Je n'ai parlé à PERSONNE. (Don't forget À when speaking TO someone.); In passé composé (or any tense that uses an auxiliary) PAS/PLUS/RIEN/JAMAIS are placed directly after the auxiliary (the conjugated portion) - before the participle. PERSONNE is different in that it is placed directly after the participle.

question: I found no one in the house.
answer: Je N'ai trouvé PERSONNE dans la maison.; In passé composé (or any tense that uses an auxiliary) PAS/PLUS/RIEN/JAMAIS are placed directly after the auxiliary (the conjugated portion) - before the participle. PERSONNE is different in that it is placed directly after the participle.

question: She is not going to find anybody in the church. (use passé récent)
answer: Elle NE vas trouver PERSONNE dans l'église.; When there are two verbs (one conjugated + one infinitive) PAS/PLUS/RIEN/JAMAIS are placed directly after the conjugated verb. PERSONNE is different in that it is placed directly after the final verb (the infinitive).

question: none
answer: aucun(e) depending on the gender of the noun you are referencing; AUCUN(E) replaces PAS when negating.; NB: AUCUN(E) is a good option when you are talking about something that is difficult to quantify (e.g. happiness or harm) because PAS should only be used with nouns that can be quantified. But AUCUN(E) is always singular. If you really need to express something that is plural then use PAS instead.

question: None (of the characters) are nice.
answer: AUCUN (des personnages) N'est gentil(le).; AUCUN(E) replaces PAS when negating.; Aucun(e) is a noun (not an adverb) in this case so we do not have to generalize the characters by adding DE/D'.

question: no/zero cats
answer: aucun chats; In this case aucun(e) is being used as an adjective - not an adverb to negate a verb. So we do not have to generalize the characters by adding DE/D'.

question: No answer is bad.
answer: AUCUNE réponse N’est mauvaise.; AUCUN(E) replaces PAS when negating.; Aucun(e) is a noun (not an adverb) in this case so we do not have to generalize the noun (the answer) by adding DE/D'.

question: No plane is flying today.
answer: AUCUN avion NE vole aujourd’hui.; AUCUN(E) replaces PAS when negating.; Aucun(e) is a noun (not an adverb) in this case so we do not have to generalize the noun (the plane) by adding DE/D'.

question: I have no idea.
answer: Je n'en ai aucune idée.; Use the singular form (une idée) and aucune to match the gender.; AUCUN(E) replaces PAS when negating.; Aucun(e) is a noun (not an adverb) in this case so we do not have to generalize the object (mistake) by adding DE/D'.

question: I did not make any mistakes.
answer: Je n'ai fait aucune faute.; Use the singular form (une faute) and aucune to match the gender.; AUCUN(E) replaces PAS when negating.; Aucun(e) is a noun (not an adverb) in this case so we do not have to generalize the object (mistake) by adding DE/D'.

question: I don’t know any lawyers.
answer: Je ne connais aucun avocat.; Use the singular form (un avocat) and aucun to match the gender.; AUCUN(E) replaces PAS when negating.; Aucun(e) is a noun (not an adverb) in this case so we do not have to generalize the object (mistake) by adding DE/D'.

question: No vacations are too long.
answer: PAS DE vacances NE sont (plural verb to match plural subject) trop longues.; When you really need to use a plural noun then you cannot use aucun(e) to replace or modify it because aucun(e) is always singular. So in this case use PAS DE + NE.; Alternatively: If you wanted to say... No vacation is too long. = Aucune vacance n'est trop longue. Then you could use aucun(e) because the noun referenced is singular.

question: no more / no longer; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: non plus ('pleww'); PLUS is negative adverb that can replace PAS in the NE + PAS syntax. Use it when you want to negate a statement where the action has stopped.; The S is silent in this case because we are dealing with a negative/lack of quantity.; Alternative: rien d'autre ('ray-uhn-doot') = nothing else

question: me neither
answer: moi non plus ('pleww'); The S is silent because we are dealing with a negative/lack of quantity.

question: I can eat. + I cannot eat more.
answer: Je peux manger. + Je NE mange PLUS ('pleww').; NE + PLUS (no more / no longer) is a negative adverb. PLUS replaces PAS in the NE + PAS syntax.; NE + PLUS (doing something no more / no longer) is the opposite of STILL going something.

question: We learn more things. + We learn more.
answer: On apprend PLUS DE choses. + On EN apprend PLUS.; In the latter phrase we did not specify the object (what is learned). This is impossible in French. We must reference it with either 'plus DE choses' OR the pronom EN. Pronom EN replaces a quantity of something or the complement of a phrase following DE (e.g. J'ai pense DE...).

question: I still have money. + I do not have any more money.
answer: J'ai encore DE L'argent. + Je N'ai PLUS D'argent.; NE + PLUS (no more / no longer) is a negative adverb. PLUS replaces PAS in the NE + PAS syntax.; Because we are using a negative adverb we must generalize the object (change from: DE LA + argent to: DE + argent)

question: He continues to sleep. + He sleeps no more.
answer: Il continue de dormir. + Il NE dort PLUS ('pleww').; NE + PLUS (no more / no longer) is a negative adverb. PLUS replaces PAS in the NE + PAS syntax.

question: Given: I would like more wine. - Is the S in plus pronounced? Why?
answer: Je voudrais plus ('plewws') DE vin; The S is pronounced because it relates to a noun with a positive quantity.; We generalize the object (DE vin) because PLUS replaces PAS and is being used as an adverb here.

question: Given: There is no more school. - Is the S in plus pronounced? Why?
answer: Il n'y a plus ('pleww') D'école.; The S is NOT pronounced because it relates to a noun with a negative/lack of quantity.; We generalize the object (DE + école) because PLUS replaces PAS and is being used as an adverb here.

question: Given: I do not want it anymore. - Is the S in plus pronounced? Why?
answer: Je n'en veux plus.; The S is NOT pronounced because it relates to a noun with a negative/lack of quantity.

question: Given: You are more intelligent than an apple. - Is the S in plus pronounced? Why?
answer: Tu es plus intelligent qu'une pomme.; Contract que + une = qu'une.; S in plus is pronounced because it precedes an adjective that starts with a vowel or a silent h followed by vowel.

question: Given: I am stronger than you. - Is the S in plus pronounced? Why?
answer: Je suis plus fort que toi.; S in plus is NOT pronounced because it precedes an adjective that DOES NOT start with a vowel or a silent h followed by vowel.

question: How do you pronounce "3 + 4 = 7"?

question: It's more of an apple than a pear.

question: It's easier in Asia than in Europe.
answer: C'est plus facile en Asie qu'en Europe.; Normally the N in en is silent because it is at the end of the word. But here you must pronounce the N in en to make a liaison with the next word (Europe) which starts with a vowel.; Pronounce the last two words as one word blended together 'koh-noo-rope'

question: It's more difficult in Spain than in France.
answer: C'est plus dificil en Espagne qu'en ('koh') France.; Remember that the N in en is silent. It stays silent here because the next word (France) starts with a consonant.

question: The doctors in France give more drugs than in the United States.
answer: Les médecins en France donnent plus de médicaments qu'aux Etats-Unis. ('koh-zuh-ta-zoo-nee'); pronounce the last part as a single word

question: a lot more; specify the pronunciation
answer: beaucoup plus ('ploos'); the S is pronounced because we are dealing with a positive quantity

question: more than X; specify the pronunciation
answer: plus que ('ploos-kuh') X; S on plus is pronounced because it refers to a positive quantity.

question: He/She is more than a banker.
answer: Il/Elle est plus qu'un/qu'une banquier/banquière.; S in plus is pronounced because it refers to a positive quantity and comes before a word that starts with a consonant.; NB: qu'un is pronounced 'kahn' not 'koon'

question: a little more than a week
answer: un peu plus qu' (or d') une semaine; The difference is subtle. PLUS QUE X = more than X. PLUS DE X = more of X.

question: higher than me + lower than me
answer: élevé QUE moi + moins élevé QUE moi; If a pronoun follows QUE when making a comparison then the pronoun should be tonique.; The structure for comparing with adjectives: plus/moins/aussi + adjective + que

question: Jean is faster. + Jean is faster than Michel.
answer: Jean est PLUS rapide. + Jean est PLUS rapide QUE Michel.; S in plus is pronounced because it refers to a positive quantity and comes before a word that starts with a consonant.; The adjective (rapide) should adapt to the subject (Jean) that it describes.; The structure for comparing with adjectives: plus/moins/aussi + adjective + que

question: The rock is less intelligent. + The rock is less intelligent than the computer.
answer: Le rocher est MOINS intelligent. + Le rocher est MOINS intelligent QUE l'ordinateur.; The adjective (intelligent(e)) should adapt to the subject (le rocher - masculine) that it describes.; The structure for comparing with adjectives: plus/moins/aussi + adjective + que

question: Angelique is as intelligent as Simone.
answer: Angelique est AUSSI intelligente QUE Simone.; The adjective (intelligent(e)) should adapt to the subject (Angelique - feminine) that it describes.; The structure for comparing with adjectives: plus/moins/aussi + adjective + que

question: Élodie is as athletic as her.
answer: Élodie est AUSSI sportive QU'elle.; If a pronoun follows QUE when making a comparison then the pronoun should be tonique.; The structure for comparing with adjectives: plus/moins/aussi + adjective + que

question: I am the same age as you.
answer: Two options: 1) J'ai la même âge que vous/toi. 2) Je suis AUSSI agé(e) que vous/toi.; The structure for comparing with adjectives: plus/moins/aussi + adjective + que

question: I am less athletic than before.
answer: Je suis MOINS sportif QU'avant.; The structure for comparing with adjectives: plus/moins/aussi + adjective + que

question: Louis is almost as generous as Anna.
answer: Louis est PRESQUE AUSSI généreux QU'Anna.; Add presque to mean 'almost'. Add encore to mean 'even'.; The structure for comparing with adjectives: plus/moins/aussi + adjective + que

question: even more + even less
answer: encore plus + encore moins; Encore can mean 'yet' but when used with plus/moins it provides an emphasis like 'even'.

question: The plane is even faster than the train.
answer: L'avion est ENCORE PLUS rapide QUE le train.; Add presque to mean 'almost'. Add encore to mean 'even'.; The structure for comparing with adjectives: plus/moins/aussi + adjective + que

question: The car is even less convenient than the bus.
answer: La voiture est ENCORE MOINS pratique QUE le bus.; Add presque to mean 'almost'. Add encore to mean 'even'.; The structure for comparing with adjectives: plus/moins/aussi + adjective + que

question: She studies even less (than before).
answer: Elle étudie ENCORE MOINS souvent QU'avant.; Add presque to mean 'almost'. Add encore to mean 'even'.; The structure for comparing with adjectives: plus/moins/aussi + adjective + que

question: He is blond like his father.
answer: Il est blond COMME son pére.; This is an example of an equality comparison with adjectives (as X as) where you cannot use AUSSI because the quality is not quantified in any way. question: Eva works more. + Eva works more than Aileen.
answer: Eva travaille PLUS. + Eva travaille PLUS QU'Aileen. ('ploos-kuh'); S in plus is pronounced because it refers to a positive quantity and comes before a word that starts with a consonant.; The structure for comparing with verbs: verb + plus/moins/autant + adverb (optional) + que.

question: Anna travels less. + Anna travels less than you (informal).
answer: Anna voyage MOINS. + Anna voyage MOINS QUE toi.; When a pronoun follows the QUE in comparisons use pronom tonique (toi).; The structure for comparing with verbs: verb + plus/moins/autant + adverb (optional) + que.

question: He eats as much as I do.
answer: Il mange AUTANT que moi.; When a pronoun follows the QUE in comparisons use pronom tonique (moi).; The structure for comparing with verbs: verb + plus/moins/autant + adverb (optional) + que.

question: He speaks as well as I do.

question: Alex talks almost as much as Adam.

question: Juliette talks even less than Claire.
answer: Juliette parle ENCORE MOINS que Claire.; ENCORE (even) is placed before the comparator because it modifies the comparator - not the verb.

question: I run slower than I did yesterday.
answer: Je cours PLUS lentement QU'heir.; The structure for comparing with verbs: verb + plus/moins/autant + adverb (optional) + que.

question: The salon has more furniture. + The salon has more furniture than the office.
answer: Le salon a PLUS DE ('plooews-duh') meubles. + Le salon a PLUS DE mobilier QUE le bureau.; The structure for comparing with nouns: PLUS/MOINS/AUTANT + DE/D' + noun + QUE); S in plus is pronounced because it refers to a positive quantity and comes before a word that starts with a consonant.

question: The casino has less money. + The casino has less money than the bank.
answer: Le casino a MOINS D'argent. + Le casino a MOINS D'argent QUE la banque.; The structure for comparing with nouns: PLUS/MOINS/AUTANT + DE/D' + noun + QUE)

question: less than other things
answer: moins que D'autres choses; The structure for comparing with nouns: PLUS/MOINS/AUTANT + DE/D' + noun + QUE)

question: I have as many books as Angela.
answer: J'ai AUTANT DE livres QU'Angela.; The structure for comparing with nouns: PLUS/MOINS/AUTANT + DE/D' + noun + QUE)

question: He has almost as many children as Louis.
answer: Il a PRESQUE AUTANT D'enfants que Louis.; PRESQUE (almost) is placed before the comparator because it modifies the comparator.; The structure for comparing with nouns: PLUS/MOINS/AUTANT + DE/D' + noun + QUE)

question: This book has even more pages than the Bible.
answer: Ce livre a ENCORE PLUS DE de pages que la Bible.; ENCORE (even) is placed before the comparator because it modifies the comparator.; The structure for comparing with nouns: PLUS/MOINS/AUTANT + DE/D' + noun + QUE)

question: the biggest + the smallest
answer: le/la plus grand(e) + le/la plus petit(e)

question: the most intelligent (specify the pronunciation)
answer: le/la/les PLUS ('ploos') intelligent(e); Adding the article (le/la/les) changes the plus from a comparator to a superlative. The article must agree with the subject.; The S is pronounced because we are dealing with a positive quantity.

question: the least intelligent
answer: le/la/les moins intelligent(e); Adding the article (le/la/les) changes the plus from a comparator to a superlative. The article must agree with the subject.

question: Eva is the most dynamic. + Eva is the most dynamic of the women.
answer: Eva est LA PLUS dynamique. + Eva est LA PLUS dynamique DE femmes.; The article that indicates the superlative (le/la/les plus) must agree with the subject that is being described (Eva - feminine).; When using a superlative use DE/D' to indicate the group within which they are the most/least.

question: Jean is least dynamic. + Jean is the least dynamic of the men.
answer: Jean est LE MOINS dynamique. + Jean est LE MOINS dynamique DE hommes.;  The article that indicates the superlative (le/la/les moins) must agree with the subject that is being described (Jean - masculine); When using a superlative use DE/D' to indicate the group within which they are the most/least.

question: He runs the most. She runs the least.
answer: Il court LE PLUS. Elle court LE MOINS.; The superlative is always masculine (LE plus/moins) when we compare with verbs (court).

question: She has the most books. She has the least books.
answer: Elle a LE PLUS DE livres. Elle a LE MOINS DE livres.; The superlative is always masculine when we compare with nouns (livres). Do not forget DE/D' before the noun.

question: Where do you most want to go?
answer: Où est-ce que tu as LE PLUS envie d'aller?; avoir envie de X = to crave X

question: Explain the two words that mean: better
answer: There are two possible translations (mieux OR meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meillures) depending on whether you are describing a verb (when you need the adverb mieux) or a noun (when you need the adjective meilleur...).; mieux (better or more well) is the adverb to use as the comparator for bien (well). Because this is an adverb it does not need to adapt (in number and gender) to the verb it describes.;  meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meillures (better) are the adjectives to use as the comparator for bon/bonne/bons/bonnes (good). Because these are all adjectives they must adapt (in number and gender) to the nouns which they describe.; NB: Better and all of its transations are called comparators.

question: You speak better English than I speak English.
answer: Tu parles MIEUX l'anglais que je parle le français. OR Tu parles MIEUX l'anglais que moi (pronom tonique).; Use MIEUX in this case because 'better' is an adverb describing the verb 'speak'. Mieux does not need to adapt in gender or number because it is an adverb - not an adjective.; Mieux (better) is an irregular adverb. It does not follow the general rules for transforming an adjective to an adverb.

question: We want to know our friends better.
answer: On veut MIEUX connaitre nos amis.; Use MIEUX in this case because 'better' is an adverb describing the verb 'know'.; Mieux does not need to adapt in gender or number because it is an adverb - not an adjective.; NB: The placement of mieux changes depending on context.

question: Jane is better at sports than John.
answer: Jane est MEILLEURE en sport que John.; Use meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meillures in this case because 'better' is an adjective describing the noun 'Jane'. Jane is feminine singular so use MEILLEURE. Adjectives (even comparators like 'better') must adapt in gender or number to the noun they describe.

question: John is better at at biology than Jane.
answer: John est MEILLEUR en biologie que Jane. ;Use meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meillures in this case because 'better' is an adjective describing the noun 'John'. John is masculine singular so use MEILLEUR. Adjectives (even comparators like 'better') must adapt in gender or number to the noun they describe.

question: Juliette and Sonia are better at maths than Sophia.
answer: Juliette et Sonia sont MEILLEURES en maths que Sophia.; Use meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meillures in this case because 'better' is an adjective describing the nouns 'Juliette et Sonia'. Juliette et Sonia is feminine plural so use MEILLEURES. Adjectives (even comparators like 'better') must adapt in gender or number to the noun they describe.

question: Bruno and Lucas are better at writing than Ryan.
answer: Bruno et Lucas sont MEILLEURS en écriture que Ryan.; Use meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meillures in this case because 'better' is an adjective describing the nouns 'Bruno et Lucas'. Bruno et Lucas is masculine plural so use MEILLEURS. Adjectives (even comparators like 'better') must adapt in gender or number to the noun they describe.

question: It's a better place. + It's a better life.
answer: C'est un MEILLEUR endroit (masc sing). + C'est une MEILLEURE vie (fem sing).; 'better' in these cases is an adjective describing 'place' and 'life' so use meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meillures.

question: It could be better.
answer: Il pourrait faire MEILLEUR.; Use meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meillures because 'better' is an adjective describing 'it'.

question: It's better than in Madrid.
answer: C'est MEILLEUR qu'à Madrid. (que + à = qu'à); Use meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meillures because 'better' is an adjective describing 'it'.

question: It's getting better. Give literal and idiomatic translations.
answer: The literal translation: Ça devient meilleur. (MEILLEUR because 'better' is being used an adjective describing 'it'. DEVEVIR = to become).; But the better / more idiomatic way to say this is: C'est de MIEUX en MIEUX. ('say-duh-myoo-zuhn-myoo') There is a liaison after the first mieux but not the second.

question: It's better to reserve/book before you go.
answer: Il vaut MIEUX réserver avant de partir.; This is idiomatic. Use Il vaut... instead of Il faut... in this case. And there is no DE or POUR before the infinitive verb.; 'better' is being used to describe a verb so use MIEUX.

question: better than them
answer: mieux qu'eux ('myoo-kuh')

question: idiomatic way to say: It's better to X than Y.
answer: Vaux (valoir) mieux que X que Y. e.g. Vaux mieux que ça arrive maintenant qu'à Noël. = It's better that it happened now instead of at Christmas.

question: idiomatic way to express: It's better. + It's the best.
answer: Ça va mieux. + C'est top.

question: Explain the two words that mean: best
answer: Use the same adverb or adjective that you would choose for 'better'. And you must add an article (le/la/les) because 'the best' is always a noun.; The two options: 1) LE MIEUX is the superlative for bien (well) - an adverb used to describe a verb / when something is doing some action the best. Adverbs do not adapt (in number and gender). 2) LE MEILLEUR / LA MEILLEURE / LES MEILLEURS / LES MEILLEURES are the superlatives for bon/bonne/bons/bonnes (good) - an adjective used to describe a noun / when something is 'the best'. Adjectives must adapt (in number and gender) to the noun they describe.

question: Simone dances the best.
answer: Simone danse LE MIEUX.; Best is like an adverb in this case because it describes 'dance'. So use LE MIEUX which never adapts in number and gender.; You must use the article (le) to indicate that it is a superlative and also because 'the best' is actually always a noun. The literal translation of 'le meiux' is 'the most well'.

question: Chloé is the best at sports. + Jacques is the best at maths.
answer: Chloé est LA MEILLEURE (fem sing) en sports. + Jacques est LE MEILLEUR (masc sing) en mathématiques.; Even though we are talking about how well people are doing at an activity... Use the adjective options - LE/LA/LES MEILLEUR(E)(S) - because 'best' is an adjective describing the subject of the phrase.

question: Camille and Chloé are the best. + Marc and Jacques are the best.
answer: Camille et Chloé sont LES MEILLEURES (fem pl). + Marc et Jacques sont LES MEILLEURS (masc pl).; Use the adjective options - LE/LA/LES MEILLEUR(E)(S) - because 'best' is an adjective describing the subject of the phrase.

question: The best thing is... + The best man is...
answer: La meilleure (fem sing) est... + Le meilleur (masc sing) est...; meilleur(e)(s) are irregular adjectives that comes before the noun.

question: The best houses are... + The best cats are...
answer: ; Les meilleures maisons (fem pl) sont... + Les meilleurs chats (masc pl) sont...; meilleur(e)(s) are irregular adjectives that comes before the noun.

question: bad + poorly/badly
answer: mal/mauvais (adjective) + mal (adverb); mal/mauvais is irregular in that it is placed before the noun that it describes.

question: Explain the two words that mean: worse
answer: 1) PLUS MAL is an adverb. Use it when describing a verb. It is the oppossite mieux (better/more well). 2) PIRE/PIRE/PIRES/PIRES are adjective. Use them when describing a noun. They are the opposite of meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meilleures (better/more good).

question: In addition to pire(s)... what is another adjective that can be used to mean 'worse'?
answer: PLUS + mauvais/mauvaise/mauvais/mauvaises can be used instead of simply pire/pires when 'worse' is an adjective that describes a noun.; e.g. Le chat est pire (masc sing) que le chien. = Le chat est PLUS mauvais (masc sing) que le chien.

question: Jacques sings worse than Marc.
answer: Jacques chante PLUS MAL que Marc.; Use plus mal (instead of pire/pires) because 'worse' is an adverb describing 'sings'. Adverbs do not need to agree (in number and gender) with a noun.; Pire (worse) and mal (poorly/badly) are irregular adverbs. They do not follow the general rules for transforming an adjective to an adverb.

question: The dogs sing worse than the cats.
answer: Les cheins chantent PLUS MAL que les chats.; Use plus mal (instead of pire/pires) because 'worse' is an adverb describing 'sing'. Adverbs do not need to agree (in number and gender) with a noun.

question: The cat is worse than the dog.
answer: Le chat est PIRE (masc sing) que le chien.; Use pire(s) - instead of plus mal - because 'worse' is an adjective describing the noun 'the cat'.; pire/pires are both pronounced 'peer'.

question: The house is worse than the apartment.
answer: La maison est PIRE (fem sing) que la appartement.; Use pire(s) - instead of plus mal - because 'worse' is an adjective describing the noun 'the house'.; pire/pires are both pronounced 'peer'.

question: The cats are worse than the dogs.
answer: Les chats sont PIRES (masc plural) que les chiens.; Use pire(s) - instead of plus mal - because 'worse' is an adjective describing the noun 'the cats'.; pire/pires are both pronounced 'peer'.

question: The houses are worse than the apartments.
answer: Les maisons sont PIRES (fem sing) que les appartement.; Use pire(s) - instead of plus mal - because 'worse' is an adjective describing the noun 'the houses'.; pire/pires are both pronounced 'peer'.

question: Explain the two words that mean: worst
answer: Use the same adverb or adjective that you would choose for 'worse'. And you must add an article (le/la/les) because 'the worst' is always a noun.; The two options: 1) LE PLUS MAL when you are describing someone/thing that is the worst at doing some verb. Adverbs do not adapt (in number and gender) to the verb. It is the opposite of le mieux (the best). 2) LE/LA/LES PIRE(S) are adjectives used to describe a noun - when some thing is 'the worst' of the group. Adjectives must adapt (in number and gender) to the noun they describe. These are the opposites of le meilleur / la meilleure / les meilleurs / les meilleures.

question: In addition to le pire / la pire / les pires... what is another way to express 'the worst'?
answer: le PLUS mauvais / la PLUS mauvaise / les PLUS mauvais(es) can be used when 'the worst' references a noun. e.g. La maison est la pire (fem sing). = La maison est la PLUS mauvaise (fem sing).

question: Chloé sings the worst.
answer: Chloé chante LE PLUS MAL.; Use le plus mal (instead of le/la/les pire(s)) because 'worst' refers to the verb 'sings'. Le plus mal does not need to agree (in number and gender) with a noun.

question: Simone and Camille sing the worst.
answer: Simone et Camille chantent LE PLUS MAL.; Use le plus mal (instead of le/la/les pire(s)) because 'worst' refers to the verb 'sing'. Le plus mal does not need to agree (in number and gender) with a noun.

question: The banana is the worst. + The tea is the worst.
answer: La banane est la pire (fem sing). + Le thé est le pire (masc sing.); Use le/la/les pire(s) because 'worst' references a noun instead of an action.

question: The tomatoes are the worst. + The lemons are the worst.
answer: Les tomates sont les pires (fem plural). + Les citrons sont les pires (masc plural).; Use le/la/les pire(s) because 'worst' references a noun instead of an action.

question: conjugate 'to be'
answer: être: je suis + tu es ('ay') + il/elle/on est ('ay') + nous sommes + vous êtes ('vooz-eht')+ ils/elles sont ('ssson')

question: When is est (conjugated 'to be') pronounced as 'ayt' instead of 'ay'?
answer: when the adjective following it starts with a vowel; e.g. Ils est intelligente; If the t in est was not pronounced is would be two vowels together and that is not how french is spoken; But otherwise the t at the end of est is never pronounced.

question: When is et (and) pronounced as 'ayt' instead of 'ay'?
answer: Never. Never make the t sound - even when the next word starts with a vowel; e.g. Elle est grande et intelligente - the pronounciation of et does not change.

question: conjugate 'to have'
answer: avoir: j'ai + tu as + il/elle/on a + nous avons + vous avez + ils/elles ont

question: conjugate 'to do'
answer: faire: je fais + tu fais + il/elle/on fait + nous faisons + vous faites + il/elles font

question: What is the difference between FAIRE and SE FAIRE?
answer: faire: to do + se faire: to get done; Making the verb reflexive (in this case) is a way to emphasize the verb.

question: What is the radical of a verb?
answer: The radical is the base of a verb - it generally does not change as the verb is conjugated.; NB: For group 1 (-er) and group 2 (-ir) verbs the radical is the part of the infinitive minus ER and IR.; Conjugation for group 3 verbs is more difficult. Some of those verbs have multiple radicals. e.g. ALLER uses the radicals: all (nous allons) + v (je vais) + ir (nous irons)

question: How do you conjugate group 1 verbs (regular -ER verbs) in present tense?
answer: endings: je -e (only pronouce the radical) + tu -es (silent) + il/elle/on -e (silent) + nous -ons (pronounced like nasal 'on') + vous -ez (pronounced like 'ay') + ils/elles -ent (-ent is ALWAYS silent in verbs but it forces the pronunciation of the previous letter)

question: What is the intonation on the conjugated forms for first person singular (je)?
answer: the intonation is always downward and shortened; e.g. je travaille sounds like 'ju tru-vay' not 'ju trav-a-ye'.

question: How do you pronounce the ending for the nous form of -ER verbs?
answer: the ending for nous is -ons ('ohn' very nasal without much of an 'n' sound on the end); this is the same sound as the on in il/elle/on ..when we use the casual form of 'we' when speaking

question: What is the only verb ending in -ER that is totally irregular?
answer: aller (to go)

question: What are some variations or small irregularities that occur when conjugating -ER verbs and which forms to they impact? (disregard the totally irregular verb ALLER)
answer: 1) In some cases there is an accent change in the second syllable when conjugating -ER verbs au présent (e.g. acheter + préférer); 2) For -YER verbs the Y can stay a Y or it can change to I before adding the endings. Either spelling is 100% correct but the pronunciations are slightly different. If we keep the Y in the spelling then the 'y' sound is heard more in the pronunciation.; When there are irregularities in conjugating -ER verbs au présent all forms are impacted EXCEPT nous and vous forms - those two forms are conjugated exactly as you would expect for -ER verbs.

question: How do you conjugate group 2 verbs (regular -ir verbs) in present tense?
answer: endings: je -is ('ee') + tu -is ('ee') + il/elle/on -it ('ee') + nous -issons ('ee-soh'; nasal and pouty) + vous -issez ('ee-say') + ils/elles -issent ('ees' -ent is ALWAYS silent in verbs but it forces the pronunciation of the previous consonant); NB: Sortir is not a regular -IR verb.

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to finish'.
answer: finir (regular -ir verb): je finis + tu finis + il/elle/on finit + nous finissons + vous finissez + ils/elles finissent ('fi-nees'; The double S changes the sound of the I and -ent is always silent on verbs.)

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to choose'
answer: choisir (regular -ir verb): je choisis + tu choisis + il/elle/on choisit + nous choisissons ('shwa-Zee-Sohn'; The single S makes a Z sound. The double S makes a Z sound because in between vowels.) + vous choisissez ('shwa-See-Say') + ils/elles choisissent

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to grow up'
answer: grandir (regular -ir verb): je grandis + tu grandis + il/elle/on grandit + nous grandissons + vous grandissez + ils/elles grandissent ('gran-dees'; -ent is silent on verbs); NB: Avoid confusion with GROSSIR whish means to put on weight.

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to see'.
answer: voir: je vois ('vwa') + tu vois + il voit + nous voyons + vous voyez + ils voient

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to receive'.
answer: recevoir; past participle: reçu; NB: This is VOIR with a prefix. So the conjugation of RECEVOIR (using radical REÇ) mirrors the conjugation of VOIR (using radical V). Except the nous and vous forms use radical REC (without cedille). je reçois + tu reçois + il reçoit + nous recevons + vous recevez + ils reçoivent

question: I would receive (conditionnel). + I would have received (conditionnel passé).
answer: Je reçevrais. + J'aurais reçu.

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to like'.
answer: aimer: j'aime + tu aimes + il/elle/on aime + nous aimons + vous aimez + ile/elles aiment

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to want'.
answer: vouloir: je veux ('voo' at the top of the mouth - NOT the deep U sound) + tu veux ('voo') + il/elle/on veut ('voo') + nous voulons ('voo-lon') + vous voulez ('voo-lay') + ils/elle veulent ('vuhl'; the -ent is not pronounced in verbs); NB: veux and veut are NOT pronounced 'voo'; VOUS - the subject pronoun - is pronounced 'voo'; VEUX and VEUT are pronounced like something between 'vuh' and 'voo' (same as PEUX) so that it is possible to distinguish them from VOUS; past participle: voulu

question: How do you pronounce... I want + I go + I see?
answer: Je veux ('voo' but higher in the mouth similar to 'vuh') + Je vais ('vay') + Je vois ('vwa')

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to go'.
answer: aller: je vais + tu va + il/elle/on va + nous allons + vous allez +ils/elles vont

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to come'.
answer: venir: je vien ('vyon') + tu viens ('vyon') + il/elle/on vient ('vyon') + nous venons ('vo-non') + vous venez ('ve-nay') + ils/elles viennent ('vyen'; NB: The double N changes the sound of the vowel that precedes the pair. 'vy' becomes 'vyeh'.)

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to do' / 'to make' (something).
answer: faire: je fais ('fay') + tu fais ('fay') + il/elle/on fait ('fay') + nous faisons + vous faites + ils/elles font ('fon')

question: to rejuvinate or renovate (a building or a face)
answer: refaire; rénové(e) = renovated

question: the insulation (in a building)
answer: la isolation

question: Idiomatic way to say: You sound like X. (e.g. my mother + a politician)
answer: On croirait entendre X.; Use On (not Tu/Vous). This is a way to make a joke / rib someone.

question: to make someone feel a certain way + He makes me sick.
answer: When we use 'make' in this way we use the verb RENDRE instead of FAIRE. Il me rend malade. = He makes me sick.; Other examples: They make me tired + confused + crazy + nervous. I make it warm.

question: That accent makes/drives me crazy.
answer: Cet accent me rend fou/folle (m/f).; Use RENDRE when you mean to make someone feel a certain way.

question: The sun makes me tired.
answer: There are two ways to express this: 1) Using RENDRE: Le soleil me rend fatigué(e). 2) Using the verb FATIGUER (to fatigue): Le soleil me fatigue.

question: It makes me sad.
answer: Ça me rend triste.; SE RENDRE = to make something feel

question: It makes me feel good.
answer: Ça me fait du bien.; This is the idiomatic to express the sentiment. Do not use SENTIR in this case.; Alternative: Ça me rend heureuse.

question: It makes me think.
answer: Ça me fait réfléchir.; Generally RÉFLÉCHIR is not used reflexively. And that is the case here. The pronom ME refers to the verb FAIRE as in 'it makes me... do something'.

question: conjugate 'to take'
answer: prendre is irregular; je prends ('pruh') + tu prends ('pruh') + il/elle/on prend ('pruh') + nous prenons ('pruh-non' ...nasal ending)+ vous prenez ('pruh-nay') + ils/els prennent ('prehn'); NB: The double N in prennent changes the sound of the first syllable.; past participle: pris

question: to make a decision
answer: prendre une décision; Use prendre - not faire - in this case.

question: to decide + to decide to do something
answer: décider is the infinitive; past participle: décidé; I decide to do something = Je décide + DE + INFINITIVE VERB. e.g. I decide to try. = Je décide d'essayer.

question: to order (food)
answer: commander; NB: When you are actually ordering food you use PRENDRE e.g. Je prends des fraises. = I'll take some strawberries. But the verb that describes the action of ordering is COMMANDER - not PRENDRE.

question: to get back on the road
answer: REprendre la route; Use the verb prendre. Emphasize the repetitiveness of the action by adding RE prefix.

question: to keep + to save
answer: garder (to keep) + sauver (to save)

question: conjugate 'to be able to'; often used as a helper verb (e.g. I can wait. You can work.)
answer: pouvoir: je peux ('juh pooh') + tu peux ('pooh') + il/elle/on peut ('pooh') + nous pouvons ('pooh-von') + vous pouvez ('pooh-vay') + ils/elles peuvent ('puhv'; the -ent is NOT pronounced in verbs)

question: conjugate 'to have to' / 'must' (do something)
answer: devoir followed by infinitive of action verb: je dois X ('dwa') + tu dois X ('dwa') + il/elle/on doit X ('dwa') + nous devons X ('duh-von') + vous devez X ('duh-vay') + ils/elles doivent X ('dwav')

question: I must read.
answer: Je dois ('dwa') lire.; Use the verb devoir and add the infinitive form of whatever you must do (e.g. lire).

question: I must go to the store.
answer: Je dois aller au magasin.;  Use the verb devoir and add the infinitive form of whatever you must do (e.g. aller).

question: How do you pronounce: They must eat.?
answer: Ils doivent manger. ('eel-dwa-manj-ay'); remember -ent is often dropped when pronouncing the third person plural

question: to need (something)
answer: avoir besoin DE (quelque chose); NB: Use avoir besoin DE... when a thing/object is needed. If you need to do something - then use the verb devoir + INFINITIVE instead.

question: I need the coffee. + You need the table.
answer: J'ai besoin du café (de + le = du). + Tu as besoin de la table.; NB: Use avoir besoin DE... when a thing/object is needed.

question: We need a boat. + She needs a dress.
answer: On a besoin d'un bateau. + Elle a besoin d'une robe.; NB: Use avoir besoin DE... when a thing/object is needed.

question: He needs privacy.
answer: Il a besoin d'intimité.

question: I would need X.
answer: J'aurais besoin X.; Use conditionnel version of AVOIR BESOIN.

question: What is the difference between DEVOIR and AVOIR besoin?
answer: Sometimes they can be used interchangeably but generally DEVOIR preceeds a verb and AVOIR BESOIN precedes a noun.; If you use DEVOIR followed by a noun then it means to owe - not to need.

question: I owe you a euro.
answer: Je te dois un euro.

question: Which three verbs are only conjugated in the 3rd person singular (il/elle)?
answer: falloir (to be required) + pleuvoir (to rain) + valoir (to be worth)

question: conjugate 'to know' (some information) AND give the past participle.
answer: savoir; past participle: su; conjugation: je sais + tu sais + il/elle/on sait + nous nous + vous savons + ils/els savent ('sav')

question: to know (to be familiar with)
answer: connaître (+ noun); Do not use DE or AVEC. e.g. Elle connaît la ville. (She knows - is familiar with - the city.); connaître can mean to know a someone personally or to know OF that person.

question: I didn't know that.
answer: Je ne connaissais/savais pas.; Use imparfait tense because you didn't know it before but now you do know it - something that was true in the past but is different now (similar to telling a story)

question: I didn't know X. What tense should the phrase X be in?
answer: Typically the phrase should be in the imparfait because you are describing some memory that you thought about in one way and now you know differently.

question: I haven't seen/heard of that (before).
answer: Je n'ai jamais entendu parler de ça.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.; In this case passé composé is the best choic in french. Though in English we use plus que parfait (had seen/heard).; The 'before/already' is implied in french. We do not need to add 'déja' for this specific expression.

question: I studied at this school before.
answer: J'ai déja étudié à cette école avant.; Use DÉJA to express 'already'. It modifies the verb so it is placed between the auxiliary and the past participle in passé composé.

question: I went to the store already. + I already went there.
answer: Je suis déjà allé(e) au magasin. + J'y suis déja allé(e).; Passé composé is a good choice in this case because the statement is straightforward in the past. The speaker is not using past perfect (had been).; Déja should fall between the two parts of the verb in both cases in french.; Déja is the word to use for a direct translation of 'already' or for when we use the word before to mean already. e.g. I went to the store (before).

question: Were you (informal) in the Netherlands? + Were you there?
answer: Est-ce que tu as été aux Pays-Bas ('pay-ee-bah')? + Est-ce que tu Y as été?; Use pronom Y to reference a location.; Passé composé is a good choice in this case because the question is straightforward in the past. The speaker is not using past perfect (had been).

question: Were you (informal) in the Netherlands before/already? + Were you there before/already?
answer: Est-ce que tu as DÉJA été aux Pays-Bas? + Est-ce que tu Y as DÉJA été?; Déja always lies between the two parts of the verb.; Déja is the word to use for 'already' or for 'before' in situations where it can be replaced with 'already'.

question: Have you gone/been to Germany before/already?
answer: Est-ce que tu étais DÉJA allé(e) en Allemagne?; In this case ALLER and plus que parfait are the best choices in french.; Déja is the word to use for 'already' or for 'before' in situations where it can be replaced with 'already'. Déja always lies between the two parts of the verb.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.

question: Have you gone/been there before/already?
answer: Est-ce que tu Y étais DÉJA allé(e)?; Use pronom Y to reference a location.

question: conjugate 'to hate'
answer: détester: je déteste + tu détestes + il/elle/on déteste + nous détestons + vous détestez + ils/els détestent

question: to hate eating
answer: détester manger; No preposition is required after détester to join with another verb. Just conjugate the first verb.

question: conjugate 'to appreciate'
answer: apprécier: j'apprécie + tu apprécies + il/elle/on apprécie + nous apprécions + vous appréciez + ils/elles apprécient

question: How do you remember which verb tenses use a radical and which tenses use the entire infinitive as their base (before adding the ending for each form)?
answer: Use a radical - not necessarily the same one - in the past and present (passé composé + imparfait + présent). Use the full infinitive - or variation on the infinitive - in the future (futur proche + futur simple + conditionnel).; NB: The endings for the imparfait ('past-like') and conditionnel ('future-like') are exactly the same BUT their bases are different.

question: How do you remember which verb radical to use in imparfait vs futur simple/conditionnel?
answer: There is no hard rule. Generally for irregular verbs... the radical in the past tenses does NOT have an R at the end. But the radical in the future tenses does have an R at the end.; e.g. DEVOIR... je DEVais (imparfait) je DEVRais (conditionnel); e.g. POUVOIR... je POUVais (imparfait) je POURRais (conditionnel); e.g. AVOIR... j'AVais (imparfait) j'AURais (conditionnel); e.g. ALLER... j'ALLais (imparfait) j'IRais (conditionnel)

question: I go to the office at 8am.
answer: Je vais au bureau à 8 heures.

question: that last week / the previous week
answer: la semaine dernière / la semaine précédente; you could make the latter plural: les semaines précedentes - the previous weeks

question: the last (of something) / the new (of something)
answer: la dernier X / la nouveau X; nouveau/nouvelle is one of the adjectives that comes before the noun it modifies.

question: in the last lesson
answer: au dernier cours; NB: dernier/dernière (m/f)

question: a lesson
answer: une leçon / un cours (more like 'a class')

question: I have french lessons every Sunday online.
answer: J'ai des cours de français tous les dimanches en ligne.

question: We watch football (soccer). / We watch a game of football.
answer: On regarde DU foot. / On regarde un match de foot.; plural of match = matchs

question: I wanted to go to more (football) matches.
answer: Je voulais aller à plus de matchs.; Use imparfait of VOULOIR (instead of passé composé) because it is a state of being and whatever you wanted in the past is different from what you want at this moment. Also it is much more polite to express this with imparfait - just as we would use conditionnel (voudrais) to express what we want in the present.

question: a game (like a boardgame)
answer: un jeu; pronounced just like the word for I (je)

question: a video game
answer: un jeu video

question: the olympic games
answer: les jeux olympiques ('lay-zhoo-Zo-lim-peek'); There is a Z liaison between jeux and olympiques.; Often people abbreviate: J.O. ('zshee-oh' - like 'geo').

question: a team + the women's/men's team
answer: un équipe + l'equipe féminin/masculin

question: the stadium
answer: le stade

question: to play with words / to play with fire
answer: You can make a literal translation in these cases. JOUER + AVEC.; jouer avec les mots / jouer avec le feu

question: What are the three major ways to express doing some activity?
answer: 1) FAIRE + DU / DE LA / DES / D' + some activity  2) JOUER + AU / À LA / AUX  + game/sport 3) JOUER + DU / DE LA / DES / D' + music/musical instrument; à + le = au; à + les = aux; de + le = du; de + les = des; d' is used when the following word starts with a vowel

question: to play sports + to play football (soccer)
answer: faire du sport + jouer au foot OR faire du foot; With football you can use either JOUER or FAIRE.

question: I play tennis.
answer: Je joue ('zshoo') au tennis.; JOUER + À because tennis is a sport/game.; Tennis is masculine singular. à + le = AU.; The present tense conjugations of jouer (e.g. je joue) have only one syllable - despite the multiple vowels - and they sound exactly the same as the word for cheek (une joue)

question: You play pétanque.
answer: Tu joues ('zshoo') à la pétanque.; JOUER + À because pétanque is a sport/game.; Pétangue is feminine singular so à la remains À LA.

question: We play chess.
answer: Nous jouons ('zshoo-ohn'; pronounced almost as a single syllable) aux échecs.; JOUER + À because chess is a sport/game.; Échecs is plural. à + les = AUX.

question: They play cards. + They play poker.
answer: Ils jouent ('zshoo') aux cartes. + Ils jouent au Poker ('poe-kehR'; The R is pronounced in this case because it is not a french word.); JOUER + À because cards is a sport/game.; Cartes is plural. à + les = AUX.

question: He plays piano.
answer: Il joue ('zshoo') du piano.; JOUER + DE because we are talking about music/musical instrument.; Piano is masculine singular. de + le = du

question: His friend plays the flute.
answer: Son ami joue ('zshoo') de la flûte.; JOUER + DE because we are talking about music/musical instrument.; Flûte is feminine singular.

question: She plays the drums / the guitar.
answer: Elle joue ('zshoo') de la batterie / de la guitare.; JOUER + DE because we are talking about music/musical instrument.; Drums and guitar are both feminine singular in french.

question: I do not know how to play the violin.
answer: Je ne se pas faire du violin.; Use SAVOIR (not connaître) to talk about knowing how to play an instrument.

question: They play hip-hop music.
answer: Ils font de la musique hip-hop.; We do not use the verb JOUER in this case. Use FAIRE + DE instead.; La musique is feminine singular.

question: My friends played music (with instruments); Specify the pronunciation.
answer: Mes amis ont ('a-mee-ont'; NO liaison) fait de la musique.; There is not liaison after amis when using the verb avoir (conjugated as ont in this case); We do not use the verb JOUER in this case. Use faire de la musique instead.

question: We played some games.
answer: On a joué à quelques jeux.; Use quelqueS because games is plural.

question: He played soccer.
answer: Il jouait au football.; Use imparfait to describe someone's hobby in the past.

question: I dance. + I ski.
answer: Je fais DE LA danse. + Je fais DU ski.; Use FAIRE + DE.; La dance is feminine singular. Le ski is masculine singular. de + le = du.

question: He rides a bike.
answer: Il fait du vélo.; Use FAIRE + DE. Le vélo is masculine singular. de + le = du.

question: She rides horses.
answer: Elle fait de l'équitation.; Use FAIRE + DE. l'équitation makes the contraction because it starts with a vowel.

question: to do gymnastics + to do yoga
answer: faire de la gymnastique + faire du yoga; Use FAIRE + DE. DE + LE = DU.

question: to go hiking + to go climbing
answer: faire de la randonnée (feminine) + faire de l'escalade (feminine)

question: I go to the gym.
answer: Je vais à la salle du sport.

question: to exercise + to do cardio
answer: faire de l'exercice + faire du cardio; Alternatives: pour endurance (for endurance) / rester en forme (to stay in shape)

question: to listen to the music
answer: ècouter de la musique; remember to always use a preposition and an article (DE LA) after écouter

question: a guitar + a drum + a bass
answer: une guitare + un tambour + une basse

question: a harp + a trumpet + a violin
answer: une harpe + une trompette + un violon

question: to look after someone
answer: s'occuper de

question: We stay here.
answer: On reste ici.

question: a household
answer: un ménage; This can mean a couple or any group of people that live together.

question: to buy
answer: acheter; NB: achats ('ah-sha') is the noun for purchases and is derived from acheter

question: How does acheter change as it is conjugated au présent?
answer: j'achète + tu achètes + il achète + nous achetons + vous achetez + ils achètent; acheter is an -ER verb so the minor variations (adding accent grave è) do not impact the nous and vous forms.

question: to browse / to go bargain hunting
answer: chiner; a bargain-hunter = chineur/euse; CHINER = to browse / to go bargain-hunting

question: to go shopping (for luxury clothing or goods)
answer: faire du shopping; This is not running errands - it's specifically for a luxurious experience.

question: to go shopping (for daily food + home goods/furniture + clothing + gifts)
answer: faire les courses; This means running errands

question: to do housework + to tidy up
answer: faire le ménage + ranger; e.g. ranger des affaires = to get the affairs in order

question: Use for housework. + Do not use for housework.
answer: Utilisez pour faire le ménage. + N'utilisez pas pour faire le ménage.

question: the task
answer: la tâche

question: the chores + to share the chores
answer: les tâches ménagéres + partager des tâches

question: to share (e.g. a plate)
answer: partager

question: to split a bill 50/50
answer: faire moitié moitié OR faire moit moit (both Ts are pronounced; more casual) OR faire 50/50

question: to put together the furniture + to arrange the furniture
answer: MONTER/constuire les meubles + AMÉNAGER les meubles; SURMONTER can mean 'to mount' or 'to overcome'.; AMÉNAGER can also mean to 'fit out' a space + landscape a terrain + to 'put in' an installation + to develop a neighborhood.

question: to disassemble the furniture
answer: démonter les meubles; MONTER = to assemble (among other things)

question: to come together / to gather
answer: (se) assembler or (se) rassembler; It is common in french to add R- or RE- prefix to a verb to emphasize it. This does not necessarily mean that the verb is performed again - though it might mean that. e.g. couvert and recouvert (emphasizes the covering)

question: to open + to cover
answer: ouvrir + couvrir; COUVRIR is typically conjugated similar to OUVRIR.; NB: ROUVRIR (to open again) and RECOUVRIR (to cover again) are often used to simply mean 'to open' or 'to cover'. Adding the R- prefix is a way to emphasize the verb.

question: to discover + to reveal
answer: découvrir + révéler; Conjugation is similar to OUVRIR (e.g. past participle: découvert).;

question: the discovery
answer: la découverte

question: to burry + to escavate/uncover
answer: enterrer + deterrer

question: to wrap + to unwrap
answer: emballer + déballer

question: arranged well (like for a room) + disorganized
answer: bien rangé(e) / bien organisé(e) + dérangé(e) / désorganisé(e); NB: SE DÉRANGER = to be bothered by something

question: messy
answer: désordonné(e) OR en désordre; the disorder = le désordre

question: organized (like for a person) + to have a sense of organization
answer: organisé(e) + avoir un sens ('sohnS'; S is pronounced) d'organisation

question: well-situated / in a good location
answer: bien situé(e)

question: well-decorated + well-equipped
answer: bien décoré(e) + bien equipé(e)

question: to clean + the cleaning
answer: nettoyer + le nettoyage; NB: You cannot use 'le nettoyage' on its own. You must specify WHAT is being cleaned during the cleaning. e.g. Il y avait beaucoup de nettoyage À faire chez nous. = There was a lot of cleaning (happening) at our place.

question: to dry
answer: se sécher

question: dry + wet
answer: sec/sèche (m/f) + mouillé(e)

question: to do the laundry (to wash clothes) + to iron the clothes
answer: faire la lessive + repassage; s'occuper du linge = washing AND drying AND ironing clothes

question: to wash the dishes by hand + to wash the dishes in a dishwasher + to wash the dishes in a restaurant
answer: faire la viselle (means by hand) +  mettre dans le lave-vaisselle + faire la plonge (means professionally in a restaurant)

question: to eat without having to do dishes
answer: manger sans la vaisselle

question: to sweep
answer: ramoner; This is the word to use for cleaning a chimney.

question: to fix things / to tinker
answer: bricoler

question: makeshift job / Do-It-Yourself
answer: le bricolage; e.g. Elle aime le bricolage = She likes doing DIY (activities).

question: sewing / tailoring
answer: la couture

question: to mend
answer: recoudre

question: to repair + recover
answer: réparer + récupérer

question: to repaint (a room)
