answer: J'ai moins DE sommeil quand d'autres personnes restent chez nous.; Use the noun for sleep in this case (le sommeil) with the verb AVOIR - instead of the verb (dormir).; NB: If you omit the DE then the meaning is very different. e.g. J'ai moins sommeil. = I need less sleep.

question: I slept well last night.
answer: Je passe une bonne nuit.

question: to sleep in + I slept in.
answer: faire une grasse matinée + J'ai fait une grasse matinée.; Grasse does not have a direct translation - it is just part of this phrase that means to sleep in.

question: to be sleepy + to be asleep
answer: AVOIR sommeil + ÊTRE endormi

question: the sleep
answer: le sommeil

question: to curl up (like a cat)
answer: se blottir

question: idiomatic way to express going to sleep (like a child)
answer: dodo

question: idiomatic saying that means all I do is work and sleep - no fun
answer: C'est métro boulot dodo.

question: It is night / dark outside.
answer: Il fait nuit.; Do not use soir or soirée in this case.

question: to wash / to wash oneself
answer: laver / se laver

question: to take a shower
answer: se doucher (reflexive) OR prendre une douche

question: I do not take a shower.
answer: Je NE me douche PAS.;NB: For reflexive verbs the NE comes before both the verb and the associated pronoun. Like non-reflexive verbs the PAS comes after the verb when using a reflexive verb.

question: to shave
answer: se raser; the S sounds like a Z because between to vowels

question: to brush (hair or teeth)
answer: se brosser

question: the toothpaste
answer: le dentifrice

question: the toothbrush
answer: la brosse à dents

question: the hairbrush
answer: la brosse á cheveux ('sheh-vooh'); EUX makes an 'oo' sound; The word for horse is chevaux which is 'sheh-voh'.

question: the hairdryer
answer: le sèche-cheveux ('sheh-vooh') OR le séchoir à cheveux

question: the curling iron
answer: le fer à friser

question: the shampoo + the conditioner
answer: le shampooing ('sham-pwa') + l'après-shampooing

question: to put on makeup + to take off makeup
answer: se maquiller + se démaquiller; makeup = le maquillage

question: to get dressed
answer: s'habiller; reflexive verb that starts with a vowel b/c H is silent; This can be used to say you are wearing something but could also use prendre.

question: to get undressed
answer: se déshabiller (reflexive verb)

question: idiomatic way to say: to get dressed up / dressed to the 9's
answer: SE METTRE sur son 31; e.g. Je me suis mis (conjugated METTRE) sur mon 31.; Alternative: s'habiller bien

question: She dressed well. + She did not dress well.
answer: Elle se suis BIEN habillée. + Elle NE se suis PAS BIEN habillée.; BIEN (and any adverbs) are placed in between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé - along with PAS.

question: to agree
answer: s'accorder

question: to resolve
answer: résoudre

question: to find
answer: Two verbs are possible. They both work for people and things. 1) TROUVER when you find something that you didn't have or didn't know beforehand. e.g. when you find a bar you never knew about before 2) RETROUVER when you find something (or meet someone) that you lost or knew a long time ago. e.g. to find your keys that you had lost e.g. to see a friend that you have not seen in a very long time

question: I found a new teacher. I found a house.
answer: Use TROUVER without a reflexive pronoun: J'ai trouvé un nouveau professeur. + J'ai trouvé une maison.; NB: If you already knew the thing that you found (e.g. to find keys after losing them) then you must use RETROUVER instead of TROUVER. Trouver is only for people and things that you find for the first time.

question: I find myself in a new world. + I find myself funny.
answer: Use TROUVER reflexively: Je ME trouve dans un nouveau monde. + Je ME trouve drôle.; NB: If you mean that you found yourself after being lost then you must use RETROUVER instead of TROUVER.

question: Where does one find X? + Here you find X.
answer: On y trouve X? + On y trouve X.; These are common ways to talk about the location of things ('here we find X')

question: I find that the project is interesting. + I find the project interesting.
answer: Je trouve QUE le projet est intéressant. + Je trouve le projet intéressant.; These two structures are exactly the same in english and french: 1) TROUVER QUE + entire phrase 2) TROUVER + noun or adjective

question: I find that the position/post is fascinating. + I find the position fascinating.
answer: Je trouve QUE le poste/poste est fascinant. + Je trouve le poste fascinant.; NB: passionnant = fascinating  passionné(e) = keen

question: to do without
answer: se passer DE; This verb always uses DE before the object.

question: to lack something
answer: manquer DE quelque chose; When you use manquer to mean 'to lack' (something) then you must place DE after the verb and before the something.

question: to miss something + to miss someone
answer: manquer + se manquer; Use the verb reflexively when you mean to miss a person (instead of a thing).; MANQUER also means 'to lack'. MANQUER + DE = to lack something. MANQUER alone (without preposition) = to miss something.

question: The quiche lacks salt.
answer: La quiche manque DE sel.; Use MANQUER + DE to express a lack OF something.

question: There is a page missing from this book.
answer: Il manque une page dans ce livre.; Use MANQUER + DE to express a lack of something.

question: I missed my train.
answer: J'ai manqué mon train.; Use MANQUER (without a preposition) to mean 'to miss something'.; NB: It's also common to use RATER (to fail) to express this: J'ai raté mon train.

question: Very informal to way to express: I missed my bus.
answer: J’ai loupé mon bus.; This uses a very informal verb: LOUPER.; When writing use MANQUER or RATER. But you will hear LOUPER spoken in familiar situations.

question: You didn't miss anything.
answer: Tu n’as rien manqué.; Use MANQUER (without preposition) to mean 'to miss something'.

question: I miss you.
answer: Tu me manques.;  Use MANQUER reflexively to mean 'to miss someone' but you also have to invert the order (compared to english).

question: I miss my parents.
answer: Mes parents me manquent.; Use MANQUER reflexively to mean 'to miss someone' but you also have to invert the order (compared to english).

question: I miss X Y and Z.
answer: X Y et Z... Ils me manque.; You could say: X Y et Z me manque. But using the pronoun ils is more correct. In any case you have to list the items first because they are the subject. I is the object represented by the pronoun 'me'.

question: to lose
answer: perdre; past participle: perdu; NB: to lose weight is a different verb: maigrir

question: to forget / overlook; conjugate and give pronunciation
answer: oublier ('oh-blee-yay'): j'oublie ('zshow-blee') + tu oublies ('o-blee') + il oublie ('o-blee') + nous oublions ('o-blee-on') + vous oubliez ('o-blee-ay')+ ils oublient ('o-blee'); NB: tu oublies... two vowels are together and it's ok and we do not use liaison. So the prohibition of two vowel sounds together has exceptions.; Do not confuse oublier (to forget) with obliger (to obligate).

question: I will write it in order not to forget it.
answer: Je vais l'écrire pour ne pas l'oublier.

question: to obligate / force
answer: obliger ('oh-blee-zshay'); Do not confuse oublier (to forget) with obliger (to obligate).

question: I force you (familiar) to do your homework.
answer: Je t'oblige à faire tes devoir.; Literally: I obligate you (to do something).

question: the strength (physical)
answer: la force

question: strong + weak
answer: fort(e) + faible; NB: faible can mean a small(er) amount in French. It does not always literally mean weak.

question: a strength (of character/skill) + a weakness
answer: un point fort + un point faible

question: a characteristic
answer: un attribut = an attribute

question: to meet up (with someone you already know)
answer: Two options: 1) (SE) VOIR is the most common. Use this for most cases. e.g. I will see my friend tonight. = Je vais voir mon ami ce soir.; 2) (SE) RETROUVER; retrouver is literally 'to regain' a thing (after being lost) or a person (when you meet up after not seeing them for a long time). e.g. After 10 years my old friend and I met up. = Aprés 10 ans mon vieille amie et moi nous (reflexive pronoun) sommes rencontrés. Use the reflexive form in the last case because what you mean is we meet 'ourselves'.

question: I found my keys.
answer: J'ai retrouvé mes clés.

question: I met up with my friend. + I met up with my friend (that I had not seen in a really long time).
answer: J'ai vu mon ami(e). + Je suis retrouvé(e) mon ami(e).; Use VOIR for meeting up / 'seeing' a person unless you mean that you met up after a very long time.; Do not use RETROUVER reflexively in these cases because you are not doing anything 'to yourself'.; RETROUVER/TROUVER uses avoir as auxiliary. But if you use the verb reflexively then use être as the auxiliary AND the participle must agree in gender and number with the subject.

question: We will meet again.
answer: Nous nous allons voir encore.; This is an example of when you use VOIR reflexively because what you really mean is: We will see EACHOTHER again.

question: to meet (someone for the first time OR someone by chance without planning)
answer: (se) rencontrer ('rohn-kohn-tray'); past participle: rencontré; Remember there are 2x Ns and TR sound. It is very different from raconter (to tell a story; 'ra-kohn-Tay'; 'ra' is like the word 'rad' without the D or the word 'racoon').

question: I met (for the first time) my friend.
answer: J'ai rencontré mon ami(e).; Use rencontrer (instead of retrouver) because you are meeting for the first time or by chance.; You do not need to use the verb reflexively because all of the people meeting up are specified. So use avoir as the auxiliary and only one form of the past participle in passé composé.

question: I met them (for the first time).
answer: Je les ai rencontré.; In french 'them' is a direct object so we use LES to represent the plural people.

question: We met (for the first time) in Berlin.
answer: On s'est rencontrés à Berlin.; Use rencontrer (instead of retrouver) because you are meeting for the first time or by chance.; 'with eachother' is implied so you need to use the reflexive form of the verb. That means that in passé composé the auxiliary changes to être and the past participle must agree in gender and number with the subject.

question: They (all men / all women) met (for the first time).
answer: Ils se sont rencontrés. / Elles se sont rencontrées.

question: How did you meet them?
answer: Comment tu les as rencontré?; Use rencontrer (instead of retrouver) because you are meeting for the first time. ;You do not need to use the reflexive form because both you (tu) and them (les) are specified - there is no implied 'eachother'.

question: Did you meet them all in France?
answer: Est-ce que tu les as tous rencontrés en France?

question: Pay attention to pronunciation: She will tell a story.
answer: futur simple: Elle racontera ('ra-kohn-tra') une histoire.; The penultimate syllable gets dropped (like medecin). This would not happen if there was an R directly after the T in the infinitive form.; The infinitive is raconter ('ra-kohn-tay') where the first syllable is like the first syllable of 'racoon'.

question: Pay attention to pronunciation: She will meet Marc (for the first time).
answer: futur simple: Elle rencontrera Marc. ('rohn-kohn-truh-ra'); All of the syllables are pronounced - you cannot drop any of them.; The first syllable is a classic french E - something between 'rohn' and 'ruhn'.

question: a meeting
answer: une réunion

question: to avoid
answer: éviter

question: physics + mechanics
answer: la physique + la mécanique

question: a movement
answer: un mouvement

question: to move around physically or to start moving
answer: bouger; This verb can be used reflexively if an animate object is moving itself.; Bouger is not the best verb for moving from one location to another (déplacer) or for moving from one city to another for change of life (déménager).

question: to move from one location to another
answer: déplacer; This verb can be used reflexively if an animate object is moving itself.; Déplacer is not the best verb for moving around in a space (bouger) or for moving from one city to another for change of life (déménager).

question: to move (from one city to another)
answer: déménager = to move permanently from one city to another; Do not use this word for physical movement.

question: to move in (to a new house)
answer: emménager

question: He moved from Naples. He moved to Sardinia.
answer: Il a déménagé de Naples. + Il a emménagé à Bologne.; déménager = to move from a place. Use DE instead of À.; emménager = to move to a new place. Use À.

question: to install or put something up
answer: installer (without reflexive pronoun); Alternative: mettre en place (literally: to put in place). une mise en place = an installation

question: to settle (especially after a move)
answer: s'installer ('son-sti-lay'); a reflexive verb; l'installation = the settling (e.g. in a city)

question: My family moved a lot. (use passé composé)
answer: Ma famille a déménagé plusiers fois.

question: We moved every two years. (use imparfait)
answer: On déménageait tout les 2 ans.

question: temporary (like a pop-up) + timeless
answer: ephémère + intemporal

question: Where did you go in Croatia?
answer: Où es-tu allé(e) en Croatie?

question: to force + You force me to make a decision.
answer: forcer + Tu me force à prendre une décision.

question: to try (someone or something) ...to give it a chance
answer: tester; This can be used for interviewing someone and trying on clothes.

question: a job interview; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: un entretien d'embauche ('dohm-bowsh' ryhmes with bow like bateau chateau etc; Do not pronounce it 'boosh' because that sounds like the word for mouth instead); un entretien all by itself means an appointment for discussion; Alternative: un entretien de recruitment

question: an interview of someone (journalism)
answer: un interview (journalism); NB: The word interview in french can only be used for this specific type of discussion. To say job interview: un entretien d'embauche.

question: I succeeded in the job interview.
answer: J'ai passé l'entretien (d'embauche).

question: to have experience in X
answer: avoir de l'expérience en X

question: to confide (in someone)
answer: se confier (à quelqu'un)

question: to trust X
answer: To options: 1) faire confiance À (e.g. Je fais confiance au gouvernement.) 2) se fier ('fee-yay'); SE FIER sounds different than fier/fiére ('fyehr') - which is the word for proud.

question: to distrust / beware of X
answer: Two options: 1) ne faire pas confiance DANS (e.g. Je ne fais pas confiance DANS le livre.) 2) se méfier ('may-fee-yay')

question: trustworthy
answer: fiable = reliable

question: to build
answer: construire

question: to frame
answer: encadrer; This is used the same way in french as it is in english. e.g. to frame a picture + to frame a face (after a haircut)

question: to remember
answer: There are two possibilities: 1) SE SOUVENIR is always used reflexively and requires DE between the verb and the object. 2) (SE) RAPPELER can be used for 'to remember' and 'to remind someone of something'. It does not require a reflexive pronoun AND it does not require any preposition between the verb and the object.

question: How do you say: I remember him. Two ways: 1) with SOUVENIR 2) with RAPPELER
answer: 1) Je me souviens de lui. Always reflexive. Always require DE between verb and object. 2) Je me le rappelle. Literally: I remind myself of him. But the object is NOT a tonique pronoun because (SE) RAPPELER does not use DE.

question: I remember it.; What is the infinitive of the verb?
answer: Je m'EN souviens. (juh-muh-soo-vyuh); SE SOUVENIR (to remember) is the verb and it is reflexive (me/m'); Pronom EN replaces 'it' because SE SOUVENIR is followed by DE. Do NOT use regular pronouns for the 'it'. e.g. Do NOT say: Je me le souviens.;  Pronom EN replaces a quantity of something or the complement of a phrase following DE (e.g. J'ai pense DE...).

question: I don't remember it.
answer: Je ne m'EN souviens pas.; Use pronom EN (instead of pronom Y) to refer to 'it' because SE SOUVENIR is always followed by DE when the object of the verb is more explicit.

question: I don't remember the conjugation.
answer: Je ne me souviens pas DE la conjugaison.; SE SOUVENIR (conjugated) + DE + the thing that was forgotten

question: I don't remember everything.
answer: Je ne me souviens pas DE tout.; SE SOUVENIR (conjugated) + DE + the thing that was forgotten

question: I will try to remember it.
answer: Je vais essayer DE m'EN souvenir.; Use DE between essayer and a second verb. Use EN to refer to the thing that you are remembering. The reflexive pronoun (ME) must adapt to the subject even though we are using the infinitive form of the verb: SOUVENIR.

question: idiomatic way to say: You told me about that.
answer: Tu m'en a parlé. Use PARLER (instead of DIRE) for this expression. EN is the general pronoun for the thing that was told.

question: Everything is ok.
answer: Tout est okay.

question: What do you remember?
answer: DE qoui te souviens tu?; Remember to use DE with souvenir every time that you refer to what is being remembered (unless you extract it with a pronoun).

question: You remember it. Do you remember it?
answer: Tu t'en souviens. Est-ce que tu te souviens?; NB: m' (which stands for me - reflexive pronoun) is replaced by t' (which stands for te)

question: It helps me to remember.
answer: Ça m'aide me souvenir.

question: a memory
answer: un souvenir OR une mémoire; The difference between these two is subtle. Souvenir describes something you experienced (often with another person). Mémoire speaks more the function of the brain - something that you memorized.

question: to replace / Replace X with Y.
answer: replacer / Replacez X par Y.; The formal you (vous) is understood/omitted in the command.

question: What is the présent progressif verb tense? How is it constructed?
answer: présent progressif emphasizes doing something right now. In English we use gerunds for this which turn verbs into nouns. e.g. I am eating.; ÊTRE conjugated + en train de + INFINITIVE; e.g. Je suis en train de manger.

question: She walks a lot. + She is walking.
answer: Elle marche beaucoup. / Elle est en train de marcher.; The former is simple présent tense. The latter is présent progressif.

question: He was walking.
answer: Il était en train de marcher.; Walking is in the gerund form so we use the présent progressif tense (être + en train de + infinitive). But we also must use imperfect (was doing something). So the conjugated être must be in imparfait: était.

question: I am learning. + I am not learning.
answer: Je suis EN TRAIN D'apprendre. + Je ne suis PAS en train d'apprendre.; When you negate the présent progressif tense PAS is placed directly following the conjugated ÊTRE.

question: I am dressing/getting dressed.
answer: Je suis en train de ME habiller.; When using présent progressif tense with a reflexive verb... the reflexive pronoun stays with the infinitive. But it must adapt to the subject (e.g. me instead of se).

question: What is the passé recent tense? How is it constructed?
answer: VENIR conjugated + DE + INFINITIVE (adapt reflexive pronouns to the subject); This is how you express that something was 'just happening'. e.g. I just read that book. = Je viens de lire ce livre.

question: I just arrived.
answer: Je viens (juste) D'arriver.; Use passé recent: VENIR conjugated + DE + INFINITIVE; Add juste (just) for emphasis.

question: We just woke up.
answer: On vient (juste) DE SE réveiller.; Use passé recent: VENIR conjugated + DE + INFINITIVE; If the verb is reflexive then you must adapt the pronoun to the subject (even though you are using an infinitive). The pronoun is placed directly before the infinitive verb.

question: I just got married.
answer: Je viens DE ME marier.; Use passé recent: VENIR conjugated + DE + INFINITIVE; If the verb is reflexive then you must adapt the pronoun to the subject (even though you are using an infinitive). The pronoun is placed directly before the infinitive verb.

question: They just found a new apartment.
answer: Ils viennent DE trouver un nouvel appartement.; Use passé recent: VENIR conjugated + DE + INFINITIVE

question: He returns tomorrow.
answer: Il revient (présent) demain (futur).; You can use present tense to describe something in the future - just like in english.

question: I leave tonight.
answer: Je pars (présent) ce soir (futur).; You can use present tense to describe something in the future - just like in english.

question: How do you construct a command (impératif aka imperative)?
answer: There are only 3 possibilities: tu + nous + vous. Omit the subject because it is assumed. Then use the present tense conjugation of the verb. For regular -ER verbs: remove the S from the tu form.; e.g. Eat the food.: (tu) Mange / (nous) Mangeons / (vous) Mangez la nourriture.

question: (you informal) Cut the bread.
answer: Coupe le pain.; COUPER is a regular -er verb so we use the present tense conjugation for tu (coupes) and then remove the S.

question: (we / let's) Change the sheets.
answer: Changeons les draps.; CHANGER is the verb. The present tense conjugation for nous is changeons.

question: (you formal) Listen.
answer: écoutez.; ÉCOUTER is the verb. The present tense conjugation for vous is écoutez.

question: How do you construct a command (impératif) for group 2 (-ir) verbs?
answer: Keep the final S in the tu form.; e.g. Finish the food.: (tu) Finis / (nous) Finissons / (vous) Finissez la nourriture.; NB: Sortir is not a regular -IR verb.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Go to the store.
answer: (tu) Va / (nous) Allons / (vous) Allez au magasin.; Aller is treated as a regular -ER verb in this case so we remove the S from the conjugated tu form.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Cook the meat.
answer: (tu) Fais cuire / (nous) Faisons / (vous) Faites le viande.; Faire is an irregular verb so we do not delete the S at the end of the tu verb form!

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Be nice.
answer: (tu) Sois / (nous) Soyons / (vous) Soyez sympa.; être is a fully irregular verb for imperative - you have to memorize the three.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Get a cat.
answer: Use the verb avoir (to have): (tu) Aie / (nous) Ayons / (vous) Ayez un chat.; avoir is a completely irregular verb for imperative - you have to memorize the three.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Put on the coat.
answer: Use the verb mettre (to put): (tu) Mets / (nous) Mettons / (vous) Mettez le manteau.; keep the S on the tu form because mettre is irregular in the imperative case

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Do something.
answer: Use the verb faire: (tu) Fais / (nous) Faisons / (vous) Faites quelque chose.; keep the S on the tu form because faire is irregular in the imperative case

question: How do you construct a command (impératif) for reflexive verbs?
answer: The pronoun gets attached to the end of the verb.; e.g. (you informal) Go for a walk! = Promène-toi!; SE PROMENER is an -er verb so the S is omitted in the you informal form.

question: Let's go for a walk!
answer: (nous) Promenons-nous!; Use the impératif command form. SE PROMENER is the verb. To make the impératif for a reflexive verb attach the pronoun after the verb.

question: (you informal) Hurry up!
answer: Dépêche-toi!; SE DÉPÊCHER = to hurry up (oneself). It is generally used reflexively.

question: (you formal) Register! / Sign up!
answer: (vous) Inscrivez-vous!; Use the impératif command form. S'INSCRIRE is the verb. To make the impératif for a reflexive verb attach the pronoun after the verb.; the registration = l'inscription (from S'INSCRIRE)

question: (you formal) Do not eat that!
answer: (vous) Ne mangez pas ça!; Use the impératif command form. Mangez ça! would be the positive form. To negate it: NE comes directly after where the subject should be. PAS comes directly following the verb.

question: (formal / informal) Drink lots of water.
answer: Bois / Buvez plus de l'eau.; NB: When plus is followed by DE then the S is pronounced 'plooews'.

question: (formal / informal) Always sleep for 8 hours.
answer: Dors / Dormez depuis huit heures pour toutes les nuits.

question: (formal / informal) Stop using your laptop.
answer: Arrête / Arrêtez d'utliser ton / votre ordinateur.

question: (formal / informal) Take some medicine.
answer: Prends / Prenez des médicaments.

question: (formal / informal) Put a wet towel on your forehead.
answer: Mets / Mettez une serviette de toillette humide sur ton / votre front.

question: How do you construct the near future tense in French (le futur proche)?
answer: ALLER conjugated + INFINITIVE of the action verb; The direct translation is 'X is going to do something'. NB: All object pronouns are placed between the two verbs!

question: When do you use futur proche?
answer: Technically it should only be used for something that will happen imminently or a change to the status quo. Those are the only ways that you should use futur proche in writing. If something will occur further into the future in writing then use futur simple instead.; But when speaking it is very common for people to use futur proche for anything in the future because it's easy to formulate. It is especially correct to say something like: Le année prochaine je vais aller... because you made the time frame clear.

question: I am going to go (for a) walk. Use futur proche.
answer: Je vais marcher.

question: They are going to eat. Use futur proche.
answer: Ils vont manger.

question: After we go to the cinema we will drink some wine. Use futur proche.
answer: Aprés on va au cinema on va boire DU vin.; Remember that BOIRE is always followed by DE. de + le = du

question: You are going to eat it (masculine). Use future proche.
answer: Tu va le manger.; Notice how the object pronoun is placed in between the two verbs in future proche.

question: I am going to help you. Use futur proche.
answer: Je vais t'aider.; Notice how the object pronoun is placed in between the two verbs in future proche.; The pronoun te ends in a vowel and the infinitive starts with a vowel so we condense them using apostrophe.

question: How do you construct the simple future tense in French (le futur simple)?
answer: ENTIRE INFINITIVE* + ending that agrees with subject (je –AI + tu -AS + il/elle/on -A + nous -ONS + vous -EZ + ils/elles -ONT); *except for 3rd group and irregular verbs; NB: The endings for the nous form and ils form sound exactly the same and they are NOT silent! (not like -ENT au présent).

question: What are the two non-intuitive things regarding pronunciation in futur simple?
answer: 1) ils/elles -ONT ending in futur simple is pronounced (not silent like -ENT au présent) 2) We often drop a syllable in futur simple. e.g. PRÉSENTER: il présentera ('pray-suhn-TRA'). Drop the penultimate syllable like médicin.

question: What is the futur simple base for -ER verbs (group 1) and -IR verbs (group 2)?
answer: the entire infinitive for both group 1 and group 2 verbs; e.g. parler and choisir; NB: This is the same base used for the conditionnel tense.

question: What is the futur simple base for group 3 verbs ending in -RE (e.g. prendre + dire + croire + descendre)?
answer: the entire infinitive minus the final E; prendre:prendr + dire:dir + croire:croir + descendre:descendr; NB: This is the same base used for the conditionnel tense.

question: What are the futur simple bases for these irregular verbs: être + aller + faire + venir?
answer: être:ser + aller:ir + faire:fer + venir:viendr; NB: These are the same bases used for the conditionnel tense.

question: What are the futur simple bases for these irregular verbs: avoir + savoir + voir?
answer: avoir:aur + savoir:saur (savoir is conjugated the same as avoir but with an S at the beginning) + voir:verr (voir is totally different than avoir and savoir); NB: These are the same bases used for the conditionnel tense.

question: What are the futur simple bases for these irregular verbs: pouvoir + vouloir + devoir + falloir?
answer: pouvoir:pourr + vouloir:voudr + devoir:devr + falloir:faudr; NB: These are the same bases used for the conditionnel tense.

question: When should you use futur simple?
answer: Generally you should use futur simple when there is certainty that something will happen in the future especially if it is not in the immediate future.; Examples of when to use futur simple: an ongoing change + the result/consequence of a change + plans for the future; Never use futur simple directly following SI (if) because that would be something that is uncertain. - e.g. Si on mange trop (use présant because 'if' makes this part of the sentence uncertain)` alors on grossit (use futur simple because this part of the sentence is a certainty).

question: What verb tense will generally follow these setups: Quand ... + Pendent que ... + J'espére que ...?
answer: Assuming you are describing an event in the future then use futur simple in these phrases.

question: When should you use alors vs puis?
answer: Alors is a good transition word when you are revealing a consequence of the earlier sentence (e.g. if i eat too much then i will gain weight).; Puis should only be used to describe sequential steps. e.g. We went to dinner. Then we went to a movie.

question: then (at that time in the future)
answer: cependant; This is not a commonly used word but it is the appropriate word when you want to express that you will do something at a time in the future (cependant) instead of doing something because of a cause (alors) or doing something after something else (puis).

question: When should you use futur simple vs conditional?
answer: If there is anything about the future statement that is uncertain then use conditional. e.g. If she goes (présent) I would go (conditional WOULD).; If the future statment is certain then use futur simple. e.g. If she goes (présent) I will go (futur simple WILL).

question: I will finish. Use futur simple.
answer: Je finirai. (finir is the infinitive + ai to agree with je)

question: I will finish it (masculine). Use futur simple.
answer: Je le finirai.; All pronouns representing objects of the verb are placed before the verb in futur simple.

question: You will go out. Use futur simple.
answer: Tu sortiras. (sortir is the infinitive + as to agree with tu)

question: You (plural/formal) will sing. Use futur simple.
answer: Vous chanterez. (chanter is the infinitive + ez to agree with vous)

question: They will arrive tonight. Use futur simple.
answer: Ils arriveront ce soir.

question: I will take. Use futur simple.
answer: Je prendrai.; For verbs that end in -e (like PRENDRE) we remove the -e from the infinitive before applying the same futur simple endings to agree with the subject.; PRENDR + AI

question: They will put. Use futur simple.
answer: Ils mettront.; Follows the same pattern as PRENDRE.; 'muh-tron' because -ont is still pronounced in this form.

question: We will wait. Use futur simple.
answer: On attendra.; Attendre is the infinitive. It ends in -e so subtract the -e. Then add the -a ending for il/elle/on.; ATTENDR + A

question: I will come tomorrow. Use futur simple.
answer: Je viendrai demain.; This is an example of a verb that is irregular in futur simple. The infinitive for 'to come' is VENIR. But we change it to VIENDR and then add the futur simple endings.

question: You will go. Use futur simple.
answer: Tu iras.; Aller is irregular in futur simple. The infinitive for 'to go' is ALLER. But we change it to IR and then add the futur simple endings.

question: We will go. + They will go. Use futur simple.
answer: On ira (or nous irons). + Ils iront.

question: I will go. He would go.
answer: J'irai (futur simple). Il irait (conditionnel).; Note that the conditional conjugated forms sounds like the first person futur simple form.

question: We will go shopping (errands - not luxury goods).
answer: Nous ferons des courses.; Faire is irregular in futur simple. Instead of 'fair' we use the radical 'fer' and then add the endings.

question: You (formal/plural) will be in Paris.
answer: Vous serez à Paris.; être is irregular in futur simple. We use 'ser' as the radical and then add the endings.

question: She will have a cat.
answer: Elle aura un chat.; Avoir is irregular in futur simple. We use 'aur' as the radical and then add the endings.

question: What will you eat? (use futur simple)
answer: Que mangeras-tu?

question: What will you (informal) do? / What will you (formal) do?
answer: Que feras-tu? / Que ferez-vous?; Faire is irregular in past participle using 'fer' as base.

question: Where will you (formal) go on vacation?
answer: Où irez-vous en vacances?; Aller is irregular in past participle using 'ir' as base.; vacation is always plural in french - vacances

question: I will see you (informal). Use futur simple.
answer: Je te verrai.

question: I will do it.
answer: Je le ferai.

question: If I save money then I will travel to Italy.
answer: Si j'economise d'argent puis j'irai à l'Italie.; The first phrase is in présent indicatif because it is a hypothesis. The second phrase is in futur simple because it is something that will certainly happen if the hypothesis is met.

question: I will work more if I travel less.
answer: Je traveillerai plus si je voyage moins.; The first phrase is futur simple because it happens in the future if the hypothesis (the second phrase in présent indicatif) is met.

question: Is it possible for the futur simple to follow the word SI (if) directly?
answer: It is possible if the SI indicates 'whether or not something will happen' instead of indicating a hypothesis ('if something happens').;e.g. Je ne sais pas SI je partirai. = I do not know IF (yes/no) I will leave (futur simpl directly follows the SI). Si je pars... = IF I leave... (hypothesis so présent directly follows the SI)

question: I will not eat butter any more. (use futur simple)
answer: Je NE mangerai PLUS de beurre.; 'no more' is a quantity so you have to use the basic DE which does not agree with the noun.; This is one way to express that you will stop doing something in the future.

question: I will not eat butter or bread. (use future simple)
answer: Je NE mangerai PAS de beurre NI de pain.; 'none' is a quantity so you have to use the basic DE which does not agree with the noun.; Use NI instead of ET when you are are negating multiple items.; This is another way to express that you will stop doing something in the future.

question: I will never eat butter. (use future simple)
answer: Je NE mangerai JAMAIS de beurre.; 'none ever' is a quantity so you have to use the basic DE which does not agree with the noun.; This is one way to express that you will stop doing something in the future. JAMAIS replaces PAS.

question: I will stop eating butter. (use future simple)
answer: J'arrêterai manger de beurre.; This is another way to express that you will stop doing something in the future.

question: I will stop. (use future simple)
answer: Je m'arrêterai.; When you use arrêter and you do not specify what you are stopping then you must use the reflexive form of the verb (S'ARRÊTER) to explain that you are stopping yourself ...from doing something. You cannot just say: J'arrête.

question: How do you construct the passé composé (a past tense) in French?
answer: AUXILIARY VERB (conjugated form of être or avoir) + simple PAST PARTICIPLE of the main verb; in English it's like 'i have jumped.'; NB: If être is the auxiliary (helper) verb then the past participle must also agree with the subject including gender for ALL forms - not just the third person (e.g. il/elle)

question: When should you use passé composé (instead of imparfait)?
answer: Use it for actions that occurred within a tight/specific time range in the past (not an ambiguous range) and that are no longer happening in the present + actions that conclude a story + actions listed chronologically + an action that interupts the setting/background (e.g. the phone rang); For example these words typically trigger passé composé: d'abord + ensuite/puis + enfin + aprés de + il y a.

question: Generally how do you make the past participle of a verb?
answer: 1) -ER verbs: radical + é ...which sounds exactly the same as the 2nd person plural (vous) in present that ends with -ez; 2) -IR verbs: radical + i; 3) -RE verbs: radical + -is OR radical + u; 4) -OIR verbs: radical + u

question: I ate. We drank.
answer: J'ai mangé. On a bu.; boire is the infinitive for 'to drink' - bu is the past participle and it uses AVOIR in passé composé.

question: You (informal and formal) bought.
answer: Tu as acheté. Vous avez acheté.

question: They studied.
answer: Ils ont étudié.; étudier is the infinitive and it follows the same rules because the radical is 'étudi' - not 'étud'.

question: They did not study. I did not study.
answer: Ils n'ont étudié. Je n'ai pas étudié.; You do not need to add DE after PAS when what follows is a verb. This is different from nouns. e.g. Je n'ai pas DE pommes.; In passé composé PAS is placed between the auxiliary and the past participle. It is the only word that comes between those two parts of the verb.

question: All in passé composé: I read. / I read it. / I did not read it.
answer: J'ai lu. / Je l'ai lu. / Je ne l'ai pas lu.; Lire changes to Lu for past participle.

question: I learn. / I learned.
answer: J'apprends. ('juh-prawn') / J'ai appris. ('jay ah-pree')

question: What is the past participle for to take + to learn + to understand?
answer: prendre: pris + apprendre: appris + comprendre: compris; Every S is silent at the end.

question: at school / in school
answer: à l'école

question: We saw something.
answer: On a vu quelque chose.; Voir is the infinitive. It uses avoir in passé composé and the participle is vu.; NB: The general rule for making a past participle for a verb ending in -OIR is to replace -OIR with -U.

question: They wanted something. (use passé composé)
answer: Ils/Elles ont voulu quelque chose.;Voulour is the infinitive. It uses avoir in passé composé and the participle is voulu.; NB: The general rule for making a past participle for a verb ending in -OIR is to replace -OIR with -U.

question: They were wanting me to... (use imparfait which is the likely idiomatic way to say this in french - unless you are stating the conclusion of a story)
answer: Ils voulaient que je...; Voulour is the infinitive

question: You were able (to pay).
answer: Tu a pu (payer).; Pouvoir is the infinitive (to be able to). Pouvoir uses avoir in passé composé and the participle for all subjects is pu.; NB: pouVOIR is the infinitive so it should be conjugated exactly the same as VOIR (to see).

question: Which 5 verbs have a completely irregular past particle?
answer: avoir (eu) + être (été) + faire (fait) + offrir (offert) + ouvrir (ouvert); NB: All of these use AVOIR as the auxiliary in passé composé and plus que parfait.

question: He had. / He was. / He did (something).
answer: Il a eu. / Il a été. / Il a fait.; All the 5 verbs with an irregular past participle use AVOIR as the auxiliary verb in passé composé.

question: How do you say 'There is...' (il y a...) in the past (there were...) and future (there will be...)?
answer: For past you must use imparfait because it describes the scene (instead of an action): Il y avait... (not Il y a eu...).; For the future use futur simple: Il y aura...

question: He spoke rapidly.
answer: Il a RAPIDEMENT parlé.; In passé composé: Adverbs (like rapidement) are placed between the auxiliary and the past participle.

question: She often wore makeup.
answer: Elle s'est SOUVENT maquilée.; In passé composé: Adverbs (like souvent) are placed between the auxiliary and the past participle.

question: I grew a lot as a person (during some formative time of life)
answer: J'ai BEAUCOUP grandi en tant que personne.; In passé composé: Adverbs (like beacoup) are placed between the auxiliary and past participle.

question: How do you negate a phrase in passé composé?
answer: NE comes directly after the subject. PAS is placed between the auxiliary and the past participle.; e.g. We did not do X. = Nous n'avons pas fait X.; Nothing else (except adverbs) are ever placed between the auxiliary and the past participle.

question: He did not read. + They did not run.
answer: Il N'a PAS lu. + Ils N'ont PAS couru.; In passé compose: NE is placed directly after the subject (before any pronouns). PAS is placed between the auxiliary and past participle.

question: I did not travel a lot.
answer: Je N'ai PAS BEAUCOUP voyagé.; In passé composé: Adverbs (like beacoup) are placed between the auxiliary and past participle - with PAS.

question: I have not yet finished.
answer: Je n'ai pas ENCORE fini.; Encore can mean 'yet' or 'even'.; Adverbs (like encore) are placed between the auxiliary and the past participle - with PAS.

question: What the three characteristics that lead to a verb using être in passé composé?
answer: 1) a verb that describes movement of an animate object (e.g. la maison de être = verbs that describe a person's movement in/around a home) 2) a verb that describes a change of state (e.g. naître + mourir + devenir = to become something) 3) Any verbs that is being used in a reflexive way (e.g. SE PROMENER); NB: An acronym to remember the 15 base verbs is MRS VANDERTRAMPP.; Remember that when être is the auxiliary verb then the past participle must agree with the subject in gender and number.

question: What are the 15 verbs that use être in passé composé (a past tense)?
answer: Monter Retourner Sortir Venir (e.g. includes devenir + revenir + etc.) Arriver Naître Descendre Entrer Rentrer Tomber Rester Aller Mourir Partir Passer; Remember that when être is the auxiliary verb then the past participle must agree with the subject in gender and number.

question: Conjugate 'to arrive' in passé composé.
answer: ARRIVER is the infinitive; Je suis arrivé(e) (m/f) + Tu es arrivé(e) (m/f) + Il/Elle/On est arrivé(e) (m/f) + Nous sommes arrivés + Vous êtes arrivés + Ils/Elles sont arrivé(e)s; explanation: arriver uses être in passé composé. So we conjugate être for the auxiliary. Then the past participle must agree with the subject.

question: I go out. + I went out.
answer: Je sors. + Je suis sorti(e).; SORTIR is not a regular -IR verb in the present tense.; SORTIR uses être in passé composé so the past participle must agree with the subject.; Think of: la sortie = the exit. SORTIR = to go out.

question: I leave. + I left (a place).
answer: Je pars. + Je suis parti(e).; PARTIR is not a regular -IR verb. Nous partONS. - not Nous partissons.; PARTIR uses être in passé composé so the past participle must agree with the subject.; Think of partir as 'parting' from something.

question: You come from X. / You came (from X).
answer: Tu viens de X. / Tu es venu(e) de X.; Add the E if the person that is tu is feminine.; Venir (to come) uses être in passé composé which means that the participle must agree with the subject.

question: They (all feminine) went online to learn.
answer: Elle sont allées en ligne.; ALLER is the same verb we use in English: 'to go' online;  Aller uses être in passé composé and so it must agree with the subject (Ils sont allés. vs Elles sont allées.)

question: What are the only two verbs that use être in passé composé AND are irregular in passé composé?
answer: naître (to be born) and mourir (to die) - e.g. Je suis né(e) + Il/Elle est mort(e).; NB: Any verb can be made into a reflexive verb. So if a verb (that normally uses avoir in passé composé) is used reflexively in passé composé then it might be an additional case of an irregular être verb in passé composé.

question: They (all men / all women) died.
answer: Ils sont morts. / Elles sont mortes.;Mourir (to die) uses être in passé composé which means that the participle must agree with the subject.

question: She/he was born on XX/XX/XXX. He was born.
answer: Elle/il est né(e) le XX/XX/XXXX.; Naître (to be born) uses être in passé composé so the past participle must agree with the subject.; Place LE before any date because all dates are masculine nouns.

question: You (formal and informal) were born in XXXX
answer: Vous êtes / Tu es né(e) à/en/au/aux XXXX.; à for a city; en/au/aux for a country following aller + rester + partir.

question: What are 2 alternative ways to say I was born in Paris (without using the verb naître)?
answer: Je suis natif de Paris. + Je suis parisienne de naissance.

question: the city where I was born
answer: la ville OÙ je suis né(e); Use the relative pronoun OÙ to represent a time or place (where or when). This is different than when you start a phrase with 'when'. e.g. when i was 10 years old = QUAND j'avais 10 ans

question: My cousin had a son.
answer: Use AVOIR in passé composé: Mon cousin a eu un fils.

question: How do you construct passé composé for reflexive verbs?
answer: All reflexive verbs use être as a helper verb (regardless of whether or not they use être in the non-reflexive form). SUBJECT + PRONOUN (me/te/...) + ÊTRE CONJUGATED + PAST PARTICIPLE OF THE VERB; NB: We are using être as the auxiliary verb in these reflexive cases so the past participle must agree with the subject.

question: Yesterday I got up at 8am.
answer: Hier je me suis levé(e) à 8h.

question: You (masc / fem) went to sleep late last night.
answer: Tu t'es couché / couchée tard hier soir (or la nuit dernière).; Se coucher is reflexive so we use être as auxiliary and then the past participle agrees with the subject.

question: I help you.
answer: Je t'aide.; pronouns that are direct objects come BEFORE the verb in French

question: I helped you.
answer: Je t'ai aidé.; In the past tense the direct object pronoun comes BEFORE BOTH the helper verb and the action verb.

question: He helped us. / I helped them.
answer: Il nous a aidé. / Je les ai aidé.

question: Can you (formal) help me? + Would you help me?
answer: Pouvez-vous m'aider? (présent) + Pourriez-vous m'aider? (conditionnel); The latter is more polite because it uses the conditionnel tense.

question: Can you (informal) hear me?
answer: Peux tu m'entendre?

question: Can I ...? + May I ...?
answer: Pourrais-je ('poo-rayj')...? Use POUVOIR in the conditionnel tense to be polite in formal and informal settings.; Rarely used alternative: Puis-je ('poo-eej') ...? This is the present tense (je peux) inverted. We cannot say peux-je because of vowels so we revert to an ancient form of the word (je puis). This is not common. It sounds weird in everyday settings. Do not use it.

question: May I help you?
answer: Pourrais-je vous aider? Use POUVOIR in the conditionnel tense to be polite in formal and informal settings.; Alternative you may hear: Comment puis-je ('poo-eej') vous aider? = How can I help you? using inversion of the ancient form je puis. A vendor in a store may use this to be overly polite but it sounds weird in everyday conversation.

question: He gives to me. + He gave to me. + He will give to me.
answer: Il me donne. + Il m'a donné. + Il va me donner.; In future proche (conjugated ALLER + infinitive) pronouns that are objects of the verb - direct and indirect - are placed in between the conjugated ALLER and the infinitive.

question: You told me multiple times.
answer: Tu me l'as dit plusieurs fois.; Tu (You) me (to me) le (it) as (auxiliary AVOIR because NOT reflexive and uses 'to tell' uses avoir) dit (past participle of dire); NB: In French you cannot just say 'You told me.' You must refer to what it is that was told (You told IT to me.) ...even if you use a pronoun and even if you already described it in a previous sentence.; Both the direct and indirect object pronouns come before the verb.

question: I remembered it. (past tense).
answer: Look at the infinitive (se souvenir). It is a variation of the verb VENIR. So it has the same ending in past participle: souvenu. Je m'en suis souvenu.; Remember in this case we use 'en' instead of 'le' to represent 'it'.

question: I thought...
answer: Je pensais... (NOT j'ai pensé...); We almost always use the imparfait to describe something we were thinking in the past because (implicitly) we no longer think the same now.

question: What is 'imparfait' tense? (the imperfect tense within the indicative group)
answer: It is used when talking about something that happened in the past with a continuing/ambigous time frame (e.g. when telling a story/memory about something that happened in the past - that is no longer happening - e.g. in your childhood) or describing how someone or something was in the past (but the situation or person has changed since then).; Example: I bought something at the store (past) / I was buying something at the store. (imperfect tense within the indicative group); Example: I walked on the beach. (past) / I used to walk on the beach. (the 'imparfait' tense); Use the imparfait when describing the following in the past: a situation + scene + state of being + habit + feelings + thoughts

question: How do you construct the 'imparfait' tense?
answer: For -ER and -IR verbs: RADICAL of the infinitive in the NOUS form + imparfait endings (je -ais + tu -ais + il -ait + nous -ions + vous -iez + ils -aient); There is no auxiliary/helper verb (as in passé composé).; NB: For all -ER verbs 'imparfait' sounds exactly the same as the infinitive for ALL subjects except nous and vous.; NB: The endings (not the base) for the imparfait and conditionnel tenses are exactly the same!

question: What are the two english phrases that - when translated - almost always use 'imparfait' tense?
answer: I was (doing something) + I used to (do something) ...for any subject; Note how these indicate something in the past that was or used to be but is no longer.

question: How do you determine whether to conjugate in passé composé vs imparfait?
answer: Use passé composé for any phrase that advances a story - an action (or reaction) that tells you the things that happened that advance the story. The items in passé composé (taken alone) should make a chronology.; Use imparfait for any phrase that enriches the context or provides detail. If the phrase doesn't fit into the chronology of the story then it probably should be conjugated in imparfati.

question: Conjugate marcher (to walk) in the 'imparfait' tense (I was walking + You were walking + etc).
answer: First determine présent nous form: nous MARCHons. Then subtract the ending so radical = MARCH; Now add the endings to the radical: Je marchais + Tu marchais + Il/Elle/On marchait + Nous marchions + Vous marchiez + Ils/Elles marchaient; NB: Marcher is a regular -ER verb so all the imparfait forms (except nous and vous) sound exactly the same as the infinitive - though they are spelled differently.

question: I ate. / I was eating.
answer: J'ai mangé. / Je mangeais.; Both are pronounced exactly the same as the infinitive.; Manger is a regular -ER verb all the 'imparfait' conjugations (except nous and vous) sound exactly the same as the infinitive - though they are spelled differently.

question: You (informal) ate. / You (informal) were eating.
answer: Tu a mangé. / Tu mangeais.; Both are pronounced exactly the same as the infinitive.; Manger is a regular -ER verb all 'imparfait' conjugations (except nous and vous) sound exactly the same as the infinitive - though they are spelled differently.

question: You (formal) ate. / You (formal) ate.
answer: Vous avez mangé. ('mon-jay') / Vous mangiez. ('mon-jee-ay'); Only passé composé is pronounced the same as the infinitive because the subject is vous.; Manger is a regular -ER verb all 'imparfait' conjugations (except nous and vous) sound exactly the same as the infinitive - though they are spelled differently.

question: She was waiting for me. + She was waiting for me to finish.
answer: Elle m'attendait. (no preposition between the verb 'to wait' and the person/thing you are waiting for) + Elle attendais que je finisse. (Use subjonctif in this case.)

question: Conjugate être (to be) in the 'imparfait' tense (I was + You were + He was + We were + You guys were + They were)
answer: J'étais ('jeh-tay') + Tu étais ('tu-eh-tay' OR 'teh-tay' but always spelled as two words) + Il/Elle était ('eh-tay') + Nous étions ('eh-teeon')+ Vous étiez ('eh-teeay')+ Ils/Elles étaient ('eh-tay')

question: I was happy.
answer: J'étais heureux/heureuse.; You automatically use the imparfait (instead of passé composé) because you are describing a state of being in the past.

question: Conjugate avoir (to have) in the imparfait tense (I was having + You were having + He was having + We were having + You guys were having + They were having)
answer: j'avais + tu avais + il avait + nous avions + vous aviez + ils avaient

question: Conjugate savoir (to know) in the imparfait.
answer: the same as AVOIR - just add an S in front of them all

question: Conjugate voir (to see) in the imparfait.
answer: Different than AVOIR. je voyais + tu voyais + il voyait + nous voyions + vous voyiez + ils voyaient

question: to recognize/acknowledge
answer: reconnaître; It is CONNAÎTRE (to be familiar with) with the prefix RE-.

question: to get to know (someone)
answer: apprendre à connaître (quelqu'un); e.g. J'ai appris à le connaitre. = I got to know him. le = him because it is a direct object in this case.

question: Before... I went out every night.
answer: Avant... je sortais tous les soirs.; 'i went' is the flag to use the 'imparfait'. But also when 'avant' is used in this way then you can expect 'imparfait' to follow it.

question: every two weeks
answer: toutes les deux semaines; Use toutes because semaines is plural and feminine.

question: In the mornings I ate eggs. + Frequently I ate eggs.
answer: Le matin je mangeais des œufs. +  Souvent je mangeais des œufs.; Both of these phrases suggested something that was habitually done in the past (not just once). Therefore we use imparfait in both cases.

question: I used to play tetris.
answer: Je jouais ('zshoo-ay') au tetris.; Use imparfait because in this case 'used to' means an activity in the past that was done repeatedly that is no longer happening - not to become accustomed to something.

question: I used to make coffee.
answer: Je faisais ('fez-ay') du café.; Use imparfait because in this case 'used to' means an activity in the past that was done repeatedly that is no longer happening - not to become accustomed to something.

question: I am used to sleeping a long time.
answer: Je suis habitué(e) À dormir longtemps. OR J'ai l'habitude DE dormir longtemps.; Être habitué(e) requires preposition À. Avoir l'habitude requires preposition DE.; In this case 'used to' means to be accustomed to something - not an activity in the past that was done repeatedly that is no longer happening.

question: I am used to swimming.
answer: Je suis habitué(e) À nager. OR J'ai l'habitude DE nager.; Être habitué(e) requires preposition À. Avoir l'habitude requires preposition DE.; In this case 'used to' means to be accustomed to something - not an activity in the past that was done repeatedly that is no longer happening.

question: Which verbs almost always use the imparfait tense (instead of passé composé) when used in the past tense? Why?
answer: penser + savoir + connaitre + vouloir + pouvoir + devoir; When you use these verbs in the past you almost mean that you thought/knew/wanted/etc something but that you no longer think/knew/want it now - the scenario has changed. That is why we almost always use imparfait for these verbs in the past tense. But be careful. Choosing imparfait vs passé composé depends on how the phrase is being used.

question: My mother wanted to see the horse.
answer: Ma mère voulait voir le cheval.; The infinitive is VOULOIR (to want). Conjugate vouloir in the imparfait because you are implying that she wanted something in the past but may not want the same thing in the present. For this reason... VOULOIR is almost always conjugated in imparfait (instead of passé composé) in the past.

question: It was 3:00pm. I saw an elephant.
answer: Il était 15 heures. J'ai vu un éléphant.; The first sentence describes the setting so use imparfait. The second sentence describes a discrete action so use passé composé.

question: What is the conditionnel tense?
answer: This exists in English (the conditional). It is a future tense that is hypothetical.; e.g. I might / would / could / should (do something). There is uncertainty (an implied IF).; You would do something IF something else were true. NB: the accompanying IF statement may be implied. The word IF should not be used in the same phrase as you use the conditionnel because that would duplicate the hypothetical.; I would do it = Je le ferrais (the verb faire conjugated in the conditionnel); Uses of the conditionnel: 1) to be polite (e.g. je voudrais) 2) to express a wish 3) to give advice (tu devrais) 4) to give information that is not confirmed.

question: How is the conditionnel tense constructed?
answer: Use the same base as the futur simple (the entire infinitive or modified infinitive). Then add the imparfait endings to agree with subject: je -ais + tu -ais + il/elle/on -ait + nous -ions + vous -iez + ils/elles -aient; NB: Futur conditional for almost all the types of subjects (je/tu/il/ils) sounds exactly the same as the first person singular (je) form for futur simple (though spelled differently).; But the nous and vous forms - as expected - are pronounced uniquely.

question: I would like some milk.
answer: Je voudrais DU lait.; Vouloir (to want) is conjugated in the conditionnel tense for politeness.

question: I would like to find...
answer: Je voudrais trouver...; Vouloir (to want) is conjugated in the conditionnel tense for politeness.

question: How do you express: I could / may / might (do something).
answer: Use POUVOIR and the conditionnel tense.; Je POURRais faire quelque chose.; Pouvoir - to be able to - is conjugated in the conditional. The subsequent verb is in the infinitive.

question: How do you express: I should (do something).
answer: Use DEVOIR and the conditionnel tense.; Je DEVRais (use futur simple base: devr) faire quelque chose.; Devoir - to must - is conjugated in the conditional. The subsequent verb is in the infinitive.

question: How do you express: I must (do something).
answer: Use DEVOIR and the présent tense.; Je dois faire quelque chose.

question: How do you express: I had (to do something).
answer: Use DEVOIR in the imparfait (past) because telling a story.; Je DEVais (use imparfait base: dev) faire quelque chose.; Devoir - to must - is conjugated in the imparfait. The subsequent verb is in the infinitive.; If you really needed to use passé composé (e.g. if you were stating a conclusion to past activity) then it would be: J'ai du (past participle of devoir) faire quelque chose.

question: How do you express: I didn't need (something).
answer: Use AVOIR BESOIN in the imparfait (past) because telling a story.; Je n'avais pas besoin quelque chose.; There is no second infinitive verb when you use avoir besoin.

question: How do you express: I want you (to do something). + I wanted you (to do something).
answer: This triggers subjonctif because it expresses a desire that may or may not reflect reality: Je veux QUE tu fasses quelque chose. + Je voulais QUE tu fasses quelque chose.

question: If I had more time I would dance every day.
answer: Si j'avais (imparfait) plus de temps je dancerais (conditionnel) tous les jours.; REMEMBER that you cannot use the conditionnel tense in the same phrase as SI (if). Si (if) is implicit when you use the conditionnel tense.

question: I will be able to. (futur simple) / I could. (futur conditionnel)
answer: Je pourrai. / Je pourrais.; Pronounced exactly the same ('pour-ray') because je/tu/il/elle/on/ils/elles in future conditional sound exactly the same as je in futur simple - though spelled differently.; Remember 'ai' sounds like 'ay' in french - like j'ai.

question: I will eat. (futur simple) / They would eat. (future conditionnel)
answer: Je mangerai. / Ils mangeraient.; Pronounced exactly the same ('man-jer-ray') because je/tu/il/elle/on/ils/elles in future conditional sound exactly the same as je in futur simple - though spelled differently.; -ent is always silent on verbs

question: I will have more time. (futur simple) / I will know how to do it. (futur simple)
answer: J'aurai plus DE temps. / Je saurai comment faire.; NB: AVOIR and SAVOIR are usually conjugated in the same way - just add an S to the front for the SAVOIR version.

question: Elle has been working longer than me.
answer: Elle travaille depuis plus longtemps que moi.

question: I do not have time. + We didn't have enough time.
answer: Je n'ai pas LE temps. + On n'a pas eu assez DE temps.; The first structure is an exception. Memorize to use LE temps (instead of DE temps) in this structure. The second sentence is not an exception and uses the more expected DE temps.

question: There wasn't enough time.
answer: Je n'avais pas assez de temps.

question: It took to long.
answer: Ça pris trop DE temps.

question: I quit. / I will quit. / I would quit.
answer: J'ai quitté. / Je quitterai. / Je quitterais.; QUITTER is the infinitive. It also means 'to leave'.

question: Using the verb ÉCOUTER... You would listen. / He would listen.(both future conditionnel)
answer: Tu écouterais. / Il écouterait.; ('ay-coo-tuh-ray') Both sound exactly the same as Je version in futur simple (j'écouterai) - though they are spelled differently.

question: Using the verb CHANTER... They would sing. / You (formal/plural) would sing. (both future conditionnel)
answer: Ils chanteraient. ('shon-tu-ray') / Vous chanteriez. ('shon-tu-ree-ay'); The ils version sounds exactly the same as the je version in futur simple (je chanterai) BUT the vous version sounds different because nous and vous versions do not follow the rule that je/tu/il/elle/on/ils/elles follow.

question: Using the verb VOIR... She would watch. / We (nous) would watch. (both future conditionnel)
answer: Elle verrait. / Nous verrions.; VOIR is irregular in futur simple - we use the radical 'verr'.; Notice that the pronunciation rule still holds: Elle verrait (She would watch) sounds the same as Je verrai (I will watch). BUT Nous verrions (We would watch) does not sound the same as Je verrai (I will watch) because nous and vous never follow the pronunciation rule.

question: You (familiar) would go. / You (formal/plural) would go. (both futur conditionnel)
answer: Tu irais. / Vous iriez.; ALLER is irregular in futur simple - we use the radical 'ir'.; The pronunciation similarities still hold. Tu irais (You would go) sounds the same as J'irai (I will go). Vous form sounds different - always does.

question: What is the conditionnel passé (past conditional) tense?
answer: It is the same as the conditionnel tense (a hypothetical action that depends on something else being true - explicitly or implicitly). But conditionnel passé is in the past instead of in the future.; e.g. conditionnel: might do / would do / could do / should do. condionnel passé: might have done / would have done / could have done / should have done; For example: I would have returned the book (IF I had had time). The first phrase is conditionnel passé. The second phrase could be said or omitted.

question: How do you express that something is in the conditionnel tense?
answer: au conditionnel

question: How do you construct the conditionnel passé (past conditional) tense?
answer: AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel tense + past participle; e.g. I would have done something. = J'AURAIS FAIT quelque chose.; The past participle is the same as passé composé. The pairing with avoir/être is the same as passé composé.

question: I would have written a letter.
answer: J'aurais écrit une lettre.; This is hypothetical in the past so use conditionnel passé.

question: They would have gone to the movies.
answer: Ils seraient allés au cinéma.; This is hypothetical in the past so use conditionnel passé.

question: How do you express: I could have done X. + I should have done X.
answer: J'aurais PU + INFINITIVE. + J'aurais DÛ + INFINITIVE. e.g. J'aurais pu faire quelque chose. + J'aurais dû fiare quelque chose.; These are very useful phrases that utilize conditionnel passé. Memorize them.

question: She could have gone to the movies.
answer: Elle aurait pu (conditionnel passé) aller (infinitive) au cinéma.; This is special variation of conditionnel passé (could have): AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel tense (aurait) + PAST PARTICIPLE (pu from pouvoir) + INFINITIVE

question: We should have sang a song.
answer: On aurait dû (conditionnel passé) chanter (infinitive) une chanson.; This is special variation of conditionnel passé (should have): AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel tense (aurait) + PAST PARTICIPLE (dû from devoir) + INFINITIVE

question: It could be worse. + It could have been worse.
answer: Ça pourrait être pire. (conditionnel) + Ça aurait pu être pire. (conditionnel passé)

question: polite + politely
answer: poli(e) + poliment; Transform an adjective that ends in a vowel by adding -MENT. This ensures a vowel is present before -MENT ending.

question: for politeness / in order to be polite
answer: par politesse

question: impolite; Specify pronunciation.
answer: impoli(e); The first syllable is pronounced like ingénieur because there is only one M: 'uhm-poh-lee'.

question: You come with us? (formal and informal)
answer: Vous venez / Tu viens AVEC nous?

question: How do you ask politely: Should I (do something)?
answer: Devrais-je... (insert any infinitive verb)?; should = DEVOIR in conditional tense; Alternative: Dois-je ('dwaj')...? = Must I ...?

question: How do you ask politely: Do you have eggs (formal and informal)?
answer: Auriez-vous / Aurais-tu des œufs?; Verb is AVOIR. Use conditionnel to be polite.

question: How do you ask politely: May I / Can I... (do something)?
answer: Pourrais-je...? Use POUVOIR in the conditionnel tense to ask if you may do something. This is the best way to ask the question in formal and informal situations.; Rarely used ultra-formal alternative: Puis-je ('pweej')...? Je puis is a formal alternative to Je peux. It is literally just a different way to express 'I can'. But if you use inversion to ask a question then peux-je is impossible/forbidden. So one would have to use puis-je. But this is a very rare phrasing. Do not use this as a foreigner.

question: How do you ask politely: May I keep this? (e.g. a menu)
answer: Pourrais-je garder ça?; Use POUVOIR in the conditionnel tense to ask if you may do something.

question: How do you ask politely: Could you please open the door?
answer: Pourriez-vous / Pourrais-tu ouvrir la porte?; Verb is POUVOIR. Use conditionnel to be polite.

question: How do you ask politely: Would you like some water?
answer: Voudriez-vous / Voudrais-tu de l'eau?; Verb is VOULOIR. Use conditionnel to be polite.

question: What is the plus que parfait (pluperfect) tense?
answer: Use this tense to describe an event in the past that 'had taken' place and 'had been' completed BEFORE some other past event. Often the word AVANT is in the phrase.; Do not use this for something that happened independently or in the recent past (when you would use passè composé or imparfait instead).; In English we call this the 'past perfect' tense (e.g. I had been doing something).; In English we often use a simple past tense (e.g. passé composé or imparfait) for both events in the past. But in french you MUST use plus que parfait whenever you are describing an event that occurred before some other event in the past.

question: How do you construct the plus que parfait tense?
answer: Same as passé composé but AVOIR and ÊTRE auxiliaries are conjugated au imparfait instead au présent. Use the same past participle as passé composé.; e.g. I had been eating BEFORE you saw me. = J'avais mangé (plus que parfait) AVANT tu me voyais (imparfait).

question: She returned to Portugal because her visa expired.
answer: Elle est rentrée (passé composé) au Portugal parce que son visa avait expiré (plus que parfait).; Use plus que parfait for a past event that occurred before some other past event.; Literally: Her visa had expired.

question: I read the book because I heard it was good.
answer: J'ai lu le livre parce que j'avais entendu que c'était bon.; The second phrase (j'avais entendu) is conjugated in the plus que parfait (literally: I had heard...) because it is a past event that occurs before some other past event.

question: If I had found ten euros (then) I would have bought a coffee.
answer: Si j’aVais trouvé (plus que parfait) dix euros... j'auRais acheté (conditionnel passé) un café.; If a conditional phrase (if..) is in the past (e.g. If we had arrived earlier...) - instead of in the present tense (e.g. If we arrive early...) - then that phrase should use the plus que parfait tense. And that means that the resultant/hypothetical phrase (what would have happened if the if-statement was true) should use the conditionnel passé tense (would have/could have/should have).

question: If they had found ten euros (then) they would have bought a coffee.
answer: S'ils aVaient trouvé (plus que parfait) dix euros... ils auRaient acheté (conditionnel passé) un café.; Si contracts with any word that starts with a vowel.; NB: Never use IF in the same phrase as the conditionnel tense. That would be duplication because the conditional tense assumes a hypothetical.

question: We would have finished early if we had worked together.
answer: On auRait fini (conditionnel passé) si on aVait travaillé (plus que parfait) ensemble.; If a conditional phrase is in the past (if we had worked together) then that phrase should use the plus que parfait tense. That means that the resultant/hypothetical phrase (we would have finished earlier) should use the conditionnel passé tense (would have/could have/should have).

question: What is the subjonctif (subjunctive) verb tense?
answer: It is used to express something that does not necessarily reflect reality (i.e. that is subjective). e.g. I wish that you do not smoke. - 'I wish' triggers the subjonctif tense to be used in the phrase 'you do not smoke'.; There are a lot of scenarios that trigger the subjonctif. The more uncertainty that exists the more likely that the subjonctif is required - so it is not always black and white.; Three major categories (not exhaustive) that trigger the subjonctif include: 1) preferences / advice / needs / desires / orders 2) judgements / emotions / feelings / fears 3) possibilities / opinions / doubts / suppositions.; Falloir (e.g. Il faut...) is a common trigger of the subjonctif.

question: How do you construct the subjonctif tense?
answer: For the nous/vous forms: It is exactly the same as the imparfait. (e.g. venions + veniez); For je/tu/il/ils forms: 1) Use the radical from the ILS form of the présent indicatif (e.g. venir -&gt ils viennent -&gt vienn). 2) Use the following endings: je: -e + tu: -es + il/elle/on: -e + ils/elles: -ent; So for most verbs the subjonctif forms sound like the ils/elles forms in présent indicative.

question: What are the requirements of using the subjonctif tense?
answer: Three requirements: 1) A subjonctive phrase is dependent on another phrase triggering the subjonctive tense. e.g. I wish that you have a good life. 'I wish' is présent indicatif but the verb 'to wish' triggers the subjonctive in the subsequent dependent phrase: that you have a good life.; 2) A subjonctive phrase always starts with the word 'que' or 'qui'. e.g. Je souhaite... QUE vous ayez (avoir in subjonctive) une belle vie.; 3) The independent phrase (that triggers the subsequent subjonctif) must have a subject that is different from the subject in the subjonctif phrase. e.g. I wish that I have a good life. You can't use the subjonctif in this case because the subject of both phrases is the same.

question: How do you differentiate between verbs that trigger the subjonctif vs those that do not?
answer: The level of certainty (or proximity to reality) determines whether or not to use the subjonctif. Statements expressing a high level of certainty (e.g. I am sure that...) do NOT trigger the subjonctif. Simple opinions and observations do NOT trigger subjonctif because the statements are fairly certain - what a person thinks is actually what they think. The following do NOT trigger the subjonctif: Je pense que... + Je crois que... + Je trouve que... + J'espère que... + J'ai l'impression que... ; However when you negate these statements then they indicate uncertainty/doubts. So then they DO trigger subjonctif: Je NE pense PAS que... + Je NE crois PAS que... + Je NE trouve PAS que... + Je N'espère PAS que... + J'ai doute que...; The presence of emotions makes the dependant phrase more uncertain/subjective (potentially further from reality). So the following trigger the subjonctif: J'ai peur que... + Je suis outré(e) que...

question: Which of these trigger the subjonctif: J'aimerais que... vs J'espère que...
answer: J'aimerais que... (I would like that...) triggers the subjonctif because it is a wish and the dependent phrase probably differs a lot from the current reality. J'espère que... (I hope that...) is somewhat of an exception. It does not trigger the subjonctif unless it is negated.

question: Which of these trigger the subjonctif: C'est probable que... vs C'est peu probable que...
answer: C'est probable que... does NOT trigger subjonctif because there is a lot of certainty in the phrase that follows - it is probable.; C'est peu probable que... does trigger the subjonctif because there is a fair amount of uncertainty (not probable) in the statement that follows.

question: Conjugate parler (regular au présent) in the subjonctif tense.
answer: que je parle + que tu parles + qu'il/elle/on parle + que nous parlions + que vous parliez + qu'ils/elles parlent (-ent is silent for all verbs); PARLER is regular au présent indicative AND au subjonctif.

question: Conjugate finir (regular au présent) in the subjonctif tense.
answer: que je finisse + que tu finisses + qu'il/elle/on finisse + que nous finissions + que vous finissiez + qu'ils/elles finissent (-ent is silent for all verbs); FINIR is regular au présent indicative AND au subjonctif.

question: Conjugate venir (irregular au présent) in the subjonctif tense.
answer: que je vienne + que tu viennes + qu'il/elle/on vienne + que nous venions + que vous veniez + qu'ils/elles viennent (-ent is silent for all verbs); VENIR is irregular au présent indicative but it is completely regular au subjonctif.

question: Conjugate prendre (irregular au présent) in the subjonctif tense.
answer: que je prenne + que tu prennes + qu'il/elle/on prenne + que nous prenions + que vous preniez + qu'ils/elles prennent (-ent is silent for all verbs); PRENDRE is irregular au présent indicative but it is completely regular au subjonctif.

question: Conjugate être in the subjonctif tense. It is completely irregular in subjonctif.
answer: Pronounced 'SWA': que je sois ('swa') + que tu sois + qu'il/elle/on soit + que nous soyons + que vous soyez + qu'ils/elles soient (-ent is silent for all verbs)

question: Conjugate avoir in the subjonctif tense. It is completely irregular in subjonctif.
answer: nous/vous forms are the only times we hear the 'Y'. Otherwise just pronounce the hard A ('ay'): que j'aie + que tu aies + qu'il/elle/on ait + que nous ayons (add Y sound) + que vous ayez (add Y sound) + qu'ils/elles aient (-ent is silent for all verbs)

question: Conjugate aller in the subjonctif tense. It is completely irregular in subjonctif.
answer: nous/vous forms are the only times we hear the 'L'. Otherwise just pronounce the hard I ('eye'): que j'aille + que tu ailles + qu'il/elle/on aille + que nous allions (add L sound) + que vous alliez (add L sound) + qu'ils/elles aillent (-ent is silent for all verbs)

question: Conjugate faire in the subjonctif tense. It is completely irregular in subjonctif.
answer: que je fasse + que tu fasses + qu'il/elle/on fasse + que nous fassions + que vous fassiez + qu'ils/elles fassent (-ent is silent for all verbs)

question: Conjugate pouvoir in the subjonctif tense. It is completely irregular in subjonctif.
answer: que je puisse + que tu puisses + qu'il/elle/on puisse + que nous puissions + que vous puissiez + qu'ils/elles puissent (-ent is silent for all verbs)

question: It is possible that you will never return.
answer: C'est possible que tu ne reviennes jamais.; C'est possible que triggers the subjonctif because there is enough uncertainty in the dependent phrase. But if you had said 'It is probable that...' then there is too much certainty to use the subjonctif.; REVENIR is the infinitive.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.

question: I am convinced that...
answer: Je suis convaincue que...; This does not trigger the subjonctif because it indicates a high level of certainty in whatever phrase follows.

question: I prefer (présent indicatif) that you go to the park (subjonctif).
answer: Je préfère que tu ailles (subjonctif) au parc.; NB: préférer has a slight variation (change accent aigu to accent grave) au présent in all but the nous and vous forms.; The expression of a preference (I prefer) triggers the subjonctif in the phrase (that you go to the park).; ALLER is irregular in subjonctif.

question: I would prefer (conditionnel) that you go to the park (subjonctif).
answer: Je préférerais que tu ailles (subjonctif) au parc.; NB: The change of accent in conjugation of préférer is only applicable au présent so no change to the accent in this case (conditionnel).; Statements in both the présent and conditionnel forms can trigger the subjonctif in the second phrase.; ALLER is irregular in subjonctif.

question: My preference is X.
answer: Ma préférence est X.

question: She wants the meal to be ready by 8 o'clock.
answer: Elle veut que la repa soit (ÊTRE au subjonctif) prêt pour huit heures.; VOULOIR triggers the subjonctive. And we can use the subjonctive because the subjects of the two phrases (she and the meal) are different.

question: She wants to please everyone.
answer: Elle veut faire plaisir à tout le monde.; 'She wants...' would trigger the subjonctive. But we can't use that because the subject of the two phrases (she and she) are the same. So just use the inifinitive to express the desire.

question: to complain
answer: se plaindre; je me plains + tu te plains + il se plaint +...; NB: This is probably where the word 'plaintif' comes from.

question: How do you use the subjonctif for something in the past (e.g. I wished that you told me.)?
answer: Use passé composé. Conjugate the auxiliary in the subjonctif. The past participle stays the same.; When you use the subjonctif in the past tense you must use passé composé. You cannot use imparfait.

question: How do you use the subjonctif for something in the future (e.g. It's necessary that you take the bus tomorrow.)?
answer: There is no different future form of the subjonctif tense. Just use the present subjonctif form.; Il faut que tu prennes (subjonctif present) le bus demain.

question: I must cry.
answer: Il fait que je pleure (subjonctif).; This is by far the most common way of expressing that you must do something (not with devoir and not with avoir besoin).; The literal translation of 'il fait' is 'it is required'.
