This always triggers the subjonctif in the subsequent phrase (Il fait que + SUBJONCTIF).

question: She must go to the store before she watches TV.
answer: Elle doit aller au magasin AVANT QU'ELLE regarde la télévision.; 'before doing something' is usually expressed using AVANT QUE which always triggers the SUBJONCTIF in proper and spoken french.; So we use DEVOIR in the first phrase because we are using the subjonctif in the second phrase.

question: After someone arrives in France...
answer: APRÈS QUE quelqu'un SOIT arrivé en France.; 'after doing something' is usually expressed using APRÈS QUE which triggers the SUBJONCTIF in spoken french.; NB: Technically APRÈS QUE does not trigger the subjonctif in proper french (so use indicative tense on an exam) but this how people always write and speak now.

question: I hope that the sky is blue.
answer: J'espère que le ciel est (présent indicatif) bleu.; ESPÉRER (to hope) does NOT trigger the subjonctif. It is an exception to the subjonctif rules. So we use présent instead here.

question: They hope that you will eat well.
answer: Ils/Elles espèrent que tu mangeras (futur simple) bien.; ESPÉRER  (to hope) does NOT trigger the subjonctif. It is an exception to the subjonctif rules. So we use futur simple instead here.

question: I think that we have a cat.
answer: Je pense qu'on a un chat (AVOIR au présent indicatif).; PENSER does not trigger subjonctif when it is used in the positive sense.; NB: PENSER does triggers subjonctif when it is negated.

question: I do not think that the president is close to the people.
answer: Je ne pense pas que le président soit (ÊTRE au subjonctif) proche de gens.; PENSER does not trigger subjonctif when it is used in the positive sense. But PENSER does triggers subjonctif when it is negated.

question: I believe that education is a human right.
answer: Je crois que l'éducation est (ÊTRE au présent indicatif) un droit humain.; CROIRE does NOT trigger the subjonctif when it is used in the positive sense.; NB: CROIRE does triggers subjonctif when it is negated.

question: I do not believe that you have a dog.
answer: Je ne crois pas que tu aies (AVOIR au subjonctif) un chien.; CROIRE does not trigger the subjonctif when it is used in the positive sense. But it does trigger subjonctif when it is negated.

question: What do you want me to say?
answer: Que veux tu que je dise (subjonctif)?; The subjonctif is triggered because the affirmative version would be: You want that I (do something).

question: What do you want me to do?
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous voulez que ça me fasses (subjonctif)?; The subjonctif is triggered because the affirmative version would be: You want that I (do something).

question: What is the common way to express: X is required. / X is necessary.; What is the infinitive of the verb?
answer: Il faut...; FALLOIR is the infinitive. The meaning is similar to DEVOIR but FALLOIR is only ever conjugated for 3rd person singular (il/elle/on). FALLOIR communicates that some ambiguous 'it' or 'one' must be or do something.

question: One must be determined to work here.
answer: Il faut être déterminé(e) pour travailler ici.; IL FAUT + ÊTRE + any adjective is a good way to express: One must be X...

question: What is the difference between: Il faut... and Il faut que...
answer: IL FAUT + INFINITIV is even more general / less aggressive than IL FAUT QUE + PHRASE SUBJONCTIF.; Il faut que... connotes a higher sense of urgency than Il faut...; Both of these options are more general / less aggressive than using the verb DEVOIR. e.g. Vous devez faire X. = You (personally) must do X.

question: What are two generalized / non-aggressive ways to say: You/One must take the medicine.
answer: 1) Il faut prendre le médicament. 2) Il faut QUE vous preniez le médicament.; The former is the most generalized way. It uses an infinitive. The latter is slightly more targeted/personal and with a higher sense of urgency - it uses a subjonctif phrase.; Both are more generalized in comparison to using DEVOIR: Vous devez prendre le médicament.

question: What are two generalized / non-aggressive ways to say: We must win this match.
answer: 1) Il faut gagner ce match. 2) Il faut QU'on gagne ce match.; The former is the most generalized way. It uses an infinitive. The latter is slightly more targeted/personal and with a higher sense of urgency - it uses a subjonctif phrase.; Both are more generalized in comparison to using DEVOIR: On doit gagner ce match.

question: What is a very direct / confrontational way to say: You must eat healthily.
answer: Vous devez manger sainement.; This is much more direct than: Il faut manager sainement. or Il faut que vous manger sainement.

question: What are three progressively direct / confrontational ways to say: You must go to the doctor.
answer: Most generalized using FALLOIR + INFINITIV: Il faut aller chez médecin.; Slightly more targeted and with higher sense of urgency using FALLOIR + SUBJONCTIF: Il faut QUE tu ailles (subjonctif) chez le médecin.; Most direct/confrontational using DEVOIR: Tu doit aller chez le médecin.

question: Using FALLOIR what are two ways to say: You/One must rest.
answer: 1) Il faut SE reposer. (more generalized / less aggressive); 2) Il faut TE/VOUS reposer. (still generalized but slightly more personalized / confrontational and with higher sense of urgency); SE REPOSER is reflexive. This means that there is an additional layer of subtlety that can be used simply by changing whether or not the reflexive pronoun is conjugated after Il faut...; NB: Il faut que... and Vous devez... would both be more direct / confrontational than the two options for reflexive verbs that use Il faut...

question: I must wait.
answer: Il faut que j'attende.; It is more common to express this using FALLOIR (instead of using DEVOIR).; Il faut que triggers the subjonctif so j'attende is in the subjonctif form.

question: You had to do your homework before going out.
answer: More targeted with high sense of urgency: Il fallait (FALLOIR in imparfait) que tu fasses (subjonctif) tes devoirs avant de sortir.; More generalized alternative: Il fallait faire tes devoirs avant de sortir. This translates more to 'it was required to do our/your homework...'; FALLOIR alone signifies a general requirement. FALLOIR + QUE is a very targeted and personal statement.

question: Using falloir in imparfait: It was required to sleep. + I (emphasis on I) really needed to sleep.
answer: Il fallait dormir. + Il fallait que je dorme (subjonctif).; FALLOIR alone signifies a general requirement. FALLOIR + QUE is a very targeted statement with a higher sense of urgency.

question: Using falloir in conditionnel: We should sleep. + I should sleep.
answer: Il faudrait dormir. + Il faudrait que je dors (subjonctif).; FALLOIR alone signifies a general requirement. FALLOIR + QUE is a very targeted statement with a higher sense of urgency.

question: It was required that I come home before midnight.
answer: Il fallait que je revienne (subjonctif form of REVENIR) avant minuit.

question: It is important that the muscles are warm before stretching.
answer: C'est IMPORTANT QUE les muscles soient (subjonctif) chauds avant les étirements.; Any kind of opinion like this (e.g. It is critical that...) triggers the subjonctif.

question: He left even though I told him to stay.
answer: Il est parti BIEN QUE je lui aie (subjonctif) dit de rester.; BIEN QUE = though / although / even though / altogether. It always triggers the subjonctif.; When you use the subjonctif in the past tense you must use passé composé. You cannot use imparfait.

question: I learn tango so that we may dance together.
answer: J'apprends le tango POUR QUE nous dansions (subjonctif) ensemble.; POUR QUE = so that / in order that. It always trigger the subjonctif.; Alternatives that also trigger the subjonctif: afin que (so that) + en sorte que (so that) + vu que (given that).

question: We will leave now so that you are on time.
answer: Nous partirons maintenant afin que tu sois (subjonctif) à l’heure. AFIN QUE = so that. Like POUR QUE (and other alternatives) it triggers the subjonctif.

question: We have to leave before it gets dark.
answer: Nous devons partir avant qu’il fasse (subjonctif) nuit.; We have to use AVANT QUE (instead of avant de) because the subjects of the two phrases are different. And AVANT QUE always triggers the subjonctif.

question: We began to eat lunch after Paul arrived.
answer: Nous avons commencé de déjeuner après que Paul soit (subjonctif) / est (indicative) arrivé.; NB: APRÈS QUE does not trigger the subjonctif technically in proper french (so use indicative on an exam). BUT this is not how french is actually spoken and written. Everyone (even if they know it is technically incorrect) uses subjonctif after APRÈS QUE.; We have to use APRÈS QUE (instead of après de) because the subjects of the two phrases are different.

question: before going to the beach (in the present) + before going to the beach (in the past)
answer: avant D'aller à la plage + avant D'être allé(e) à la plage; au présent: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE of the verb; au passé: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE (which adjusts to gender/number when être is the auxiliary)

question: before visiting X (in the present) + before visiting X (in the past)
answer: avant DE rendre visite à X + avant D'avoir rendu visite à X; au présent: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE of the verb; au passé: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE (which adjusts to gender/number when être is the auxiliary)

question: before getting up (in the present) + before getting up (in the past)
answer: avant DE se lever + avant DE s'être levé(e); au présent: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE of the verb; au passé: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE (which adjusts to gender/number when être is the auxiliary)

question: before covid + before having covid
answer: avant le covid + avant d'avoir le covid; There is no DE required after avant when what follows is a noun. When a verb follows we must add DE.

question: after going to the beach
answer: après être allé(e) à la plage (no preposition DE with après); The formula is: APRÈS + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE; In french translate 'after doing...' as 'after HAVING done...' (auxiliary as a gerund + past participle). In french we almost always assume this is happening in the past tense - there is not an option for using présent (like there is for 'before doing something').; NB: We can only use this formula when the subject of this phrase and the independent phrase are the same. e.g. After going to the beach... I took a nap. If the subjects of these two phrases are different then you have to use après que instead.

question: after visiting X
answer: après avoir rendu visite à X (no preposition DE with après); The formula is: APRÈS + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE; In french translate 'after doing...' as 'after HAVING done...' (auxiliary as a gerund + past participle). In french we almost always assume this is happening in the past tense - there is not an option for using présent (like there is for 'before doing something').; NB: We can only use this formula when the subject of this phrase and the independent phrase are the same. e.g. After visiting my aunt... I went home. If the subjects of these two phrases are different then you have to use après que instead.

question: after drinking X
answer: après avoir bu X; The formula is: APRÈS + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE; In french translate 'after doing...' as 'after HAVING done...' (auxiliary as a gerund + past participle). In french we almost always assume this is happening in the past tense - there is not an option for using présent (like there is for 'before doing something').; NB: We can only use this formula when the subject of this phrase and the independent phrase are the same. e.g. After getting up... I brushed my teeth. If the subjects of these two phrases are different then you have to use après que instead.

question: after getting up
answer: après s'être levé(e) (no preposition DE with après); The formula is: APRÈS + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE; In french translate 'after doing...' as 'after HAVING done...' (auxiliary as a gerund + past participle). In french we almost always assume this is happening in the past tense - there is not an option for using présent (like there is for 'before doing something').; NB: We can only use this formula when the subject of this phrase and the independent phrase are the same. e.g. After getting up... I brushed my teeth. If the subjects of these two phrases are different then you have to use après que instead.

question: I was running all week.
answer: J'ai couru toute la semaine.

question: the people + the characters
answer: les gens + les personnages

question: an aquaintance + a contact (a person you know)
answer: une connaissance + un contact; a confident = un(e) confident(e)

question: a colleague + a peer
answer: un(e) collègue + un(e) pair

question: a friendship
answer: une amitié

question: a friend
answer: un(e) ami(e) (m/f; pronounced same); Alternative: le copain / la copine (pronounced differently); NB: Avoid using mon ami(e) / mes amis when talking about platonic friends because this sounds like boyfriend/girlfriend in french. Instead use un(e) ami(e) or des amis.

question: a good friend + an old friend (known for a long time)
answer: un(e) bon(ne) ami(e) + un(e) vieil(le) ami(e); Like english use the word for 'old' to describe both someone who is old and someone who you have known for a long time.

question: best friends
answer: des meilleurs amis; Alternatives: un(e) vrai(e) ami(e) = a true friend + un(e) pote = buddy/pal

question: 2 to 3 friends
answer: des amis; It's not idiomatic to say deux ou trois amis.

question: idiomatic way to refer to a classmate - a person that you went to school with and were friendly with but who is not necessarily as close to you as a friend
answer: two options: 1) un copain/une copine (m/f) is more modern 2)un/une camarade (literally: comrade) is less modern but still used

question: idiomatic way to refer to someone you work with but who is not necessarily a friend
answer: un/une collègue

question: a roomate
answer: un colocataire / une colocatrice; en colocation = living with roomates

question: 2 steps to the train
answer: à deux pas du train

question: a street + a pedestrian street
answer: + une rue + une rue piétonne; des piétons = the pedestrians

question: a road + an alley
answer: une route + la ruelle; La route is a bit of a 'false friend'. It means the pavement itself - not the route.

question: an avenue + a boulevard
answer: une avenue + un boulevard

question: on the avenue + on the boulevard
answer: DANS l'avenue + SUR le boulevard; Whether to use SUR or DANS has to be memorized.

question: on the road + on the street
answer: SUR la route + DANS la rue; Whether to use SUR or DANS has to be memorized.

question: in the plaza + in the street + in the photo
answer: SUR la place + DANS la rue + SUR la photo; Whether to use SUR or DANS has to be memorized.

question: a pathway + a bike path
answer: un chemin + une piste cyclable

question: a journey + a chase
answer: un voyage + une chasse; voyage de noces = honeymoon

question: a path (for your career)
answer: parcours; This can also mean path (un chemin) or journey (un voyage) but it can additionally be used to describe a path in life or work.

question: a sidewalk
answer: un trottoir

question: the traffic + a traffic jam
answer: le trafic/la circulation + un embouteillage; Alternative and very familiar option for traffic jam: un bouchon (like bottleneck)

question: rush hour + the rush (busy time) at a restaurant or party
answer: les heures de pointe + un coup de feu

question: to drive (conjugate it)
answer: conduire OR diriger (more like to operate or turn); CONDUIRE is conjugated similar to dire. je conduis + tu conduis + il conduit + nous conduisons + vous conduisez + ils conduisent; past participle: conduit

question: We drove. + We were driving.
answer: On a conduit. + On conduisait.; NB: You can use the verb 'to drive' in french the same as you do in english. e.g. On a conduit (we drove) means that we were all on a roadtrip.

question: to fly
answer: voler; This works for describing a bird or a person in an airplane.; VOLER also means 'to steal'.

question: a bicycle + a motorcycle
answer: un vélo + une moto

question: a car + a taxi
answer: une voiture + un taxi; a flat tire = un pneu crevé

question: to park (a car)
answer: garer

question: a truck + a van
answer: un camion + un van; NB: un van is a van used for travelling.

question: a police van + a firetruck
answer: une camionnette + un camion de pompier

question: a bus
answer: un bus; 'boos' the S is pronounced even though it is a final consonant because the origin of the word is foreign

question: a subway + a subway station
answer: le métro + la station de métro

question: a train + a train station
answer: un train ('tron') + la gare ('gahr' rhymes with car); NB: gare à toi (or anyone) = a warning to someone like you are watching them and there might be consequences if they do something

question: a boat
answer: un bateau; -eau and -eaux is pronounced like a really strong 'oh' - like the word chateau; plural for all words that end in -eau is to add an X; So boats is les bateaux.

question: a sailboat + a submarine
answer: un bateau à voile + un sous-marin

question: an airplane + a flight + an airport
answer: un avion + un vol + un aéroport (4 syllables! 'ah-yah-ro-por')

question: How do you pronounce Charles de Gaulle airport?
answer: aéroport (4 syllables! 'ah-ay-ro-pohr') Charles ('shahrl') de Gaulle ('gohl'; hard O like bateau and chateau)

question: a license plate (on a car)
answer: la plaque d'immatriculation

question: an engine
answer: un moteur

question: by sea + on the sea
answer: par la mer + sur le large

question: by foot + by bike + by horse
answer: À pied + À velo + À cheval

question: by car + by train + by subway + by plane
answer: EN voiture + EN train + EN métro + EN avion

question: public transport
answer: les transports en commun

question: The public transport in my city is really developed.
answer: Les transports en commun sont bien développés dans ma ville.

question: one-way + roundtrip
answer: aller simple + aller-retour

question: a trip
answer: un trajet

question: the luggage + a suitcase
answer: les bagages (plural masculine) + une valise

question: a forest + into the great outdoors
answer: une forêt + au grand air

question: the vineyard + the orchard
answer: le vignoble ("veen-yo") + le verger

question: the nature
answer: la nature

question: the climate
answer: le climat

question: the tropics
answer: les tropiques; alternative: un climat tropical (a tropical climate)

question: the mountain(s) + the hill
answer: la montagne / les montagnes + la colline

question: the volcano
answer: le volcan

question: a rock + a pebble
answer: un rocher + un caillou

question: the ocean + the sea
answer: un océan + une mer

question: the wave + The waves crash on the wall.
answer: la vague + Les vagues éclatent sur le mur.; ÉCLATENT = to burst. This seems to be a better verb than 'to crash'.

question: the river + the lake
answer: une rivière + un lac

question: the right bank + the left bank (of a river)
answer: la rive droite + la rive gauche; NB: sur berge = on the banks of river

question: the canal + the canals
answer: le canal ('kah-nal') + les canaux ('ka-noo'); The L in the singular form is pronounced.

question: the bridge + the port
answer: le poNt + le poRt

question: on the waterfront + the docks of the Seine
answer: sur les quais + les quais de Seine; pronounced 'kay'

question: a park on the Seine
answer: un parc SUR LA Seine; Use sur instead of dans. La Seine is feminine.

question: an amusement park
answer: un parc d'attraction

question: the beach(s)
answer: la plage / les plages

question: a beach cabana
answer: une cabine de plage

question: the sand
answer: le sable

question: the sky + the atmosphere
answer: le ciel + l'atmosphère (feminine)

question: a star + a planet
answer: une étoile + une planète

question: the Moon + the Earth
answer: la Lune + la Terre; These words are capitalized in french.

question: the fire + the fireworks
answer: le feu + le feu d'artifice; Fireworks is singular in french though plural in english.; NB: un incendie = an incidence (specifically of a fire)

question: the gift
answer: le cadeau OR le don

question: to offer as a gift
answer: donner/offrir en cadeau; offrir = to offer

question: on sale
answer: en promotion OR en solde OR soldé

question: a possibility of promotion (in a job)
answer: une possibilité de promotion

question: a package/bundle of services
answer: forfait

question: to close a sale
answer: clore l'échange

question: to stand in line
answer: faire la queue

question: the checkout
answer: le caisses ('kes')

question: He goes to the checkout.
answer: Il va aux caisses.; à + les = aux ('oh')

question: paid for
answer: payant

question: shopping
answer: le shopping (remember 'le' is pronounced 'luh')

question: I wear all black.
answer: Je porte tout en noir.

question: the color
answer: une couleur; The noun for color is feminine. But when you use a color as a noun (e.g. the blue) then it is always masculine (e.g. le bleu).; The second part of the word -leur is pronounced the same as time/hour (l'heure).

question: the (color) white + white (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le blanc + blanc ('blon') / blanche ('blonch') / blancs (masculine plural; pronounced same as masculine singular) / blanches (feminine plural; pronounced same as feminine singular)

question: the (color) black + black (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le noir + noir / noire / noirs (masc pl) / noires (fem pl); all four are pronounced exactly the same way

question: the (color) red + red (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le rouge + rouge / rouge / rouges / rouges; when an adjective ends in 'e' it has the same spelling for masculine and feminine

question: the (color) pink + pink (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le rose + rose ('roos') / rose / roses / roses; Adjectives that end in 'e' are the same for masculine and feminine.

question: the (color) orange + orange (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le orange + orange ('or-onj') / orange / orange / orange; We never add an 's' to orange.

question: the (color) yellow + yellow (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le jaune + jaune ('jown') / jaune / jaunes / jaunes; 'au' makes a strong 'oh' sound; if you say 'joon' that is a different word meaning young

question: the (color) green + green (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le vert + vert ('ver') / verte ('vert') / verts (masc plural) / vertes (fem plural)

question: the (color) blue + blue (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le bleu + bleu ('blu') / bleue / bleus / bleues

question: the (color) purple + purple (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le violet + violet ('vee-oh-lay') / violette / violets / violettes; Use 'bordeaux' to describe a deep wine color

question: the (color) brown + brown (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le marron + marron ('meh-ron') / marron / marron / marron; same spelling and pronunciation for all four forms

question: the (color) gray + gray (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le gris + gris / grise / gris / grises; The adjective already ends in 's' so the masculine plural is same as masculine singular (gris).

question: a gray area (where the rules are not certain)
answer: une zone grise

question: without color
answer: incolore

question: silver
answer: argenté(e)

question: golden
answer: doré(e)

question: bright (with light) + dark (without light)
answer: lumineux + sombre

question: light (in color) + dark (in color)
answer: clair + foncé; NB: sombre is the most common word used for dark but it means without light - not the darker shade of a color.

question: She wears light blue shoes.
answer: Elle porte des chaussures bleues claires.; chaussures are plural and feminine so the adjectives must agree; do not forget to use an article before the noun

question: He wears a dark yellow jacket.
answer: Il porte une veste jaune foncée.

question: I like green. + He likes orange.
answer: J'aime le vert. + Il aime l'orange.; do not forget that there must be an article before every noun and - in this case - green is a noun instead of an adjective

question: Do you have it in white?
answer: Vous l'avez EN blanc

question: a place
answer: un lieu ('lyew'; to make plural add x) OR endroit OR l'emplacement

question: a space
answer: un espace; the green spaces (in a city e.g. parks) = les espaces verts

question: a store + a clothing store
answer: un magasin ('ma-ga-zOn') + un magasin de vêtements; Take care because this is a 'faux ami'. un magazine ('ma-ga-zEEn') is like Vogue; alternative: la boutique (more like a shop)

question: the jewelry shop + jeweler (m/f)
answer: la bijouterie + bijoutier/bijoutière (m/f)

question: a mall
answer: un grand magasin; e.g. Le Bon Marché + Les Halles + Le Printemps + La Samaritaine; This does not mean department store (e.g. BHV - Bazar de l'Hotel de Ville)

question: a display case/window (like at retail store)
answer: une vitrine

question: to line up (like at the checkout of a store)
answer: faire le queue

question: the market(s)
answer: le marché / les marchés ('mar-shay'); NB: When there is an accent on the E it means market. Without accent it means I walk ('marsh')

question: the garage sale + the flea market
answer: le vide-grenier + la brocante / les puces (literally: the fleas)

question: the workshop
answer: un atelier; Be sure to pronounce all four syllables: 'ah-tuh-lee-ay'

question: the fruit or vegetable stand + a stand (of another kind at the market)
answer: le primeur ('pree-mur') + un stand

question: the pastry shop
answer: la pâtisserie

question: the bakery + the baker (m/f)
answer: la boulangerie ('boo-lan-jree') + le boulanger (masc 'ay') / la boulangère (fem 'ehr'); NB: Drop the 'e' in 'erie'. Do not say all the syllables like 'boo-lan-jear-ree' - instead just say 'boo-lan-jree'.

question: We go to the bakery.
answer: On va à la boulangerie.; Use à la OR au (à + le) OR aux (à + les) when you are talking about a place/location.

question: She goes to the cinema.
answer: Elle va au cinéma.;à + le = au ('oh')

question: at your place
answer: chez toi; The preposition CHEZ triggers tonique pronouns. e.g. chez Marie becomes chez elle.; Do not use À or EN in front of chez. Chez is enough.

question: We go to our place. (using nous) + We go to our place. (using on)
answer: Nous allons chez NOUS. + On va chez SOI.; When you use the subject pronoun ON then the tonique pronoun is SOI.

question: Everyone goes home.
answer: Tout va chez SOI.; The pronom SOI is used in this generalized case.

question: at my friend's parent's place + at her cousin's place
answer: chez les parents de mon ami + chez sa cousine; chez can be followed by nouns as well as tonique pronouns (e.g. chez moi)

question: You (informal) are in Marseille. You (informal) go to Marseille.
answer: Tu es à Marseille. Tu vas à Marseille.; Use à for being in a place and for going in the direction of a place (that is definitely not a person or a person's home).

question: the butcher shop + the butcher (m/f)
answer: la boucherie + le boucher / la bouchère; Pronounce like a U 'boosh-ree'.

question: the fish shop + the fishmonger (m/f)
answer: la poissonnerie + le poissonier / la poissonière

question: the cheese shop + the cheesemonger (m/f)
answer: le fromager + le fromager OR le crémier / la crémière; NB: There is no feminine version of fromager.; The name of a cheese shop is an exception because it looks like the masculine version of a cheesemonger.

question: the floral shop + the florist (m/f)
answer: le fleuriste (like the person) + le fleuriste / la fleuriste; There is no word for floral shop (except maybe magasin de fleur). Use the word for the florist - like I'm going to the barber/hairdresser.

question: They go to the floral shop.
answer: Ils vont chez le flueriste.; There is no word for floral shop. So one always says they are going to the florist which is a person (not a place) so use chez instead of à.

question: the wine shop + the wine merchant (m/f)
answer: la cave à vin (not DE) + le caviste

question: the chocolate shop + the chocolate merchant (m/f)
answer: la chocolaterie + le chocolatier / la chocolatiere

question: the bank
answer: la banque

question: the post office + the posting (like a position or job)
answer: LA poste + LE poste; The spelling is exactly the same but the gender is different.

question: the mailperson
answer: two options: 1) le postier is a person who works at the post office; 2) le facteur is a person who delivers the mail

question: the laundromat
answer: la laverie

question: the dry cleaners
answer: le pressing

question: a cobbler store + a cobbler person (masc + fem)
answer: une cordonnerie + un cordonnier/une cordonnière (m/f); NB: -IER ending sounds like 'yay' with two Y sounds. cordonnier ('kohr-duh-nYay') and cordonnière ('kohr-dun-nYehr')

question: a hair salon + a hairdresser (masc + fem)
answer: un coiffeur ('qwuh-fuhr') + un coiffeur/une coiffeuse (m/f); Le coiffeur (how you call the salon) is a person - not a place - so use chez instead of à when you say you go to the hair salon (like going to the barber).

question: I got a haircut.
answer: This is not translated literally. Instead say: I went to the barber. = Je suis allé(e) chez le coiffeur.

question: a pharmacist (m/f)
answer: un pharmacien / une pharmacienne

question: a pharmacy
answer: une pharmacie

question: a doctor (m/f)
answer: médicin (same m/f); Skip the pronunciation of the middle I.; You can't make the word feminine because then it would be the word for the subject of medicine (la médecine).; Less common alternative: un docteur / une doctoresse

question: medicine (the study of) + law (the study of)
answer: la médecine + le droit (not la loi)

question: the chemistry of the body
answer: la chemie du corps

question: a dentist (m/f)
answer: un/une dentiste; NB: When using chez there is no article. e.g. chez dentiste + chez médicin ...not chez LE dentiste

question: a patient (m/f)
answer: un patient / une patiente

question: the reception desk (of a doctor's office)
answer: l'accueil du cabinet médical; NB: médical (medical) is an irregular adjective. It becomes médiCAUX when it modifies a plural noun. e.g. les cabinets médicaux = the medical offices

question: the person that works the reception desk of a doctor's office
answer: le/la secrétaire (same for m/f) OR l'assistant(e)

question: a doctor's office + an exam room (at the doctor)
answer: un cabinet du docteur + le cabinet médical

question: a (medical) clinic
answer: une clinique

question: a hospital
answer: un hôpital

question: health insurance (public) + health insurance (private + supplemental)
answer: une assurance maladie/santé + une mutuelle

question: the social security number
answer: le numéro de sécurité social ('soh-see-ehl'); When a french word ends in -CIAL pronounce it the same as the word for sky: ciel.; This is the number on the carte vitale.

question: the social safety net
answer: la sécurité sociale

question: I do not have mutuelle insurance yet - only public health insurance.
answer: Je n'ai pas DE mutuelle encore - seulement la sécurité sociale.; Use DE because a negative amount is still a quantity.

question: to be sick
answer: s'enfermer (reflexive)

question: to be seasick
answer: AVOIR LE mal de mer

question: to cough
answer: tousser; eg. Je tousse

question: to sneeze
answer: éternuer

question: to breathe + to blow (e.g. candles)
answer: respirer + souffler

question: breathtaking
answer: à couper le souffle; Literally: cuts the breath

question: genetic
answer: génétique (same m/f)

question: the cold (mostly contained to nose) + the flu
answer: le rhume + la grippe

question: I caught a cold.
answer: J'ai attrapé un rhume.; ATTRAPER is the verb 'to catch' and we use it the same way in french as in english. e.g. to catch a ball and to catch a cold

question: I have a fever.
answer: J'ai de la fièvre.

question: a smell + fragrant
answer: un odeur + oderant(e)

question: What are the two ways to talk about pain/injury?
answer: 1) To talk about acute pain/discomfort or to talk about health status in general: person injured + AVOIR MAL À + body part. 2) To talk about an event where someone was injured: person injured + SE FAIRE + MAL À + body part ...the reflexive pronoun is conjugated for the person that was injured (not the part of the body).

question: His hand is hurting / in pain.
answer: Il a mal À la main.; Use AVOIR + MAL À + body part because the pain is acute and happening right now.

question: He injured his hand.
answer: Il s'est fait (passé composé of SE FAIRE) À la main.; Use SE FAIRE + MAL À + body part because we are talking about an event where someone injured (themselves).

question: My knees hurt.
answer: Two possibilities: 1) J'ai mal AUX genoux. (à + les = aux); 2) Mes genoux me font (SE FAIRE) mal.; The second option is a different wasy to use SE FAIRE where the subject is the body part instead of the person injured.

question: an injury + a disease
answer: une blessure + une maladie; NB: le sida = AIDS

question: I have a headache. / My head hurts.
answer: J'ai mal À la tête.;To talk about pain/discomfort: AVOIR MAL + À + body part

question: I have a soar throat.
answer: J'ai mal À la gorge. / Ma gorge me fait mal.; To say that you hurt somewhere it is AVOIR + MAL + à + le/la/les + X.; To say that something hurts you... X + ME + FAIRE + MAL

question: I have a stomach ache.
answer: J'ai mal AU ventre.; à + le = au

question: My feet hurt.
answer: J'ai mal AUX pieds.; à + les = aux

question: painful (adjective) + a pain/hurt (the noun)
answer: douloureux/douloureuse + une douleur; -leur is pronounced the same as time/hour (l'heure).

question: It must have hurt.
answer: Ça a du (passé composé form of DEVOIR) être douloureux.; Literally: It must have been painful.

question: idiomatic ways to say: Get well soon. + Take care of yourself.
answer: Bon rétablissement. + Prends soin de toi.

question: the health
answer: la santé

question: the symptom
answer: le symptôme

question: a sample + the blood
answer: un échantillon + le sang; to bleed = saigner

question: a medical treatment
answer: un traitement

question: medicine
answer: two options: le médicament is for when you take medicine; la médecine is the subject of medicine - what doctor's study

question: the cost of medication
answer: la coûte des médicaments

question: a vaccine + an anaesthesia
answer: un vaccin + une anesthésie

question: a dose (of medicine)
answer: une dose ('doze') with a closed/ferme 'o' sound and downward tone.

question: a pill + a tablet + a lozenge
answer: une pilule + une tablette + une pastille

question: I will write an order for the pharmacy/laboratory.
answer: Je vais préparer l'ordonnance pour la pharmacie/le laboratoire.

question: I will prescribe X to you.
answer: Je vais vous prescrire X.

question: necessary + necessarily
answer: nécessaire + nécessairement; Transform an adjective that ends in a vowel by adding -MENT. This ensures a vowel is present before -MENT ending.

question: required + obligated (to do something)
answer: obligatoire + obligé(e)

question: a body
answer: un corps; This word is used similarly as in english: a physical body + a group in the military + a group of dancers

question: a head + a skull
answer: une tête + un crâne

question: hair
answer: literally one hair is 'un cheveu' but typically we use the plural to indicate hair: les cheveux; both are pronounced 'shuh-vooh' (e.g. peux). This is NOT the deep U sound.

question: a face
answer: un visage

question: a brain
answer: un cerveau

question: an eye + the eyes
answer: un oeil ('uhn-oy') + les yeux ('lay-zyoo')

question: an eyebrow
answer: un sourcil

question: a nose
answer: un nez

question: a cheek
answer: une joue ('zshoo'); It is pronounced as a single syllable starting with a soft J. This is the same pronunciation as the verb jouer when it is conjugated in the present tense: je joue + tu joues + il joue + ils jouent

question: a mouth + a chin
answer: une bouche + un menton; NB: bouche is pronounced 'boosh'. This is different from entretien d'embauche (job interview) which is pronounced more like 'dohm-bosh'. The last syllable ryhmes with bow.

question: a tongue
answer: une langue; This is exactly the same word that is used for 'a language'.

question: a tooth + the teeth
answer: une dent + les dents

question: an ear + the ears
answer: une oreille ('oo-noe-ray') + les oreilles ('le-zoe-ray')

question: a neck + a throat
answer: un cou + une gorge

question: a shoulder
answer: une épaule ('ay-pole'); AU sounds like a hard O in french. The final E is silent. The L is pronounced.

question: a chest (on the body)
answer: une poitrine

question: a lung + a heart
answer: un poumon + un coeur

question: a stomach / a belly
answer: une estomac (C is silent) / le ventre

question: the kidney + the liver + the intestines
answer: le rein + le foie + les intestins

question: a thorax + an abdomen
answer: un thorax + un abdomen (remember the N is silent)

question: an arm + an elbow
answer: un bras + un coude

question: a hand + a wrist
answer: une main + un poignet

question: a finger
answer: un doigt

question: the back
answer: le dos ('doe')

question: the butt + the hip
answer: les fesses (always plural) + la hanche

question: The hips bend.
answer: Les hanches SE plient.; PLIER is the verb 'to bend'. You must use it reflexively when there is no object.

question: a leg + a thigh
answer: une jambe + une cuisse

question: a knee + the knees
answer: un genou + les genoux

question: a foot
answer: un pied; sous-pied = the bottom of the foot; at her feet = à ses pieds

question: I come on foot. (I walk.) + to drag one's feet (to procrastinate physically)
answer: Je viene à pied. + traîner les pieds

question: a toe + an ankle
answer: un orteil + une cheville

question: the skin
answer: la peau ('poh'; like chateau and bateau); the sensitive skin = la peau sensible

question: the scar
answer: la cicatrice

question: a scar on my skin (literal) + a scar on the United States (figurative)
answer: une cicatrice SUR mon peux + une cicatrice POUR les états-unis; Use SUR when you mean a literal scar. Use POUR when you mean a figurative scar.

question: an appointment (at an office) + a reservation (at a restaurant)
answer: un rendez-vous + une reservation

question: a real estate agency
answer: une agence immobilière; 'ee-mobe-uh-lee-ehr'; the sound of the first I changes from 'uhn' (like inginieur) to 'ee' when there is a double consonant (mm) following it.

question: a restuarant + a cafe / a brasserie / a bar
answer: un restaurant + un café + une brasserie / un bar

question: to a little bar
answer: à un petit bar; à + un do not contract

question: How do you ask for something at a store/market? e.g. Ask for flour.
answer: First you always greet (e.g. bonjour!) and then ask for a general amount: Bonjour je voudrais de la farine.; Then - after they know what you are talking about - you specify the amount... 500 grammes de farine.; Never ever say 'je veux...' which is very rude. If the other person is in a rush then it is possible to say 'un baguette s.v.p.' but this is an exception.

question: When ordering something in a market/store/etc. how do you construct the opening phrase?
answer: Use the partitive articles (du/d' + de la/de l' + des/d') initially to indicate an unspecified quantity.; e.g. Bonjour je voudrais du café / de la farine / de l'huile / des pommes; NB: du = de + le and des = de + les because 'de le' and 'de les' are not used. D' occurs when du or des are followed by a noun that starts with a vowel.

question: When ordering something in a market/store/etc. how do you construct the second half of the phrase?
answer: After opening with a general statement of what you want in unspecified quanities... then specify the amount. Doing so will replaces partitive articles with DE or D' - only two options.; e.g. 500 grammes de café / un paquet de salade / une carafe d'eau / plus de pommes.; D' occurs when de is followed by a noun that starts with a vowel.

question: the delivery

question: I want 500 grams of meat.
answer: Je veux 500 grammes de viande.; This is what you say after you requested 'some' (general amount) of meat.; Now you express yourself more directly (I want) and you give a specific amount.; Because there is a specified amount we use a more generalized preposition that doesn't care about gender or number - there are only two options: DE (if the noun starts with a consonant) or D' (if the noun starts with a vowel) - both regardless of gender and number

question: a bottle of oil

question: a pinch of salt
answer: une pincée de sel; 'a pinch' is actually a specified amount; Use DE (or D' if noun starts with vowel) when you are talking about a specific amount OR a lack of something

question: I have a cat. I do not have a cat.
answer: J'ai UN chat. Je n'ai pas DE chat.; Add DE because ne pas (none) is a treated like a quantity so you have to add DE before a noun that follows.; NB: If what follows (after PAS) is verb then DE is not required.

question: No zuchini. / No onion.
answer: pas de courgette; A negative amount is considered a specific amount. So we use the non-specific prepositions that don't care about gender or number: DE (if the noun starts with a consonant) or D' (if the noun starts with a vowel)

question: No onion.
answer: pas d'oignon; A negative amount is considered a specific amount. So we use the non-specific prepositions that don't care about gender or number: DE (if the noun starts with a consonant) or D' (if the noun starts with a vowel)

question: I walked to the museum.
answer: J'ai marché jusqu'au musée.; Use MARCHER when you are walking purposefully but you cannot use MARCHER + À. (J'ai marché au musée is impossible.); Use JUSQUE when you there is some distance and you are walking until the end.; Alternative: If you want to use À then you could say: Je suis allé(e) au musée. OR Je suis allé(e) à pied au musée.

question: I walked toward the school.

question: I walk the dog.
answer: Je promène le chien. OR Je me promène avec mon chien. (The reflexive pronoun is not obligatory here because the object being walked is not a person.); When you are 'walking' a thing (not a person) then you can use PROMENER without reflexive pronoun. But if you were walking with a person then you would need to use SE PROMENER + AVEC; NB: You cannot say: Je marche mon chien. MARCHER does not work in this context. It is only used for purposeful walking between two points.

question: I walk with my grandmother.
answer: Je ME promène AVEC ma grand-mère.; PROMENER is the best verb choice. But you must use if reflexively if you are walking another person (instead of a dog etc.) AND you must use AVEC to indicate the person with whom you are walking (walking with someone instead of walking someone).

question: I escort the family.
answer: J'escorte la famille.; ESCORTER is a verb that you can use for walking around with someone that does not require prepositions or a reflexive pronoun. The person being escorted is the COD.

question: He accompanies her (e.g. with the guitar).
answer: Il l'accompagne.; ACCOMPAGNER is reserved for meaning 'on the side'. It is not used for escorting someone (to some place).

question: identity + place of origin + place where you live

question: Laurent is married to Lyna.

question: Our friends will get married. (futur proche)

Voulons is the conjugation for nous au présent so the radical is VOUL. -AIT is the imparfait ending for il/elle.; Then you can use the infinitive (SE MARIER).

question: When do you use the prepositions à + de + pour?
answer: There are many uses but these three are the options to use in front of verb when you are explaining that someone or something is doing some infinitive verb; e.g. C'est facile à faire. (That's easy to do.); Il est bon d'étudier. (It is good to study.); On a engagé une personne pour faire le ménage. (We hire a person IN ORDER TO do the chores.)

question: How do you know whether to use à vs de vs pour in front of an infinitive verb?
answer: Use 'pour' if you could replace the phrase with 'in order to do x'. You are providing a reason/explanation for doing something.; The remainder use à or de but you have to memorize those. 'de' can usually be used to replace 'from'. 'à' can usually be used to replace 'to'.

question: What is the preposition 'in' for any city (e.g. I live in Istanbul)?
answer: à Istanbul à Paris à Detroit...same for any city

question: What is the preposition 'from' for any city (e.g. I am from Istanbul)?
answer: de Istanbul de Paris de Detroit...same for any city

question: What is the preposition 'in' for a country (e.g. I live in France)?
answer: it depends on the gender...feminine: en France; masculine: au Canada; plural (au = à le which is never used): aux États-Unis; au and aux are pronounced 'oh'; Use this following verbs such as aller + rester + partir.

question: What is the preposition 'from' for a country(e.g. I am from Germany)?
answer: it depends on the gender...feminine: de France; masculine: du Brésil (du = de le which is never used);plural: des États-Unis

question: a city / in the city
answer: une ville / en ville (NOT á ville); Do not use cité - that is like a greek city-state and not idiomatic french; The pronunciation of this word is an exception: 'veel' (instead of 'veey' which would be the expected pronunciation)

question: hometown + a capital city (of a country)
answer: la ville natale + la capitale

question: a village
answer: un village

question: in Paris + in Berlin + in Montreal + in Buenos Aires; Specify pronunciation.
answer: á Paris ('pah-ree') + á Berlin ('bear-luhn'; i like ingénieur) + à Montréal ('mon-ray-ahl'; Do not pronounce the T.) + à Buenos Aires (pronounce it exactly the same as in spanish - including the S's; Do not try to pronounce this is a french way.)

question: in NYC + in Harlem
answer: á New York (pronounced same as in English) + à Harlem; Use à for cities and neighborhoods.

question: on the island of Manhattan
answer: dans l'île de Manhattan; Use dans instead of sur in this case.

question: in Virginia + in California
answer: en Virginie + en Californie; Note that the spelling changes!; Use en instead of à when describing a region/territory. à is reserved for cities and very specific locations (e.g. a musuem)

question: in Provence + in Normandy
answer: en Provence + en Normandie; Note that the spelling changes!; Use en instead of à when describing a region/territory.

question: a country
answer: un pays ('pay-yee'); This is pronounced very clearly as two syllables - not 'pay'.

question: in France
answer: en France (feminine); Names of countries are capitalized in French. Names of nationalities and languages are not capitalized in French.

question: in Canada + in England
answer: au Canada (masculine) + en Angleterre (feminine); NB: United Kingdom = Le Royaume-Uni

question: in United States
answer: aux États-Unis (plural); aux is pronounced 'ooh'

question: in Sweden + in Switzerland + in Belgium
answer: en Suède + en Suisse + en Belgique(all feminine); Generally if a country name ends in E then it is feminine. But there are exceptions.

question: in Mexico + in Morocco
answer: au Mexique + au Maroc (all masculine)

question: in Austria + in Hungary + in Scotland
answer: en Autriche + en Hongrie + en Écosse (all feminine); Generally if a country name ends in E then it is feminine. But there are exceptions.

question: in Israel + in Peru + in Nigeria
answer: au Israël + au Pérou + au Nigéria (all masculine)

question: in China + in Spain
answer: all feminine: en Chine + en Espagne ('uh-nay-spagn' pronounced all together ); Generally if a country name ends in E then it is feminine. But there are exceptions.

question: in Iraq +  in Iran
answer: en Iraq + en Iran; Both of these countries are masculine (not feminine). But we cannot write/say AU + VOWEL in french so we must use EN instead.

question: from NYC + from France
answer: de ('duh') New York + France; Both are feminine.

question: from Brazil + from Japan
answer: du ('doo') Brésil + Japon; Both are masculine.

question: from the United States
answer: des États-Unis ('day' because plural)

question: All countries that end in 'e' are feminine except for which six?
answer: le Mexique + le Mozambique + le Belize + le Cambodge + le Suriname + le Zimbabwe

question: I live in Paris.
answer: Je vis à Paris.

question: I live in France.
answer: Je vis en France. (feminine)

question: I would like to live in Mexico.
answer: Je voudrais vivre au Mexique. (masculine)

question: I am from New York City. + I am from the United States.
answer: Je viens de New York. ('vee-yun-duh') + Je viens des États-Unis (plural).

question: I am originally from Paris.
answer: Je suis originaire de Paris.

question: I am early / on time / late.
answer: Je suis en avance / à l'heure / en retard.; En avance and en retard are the correct choice for describing arrival. But if you are describing departure (or a person or thing) then use plus tard and plus tôt.

question: exactly on time
answer: pile à l'heure

question: at some time
answer: à une certaine heure

question: late (in the day) / early (in the day)
answer: tard / tôt

question: Sorry for being late.
answer: Je suis désolé(e) D'avoir été en retard.; Use DE after Je suis désolé(e) to explain for what you are sorry.

question: I'm sorry that I am not able to come.
answer: Je suis désolé(e) DE ne pas pouvoir venir.; Use DE after Je suis désolé(e) to explain for what you are sorry.

question: He arrived early. + He left the party early.
answer: Il est arrivé en avance. + Il est parti la fête plus tôt.; NB: En retard is used for arrival. Plus tard is used for departure (of people or things).

question: She arrived late.  + She left the party late.
answer: Elle est arrivée en retard. + Elle est partie la fête plus tard.; NB: En retard is used for arrival. Plus tard is used for departure (of people or things).

question: We talked late into the night.
answer: On a parlé jusqu'à tard la nuit. OR On a parlé très tard dans la nuit.; NB: If you talked until the morning = jusqu'à matin

question: There were 10 people AT the party.
answer: Il y avait dix personnes À la soirée.; Not dans la soirée.

question: It was a long time ago. + It's been a while.
answer: Il y a longtemps. + Ça faisait longtemps.

question: time (in general)
answer: le temps ('ton'); It has an S even when singular; Caution: Le temps can mean weather + time + tense of a verb.

question: I need more time. / We have lots of time.
answer: J'ai besoin de plus de temps. / On a beaucoup de temps.; NB: Both plus and beaucoup are quantities so we use DE before the noun.

question: It takes a lot of time. / It will take a lot of time.
answer: Ça prend beaucoup de temps. / Ça prendra (futur simple) beaucoup de temps.; Different verbs are used to mean 'it takes' in different circumstances including: PRENDRE + METTRE + DEMANDER

question: It took a lot of time to fix the leak.
answer: Il a fallu beaucoup de temps pour réparer la fuite.; Il a fallu is FALLOIR in passé composé - the verb that is only conjugated in 3rd person singular.; Il a fallu generally means it 'took' or 'required' something.; We use the same verb in the present tense to talk about how something is required or must be.; Different verbs are used to mean 'it takes' in different circumstances including: PRENDRE + METTRE + DEMANDER

question: I take an hour (to do something).
answer: Je mets une heure...; Different verbs are used to mean 'it takes' in different circumstances including: PRENDRE + METTRE + DEMANDER

question: from time to time; Specify pronunciation.
answer: de temps en temps ('duh-tuh-Suhn-tuh'; The S on the first temps is pronounced because of the liaison. The S on the second temps is silent.)

question: to set aside time for an activity
answer: se réserver; e.g. Je me réserve une sortie au cinéma avec des amis. = I am setting aside time for a night out at the cinema with frends.; RÉSERVER (without reflexive pronoun) = to reserve / to make a booking

question: a lot of waiting
answer: beaucoup D'attente; Use DE between beaucoup and the verb because it is still a quantity.

question: the waiting room
answer: la salle D'attente

question: I need to rest.
answer: J'ai besoin DE rester.; AVOIR + BESOIN is always followed by DE (regardless of whether it is followed by a noun or infinitive verb).

question: training/practice (in the most general way) + training/practice (for a sport) + training (for a career - a formal process)
answer: la pratique (the most general - use this for almost everything) + l'entrainement (feminine; use for practicing a sport) + la formation (only use this for a very strict preparation for a career or specific competence)

question: I need to practice more.
answer: J'ai besoin DE pratiquer plus.; PRATIQUER is the best verb for practice/training. There are other nouns to express practice/training but this is the closest verb.; AVOIR + BESOIN is always followed by DE (regardless of whether it is followed by a noun or infinitive verb).

question: I need more practice.
answer: J'ai besoin DE plus de beaucoup de pratique (most common way to express this) / d'entrainement (use for sports) / de formation (use for career training).; AVOIR + BESOIN is always followed by DE (regardless of whether it is followed by a noun or infinitive verb).

question: Can we practice asking questions?
answer: Pouvons nous pratiquer à poser des questions ?; This is a common way to use the verb pratiquer. If you really want to avoid that 'anglo' word then an alternative is to use the verb s'entraîner: Pouvons nous s'entraîner à poser des questions ?

question: It takes a lot of practice.
answer: Ça demander beaucoup DE pratiquer.; Alternatively you can use: Ça demander beaucoup d'entrainements. This avoids the use of the 'anglo' pratiquer.;  Different verbs are used to mean 'it takes' in different circumstances including: PRENDRE + METTRE + DEMANDER.; Use DE between beaucoup and the verb because it is still a quantity.

question: X is the opposite of Y.
answer: X est le contraire de Y.; contre = against

question: What/which do you choose?
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous choisissez?; remember single S is pronounced 'z' but double S is pronounced 'z'

question: It is difficult to choose the correct verb tense.
answer: C'est difficile DE choisir le bon temps.; Use DE - not POUR - in this situation.

question: a good time
answer: un bon moment; e.g. We had a good time. = On a passé un bon moment.

question: Everyone had a good time.
answer: Tout le monde a passé un bon moment.; When you mean having a good time then use PASSER (not reflexively) with auxiliary AVOIR (not être).; NB: PASSER can be used with both auxiliary verbs in passé composé: Je suis passé(e). = I passed (next to something). J'ai passé. = I passed/spent (time doing something).

question: Everything went well.
answer: Tout s'est passé (passé compose with SE PASSER) correctement.; This is slightly different than expressing having a good time (AVOIR + PASSER). Instead we use SE PASSER (instead of PASSER) and we must use être as the auxiliary because the verb is reflexive.; Tout is masculine singular so we use est (être) instead of sont.

question: I felt like they were not having a good time.
answer: J'avais l'impression qu'ils n'allaient pas passer du bon.; Everything in imparfait because you are recalling a story.; NB: If you felt something physically then use (SE) SENTIR instead of AVOIR l'impression.

question: the pronoun
answer: le pronom

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au présent?
answer: If there is only one word representing the verb in présent then pronouns come before that verb; NB: This is true for all tenses where a single word represents the entire verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au présent when using two verbs (e.g. I want to dance.)?
answer: in between the conjugated HELPER and the INFINITIVE; NB: For any tense... whenever you need two different verbs where one is a conjugated HELPER and the other is the INFINITIVE... then pronouns usually are placed before the infinitive - but not before the helper verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au passé composé?
answer: before both the AUXILLIARY conjugated form of avoir/être and the PAST PARTICIPLE; NB: This does not violate the general rule that pronouns come before an infinitive when using two verbs together (e.g. I want to dance) because there is no infinitive in passé composé - there are two words acting as verbs but they are viewed as a single verb (auxiliary + past participle). So the pronouns are placed before both the auxiliary and past participle.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au imparfait and conditionnel?
answer: If there is only one word representing the verb in imparfait then pronouns come before that verb; NB: This is true for all tenses where a single word represents the entire verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au futur proche?
answer: in between the conjugated form of ALLER and the INFINITIVE; NB: This follows the rule of dual verbs. Whenever you need two different verbs in french where one is a conjugated HELPER and the other is the INFINITIVE (e.g. I want to dance = Je veux danser)... then pronouns usually are placed before the infinitive - but not before the helper verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au futur simple?
answer: If there is only one word representing the verb in futur simple then pronouns come before that verb; NB: This is true for all tenses where a single word represents the entire verb.

question: List the french pronoms sujets (aka subject pronouns) e.g. YOU went to the store.
answer: je + tu + il/elle/on + nous + vous + ils/elles

question: What is a COD (compléments d’objet direct) aka a direct object?
answer: An object that receives or experiences the action of the verb. e.g. I bought IT.; COD (direct objects) generally follow a verb when spelled out. If we use a COD pronoun then the pronoun moves in front of the verb.

question: List the french COD pronoms.
answer: me + te + le(m)/la(f) + nous + vous + les(m/f); me + te + le/la change to m’ + t’ + l’ in front of a vowel or mute H.; NB: The COD pronouns for he/she/they are the same as the definite articles (le/la/l'/les).

question: What is a COI (compléments d’objet indirect) aka an indirect object?
answer: An indirect object receives a direct object or is 'for whom' the action of the verb is done. e.g. I gave THEM the book.; Indirect objects follow a verb when spelled out.; NB: When a preposition is used in front of the object (for THEM) then it is technically NOT an indirect object (and is not receiving the direct object) in English. Instead we call it an 'object of a preposition'. e.g. I gave the book to THEM. The coffee is for HIM.; That noun 'him' is required to be present. The preposition 'for' doesn't make sense without 'him'.

question: List the french COI pronoms.
answer: me + te + lui(m/f) + nous + vous + leur(m/f); me + te change to m' and t' in front of a vowel of mute H.; NB: The COI pronouns for him/her/them are genderless. LUI is used for both masculine and feminine.; NB: LEUR does not have an S when used as a COI pronom. But leur can also be a possesive adjective (e.g. their cat = leur chat). When leur is used as a possesive adjective then it must agree with the number of the noun that it describes (e.g. their cats = leurs chats).

question: Sometimes we do not use a COI pronom to reference an indirect object or object of a preposition. When is that the case?
answer: Use COI unless it is one of the many special cases where pronoms toniques is used. This depends - among other things - on the preposition (or lack thereof) required by the verb - which is not consistent between English and French. You cannot translate directly from English.; NB: In English the treatment of pronouns for indirect objects and objects of a preposition are the same. The pronouns taking the objective case: him/her/them.

question: Which COD and COI pronouns are the same? Which are different?
answer: They are mostly the same: me + te + nous + vous. The only perspectives in which they differ are 3rd person singular (le/la vs lui) and 3rd person plural (les vs leur).

question: When we have both a COD pronom and a COI pronom in a sentence they are both placed before the verb. Which one is placed first?
answer: COI; General order: Subject + COI pronom + COD pronom + Verb.; Exception: When both pronouns are in the 3rd person then the order is reversed.; In spoken french it is very uncommon that both a COD and a COI pronoun are used. Typically a person will only use one pronoun and be explicit about the other object.

question: Do these verbs trigger a COD pronom or a COI pronom? aimer + appeler + écouter + lire + voir
answer: They trigger a COD pronom. e.g. Je vois Audrey. = I see Audrey. Je LA (not lui) vois. = I see her.; e.g. J'écoute Audrey = I listen to Audrey. Je l'écoute. = I listen to her.

question: Do these verts trigger a COD pronom or a COI pronom? parler + plaire + répondre + téléphoner
answer: They trigger a COI pronom. e.g. Je réponds Audrey = I respond to Audrey. Je LUI (not la) réponds. = I respond to her.

question: What are pronoms toniques?
answer: Pronouns that are used in french in some special circumstances (including for emphasis). Sometimes pronoms toniques replace COI when referring to indirect objects. Sometimes they are used to show possession. Pronoms toniques ALWAYS refer to a person (never a thing). Do not use a tonique pronom if you are referring to a thing.; Other names for these pronouns: stressed pronouns + disjunctive pronouns + pronoms disjunct.

question: List the pronoms toniques.
answer: moi + toi + lui(m)/elle(f) + nous + vous + eux(m)/elles(f); me + te change to m' and t' in front of a vowel of mute H.; NB: Pronoms toniques differ by gender in 3rd person singular AND plural. (This is not surprising considering that pronoms toniques are always used to refer to people - never to things.); For example... 'to him/her/them(m)/them(f)' does not adapt to gender because TO triggers COI: lui/lui/leur/leur. BUT 'with him/her/them(m)/them(f)' must adapt to gender because WITH triggers tonique (assuming that we are referencing people): avec lui/elle/eux/elles.

question: What are the special scenarios where we use pronoms toniques?
answer: Most importantly you can only use a tonique pronom when referencing a person (not a thing). Then the scenarios include (but are not limited to): 1) a short response to question (e.g. Who is there? I am! = Moi!); 2) a double subject - a very french structure (e.g. Me` I am... = Moi` je suis... ); 3) indirect objects when we are forced - in french - to place a preposition (like APRÈS AVEC DANS DEVANT POUR SANS CHEZ...) in front of the pronoun; 4) in comparisons after QUE - remember that QUE contracts to QU' when followed by a vowel (e.g. bigger than her = plus grand qu'elle; bigger than them masculine = plus grand qu'eux); 5) a shortcut for ownership called independent possessive pronouns (e.g. mine = à moi); 6) together with -même (e.g. moi-même = myself + elle-même = herself + lui-même = himself); 7) After C’est... and Ce sont... (e.g. Ce sont EUX qui sont venus ici = They(m) are the ones who came here.)

question: for me + you + him/her + us + you guys + them(m/f)
answer: POUR triggers pronoms toniques (as long as the pronouns reference a person): pour moi + toi + lui/elle + nous + vous + eux/elles

question: with me + you + him/her + us + you guys + them(m/f)
answer: AVEC triggers pronoms toniques (as long as the pronoun references a person): avec moi + toi + lui/elle + nous + vous + eux/elles

question: his + hers + theirs(m) + theirs(f)
answer: à lui + elle + eux + elles; Use pronoms toniques to show ownership when the owner is a person. It also requires preposition À in french.

question: I walk the dog (gender not specified).
answer: Je promène le chein.; PROMENER does not use a preposition for its direct object (the dog).; Objects of the verb (direct and indirect) are placed after the verb (unless they are represented by pronouns).

question: I walk it (the male dog). + I walk it (the female dog).
answer: Je LE promène. + Je LA promène.; The dogs are direct objects of the verb. So we use the COD (le/la) pronouns.; All pronouns that represent objects of the verb are placed before the verb.

question: I help her/him. + I can help her/him.
answer: Je L'aide. + Je peux l'aider.; AIDER does not use a preposition for its direct object (him/her). So we use the COD (le/la) pronouns.; Use l' to avoid two vowels together.; All pronouns that represent objects of the verb are placed before the verb.

question: I bring you (informal). + I bring you (formal). + I bring us.
answer: Je T'amène. + Je VOUS amène. + Je nous amène.; AMENER does not use a preposition for its direct object (you/us). So we use the COD (te/vous/nous) pronouns - though the COI pronouns in these cases are exactly the same.; All pronouns that represent objects of the verb are placed before the verb.

question: I bring them (all masculine). + I bring them (all feminine).
answer: Je LES améne. (same for both); AMENER does not use a preposition for its direct object (them). So we use the COD (les) pronouns.; All pronouns that represent objects of the verb are placed before the verb.

question: She gives the hen to Anna. + She gives IT to ME.
answer: Elle donne la poule À Anna. + Elle ME LE donne.; DONNER does not use a preposition of its direct object (the cat). DONNER uses À for its indirect object (Anna).; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to you (informal).
answer: Elle TE LA donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'You' is a COI (te) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to him/her.
answer: Elle LA LUI donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'Him/her' is a COI (lui) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to us.
answer: Elle NOUS LA donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'Us' is a COI (nous) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to you (formal).
answer: Elle VOUS LA donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'You' is a COI (vous) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to them (m/f).
answer: Elle LA LEUR ('leuhr' same as heures) donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'Them' is a COI (leur) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: We work for me. + We work for you (informal).
answer: Nous travaillons pour MOI. + Nous travaillons pour TOI.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques as long as the pronoun references a person.

question: We work for him. + We work for her.
answer: Nous travaillons pour LUI. + Nous travaillons pour ELLE.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques (which disambiguate between genders in 3rd person) as long as the pronoun references a person.

question: We work for us. + We work for you (formal).
answer: Nous travaillons pour NOUS. + Nous travaillons pour VOUS.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques as long as the pronoun references a person.

question: We work for them (masculine) + We work for them (feminine).
answer: Nous travaillons pour EUX ('oo'). + Nous travaillons pour ELLES.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques (which disambiguate between genders in 3rd person) as long as the pronoun references a person.

question: We go without them (unspecified gender).
answer: On va sans EUX.; The preposition sans triggers pronoms toniques so the object of the preposition (them without specified gender) translates to EUX (instead of les or leur). is the tonique pronoun for them (male).

question: It is difficult for them (all women) to travel.
answer: C'est difficile pour ELLES de voyager.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques so the object of the preposition (them feminine) translates to ELLES (instead of les or leur).

question: Simone is stronger than her.
answer: Simone est plus forte qu'ELLE.; Using the comparator QUE triggers the pronoms tonique. So we use ELLE to represent 'her' (instead of la or lui).

question: Michael and I are playing tennis.
answer: Michel et MOI    jouons au tennis.; Use tonique pronouns (moi instead of je) whenever there are 2+ subjects of a sentence (and any of them are pronouns).; NB: One way to think of this: Michael WITH me. AVEC triggers the use of the pronoms toniques.

question: He and I are friends.
answer: LUI et MOI    sommes amis.; Use tonique pronouns (lui instead of il) whenever there are 2+ subjects of a sentence (and any of them are pronouns).; NB: When the subject is compound (lui et moi) you should pause between the subject and verb. Running them together is not idiomatic.

question: He and his friends are there.
answer: Lui et ses amis   sont là.; Use tonique pronouns (lui instead of il) whenever there are 2+ subjects of a sentence (and any of them are pronouns).; NB: When the subject is compound (lui et ses amis) you should pause between the subject and verb. Running them together is not idiomatic.

question: Them and their friends are there.
answer: Eux et leurs amis   sont là.; Use tonique pronouns (eux instead of ils) whenever there are 2+ subjects of a sentence (and any of them are pronouns).; NB: When the subject is compound (eux et leurs amis) you should pause between the subject and verb. Running them together is not idiomatic.

question: Who is going to the beach? He is! She is!
answer: Qui va à la plage? Lui! Elle!; When answering a question quickly in french like this it triggers the pronoms toniques which disambiguate between gender in the 3rd person. So use lui/elle (disambiguated) instead of le/la or lui (ambiguous).

question: They (unspecified gender) want to come too.
answer: EUX aussi veulent venir.; When using emphatic phrases (words like aussi + non plus + seul) it triggers the pronoms toniques (eux - or elle - instead of les or leur).

question: You want me to 'do something'.
answer: Tu veux que je... ; VOULOIR triggers the subjonctif to express this (You want that I...). We do not translate it directly with a direct or indirect object (me).

question: If some noun/pronoun is an indirect object in English then will it also be an indirect object in French? Why?
answer: No. Not necessarily.; French and English verbs differ in their use of prepositions. This means that a verb might use a preposition in English but not in French (and vice versa). The presence/absence of a preposition can often determine whether or not the object of the verb is direct or indirect. So you have to memorize whether how each french verbs us prepositions in order to know which pronouns to use for the objects following the verb.

question: We listen to our mothers. + We listen to THEM.; Explain the selection of the french pronoun for 'them' in this case.
answer: Nous écoutons nos mères. + Nous LES (COD) écoutons.; In English the verb that means 'to listen to something' requires a preposition TO and its object is indirect. But in french the verb ÉCOUTER does not use a preposition and its object is direct (not indirect). So when we replace the object (mothers) with a pronoun we use COD (les) instead of COI (leur).

question: We call our mothers. + We call THEM.; Explain the selection of the french pronoun for 'them' in this case.
answer: Nous téléphonons À nos mères. + Nous LEUR (COI) téléphonons.; In English the verb that means 'to call someone' does not require a preposition and its object is direct. But in french the verb TÉLÉPHONER requires the preposition À and its object is indirect (not direct). So when we replace the object (mothers) with a pronoun we use COI (leur) instead of COD (les).

question: Define transitive and intransitive verbs. Give examples.
answer: Transitive verbs can take a direct object. e.g. To put: He put the book on the table.; Intransitive verbs do not require a direct object. e.g. To die: John died.; NB: In English you cannot have an indirect object if there is no direct object.

question: Define linking verbs. Do they have direct/indirect objects?
answer: Linking verbs do not have action. They connect the subject of a sentence to some information. e.g. To be: Simone is a leader.; Linking verbs do not have direct objects. Therefore they also do not have indirect objects.

question: What is an independent possessive pronoun?
answer: An independent possessive pronoun is a shortcut for showing ownership where the pronoun stands on its own instead of being an adjective to the noun that is possessed. For example: This is my cat. 'my' is a possessive pronoun. 'cat' is the noun being possessed (by me). BUT... This cat is mine. 'mine' is the independent possessive pronoun - you could eliminate the cat entirely: It is mine.

question: How do you construct the independent possessive pronouns in french? (e.g. mine)
answer: There are two ways to express these in french. In both cases you need a second word. 1) DEFINITE ARTICLE + non-generic posessive pronoun: e.g. C'est mien. = It's mine. ...if the noun (that is owned) is singular/masculine. Both the article and the possessive pronoun change to adapt to the gender and number of the noun being owned. 2) À + generic tonique pronoun: e.g. La chat est à moi. = The cat is mine. These pronouns do not adapt to the number and gender of the possessed noun.

question: What are all the forms (masc sing + fem sing + masc pl + masc pl) of the possessive pronouns that mean 'mine'?
answer: LE mien + LA mienne + LES miens + LES miennes; Do not forget the definite article. Choose the correct form based on the gender and number of the noun being possessed.

answer: LE tien + LA tienne + LES tiens + LES tiennes; Do not forget the definite article. Choose the correct form based on the gender and number of the noun being possessed.

question: What are all the forms (masc sing + fem sing + masc pl + masc pl) of the possessive pronouns that mean 'his/her/its'?
answer: LE sien + LA sienne + LES siens + LES siennes; Do not forget the definite article. Choose the correct form based on the gender and number of the noun being possessed.

answer: LE nôtre + LA nôtre + LES nôtres (m/f plural); NB: For nous + vous + ils/elles forms the plural possessive pronoun is the same regardless of the gender of the thing that is owned.; Do not forget the definite article. question: It is not X Y or Z.
answer: Three options when making a negated list. 1) Use ou: Ça n'est pas X Y ou Z. 2) Use et: Ça n'est pas X Y et Z. This is possible in french. 3) Use ni (stronger tone): Ça n'est pas X ni Y ni Z.

question: She is taller than you (are).

question: She is as tall as you (are).
answer: Elle est aussi grande que toi.

question: Everyone is going home.
answer: On va chez soi.; Soi is used for unspecified persons. It is equivalent to 'one' or 'oneself' in English. But in English we typically use 'everyone' instead.
