question: What is an adverbial pronoun?
answer: It is a pronoun that represents a place or a quantity or the object of a preposition.; 1) there: I go to the store. I go there. There references the store - which also happens to be the object of the preposition 'to' (à).; 2) them: Cars... I have some of them/those. 'Them/those' references the object of the preposition 'of' (de).; 3) those/that: I have none of this/that. 'This/that' references the object of the preposition 'of' (de).

question: When do you use the pronom Y?
answer: Rule of thumb: Y is a pronoun that replaces a place. It means 'there'. e.g. Je vais À Paris. becomes... J'Y vais. (I go there.).; The more correct rule: Y is an adverbial pronoun that replaces a noun that is the object of the preposition À. Y can replace any noun that is the object of preposition À EXCEPT an animate object (including people).; This means that you first need to understand whether a verb requires À (use Y) or DE (use EN).; NB: If the structure is À + NOUN and the noun is an animate object...then use a tonique pronoun instead of Y.; Pronunciation: Pronom Y is pronounced 'ee'. So J'y is pronounced 'gee'.

question: When do you use the pronom EN?
answer: Rule of thumb: EN is a pronoun that replaces something that has a count/quantity to it (either clearly or vaguely). e.g. Je parle DE mon ami. (I talk about my friend.) becomes... J'EN parle. (I talk about them.).; e.g. J'en voudrais. = I want one (of those).; EN replaces any of the following: (un + une + du + de la + des) + NOUN.; The more correct rule: EN is an adverbial pronoun that replaces a noun that is the object of the preposition DE.; This means that you first need to understand whether a verb requires À (use Y) or DE (use EN).; e.g. Il cherche DEs idées. (He looks for ideas.) becomes... Il EN cherche. (He looks for some.); NB: EN can replace a NOUN on its own or an entire phrase.

question: When is it difficult to determine when to use Y vs EN?
answer: For example when someone says: I'm thinking about X. And then the next sentence references X as a pronoun. Whether you use EN or Y to reference X depends on whether you say (in french) Je pense à X or Je pense de X. So you have to memorize whether to use verb + à X or verb + de X. Then this determines whether you use Y (replaces à X) or EN (replaces de X).

question: Where do you place pronom Y or pronom EN in a phrase?
answer: Pronom Y/EN are placed last after all over pronouns. This means that they are placed directly before the verb (before the auxiliary in passé composé).; NB: Only PAS (no pronouns) comes between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé.

question: I went to Beijing. + I went there.
answer: Je suis allé(e) à Pékin. + J'y suis allé(e).; 'there' is an adverbial pronoun refering to 'Beijing'. In this case we use the pronom Y (instead of EN) because the verb (ALLER) is always followed by À (instead of DE).; Another way to remember this is that we generally use pronom Y when referring to a location.

question: I come from Shanghai. + I come from there.
answer: Je viens de Shanghai. + J'EN viens.; Use pronom EN to replace Shanghai (instead of Y) because VENIR triggers DE (not À).

question: I think about my country. + I think about it.
answer: Je pense À mon pays. + J'Y pense.; Use pronom Y (instead of pronom EN) because the verb PENCER uses À (instead of de). Therefore the object of the preposition (my country) is replaced with Y.

question: I will think about it.
answer: J'y penserai.; PENSER in futur simple. Use Y because PENSER uses À (instead of DE).

question: I think about Simone. + I think about her.
answer: Je pense À Simone. + Je pense À ELLE.; Use pronom tonique (instead of Y) because the verb PENCER uses À and the object of the preposition is a person. Therefore use the pronom tonique (elle) to replace Simone.

question: I'm interested in politics. + I'm interested in it.
answer: Je m'intéresse À la politique. + Je m'Y intéresse.; Use pronom Y (instead of pronom EN) because the verb SE INTÉRESSER uses À (instead of de). Therefore the object of the preposition (politics) is replaced with Y.

question: I change the train. + I change it.
answer: Je change DE train. + J'EN change.; Use pronom EN (instead of pronom Y) because the verb CHANGER uses DE (instead of à). Therefore the object of the preposition (the train) is replaced with EN.

question: I need a television. + I need one.
answer: J'ai besoin D'une télé(vision). + J'EN ai besoin.; 'one' is an adverbial pronoun refering to 'a television'. In this case we use the pronom EN (instead of Y) because the verb (AVOIR besoin) is always followed by DE (instead of À).; Another way to remember this is that we use pronom EN when referring to a quantity of something (one television).

question: They want telephones. + They want some.
answer: Ils veulent des téléphones. + Ils EN veulent.; 'some' is an adverbial pronoun refering to 'telephones'. In this case we use the pronom EN (instead of Y) because we are referring to a quantity of something (some phones).

question: I have it. + I do not have it.
answer: J'EN ai. ('zshoh-nay') + Je n'EN ai pas. ('zshuh-noh-nay-pah'); These are very common french expressions. This is typically how you express these phrases in french.; Use pronom EN to refer to the thing that you have or do not have because it clearly or vaguely has a count/quantity.; If you are really referring to a very specific thing that was explicitly discussed before this phrase then you can use a regular pronoun (e.g. le) instead of pronom EN to refer to 'it': I have it. = Je l'ai. (le + ai = l'ai)

question: I like to go to the Mediterranean Sea. + I like to go there. + I like the climate there.
answer: J'aime aller à la mer Méditerranée. + J'aime Y aller. (Y is placed before the infinitive verb that it modifies.) + J'aime le climat là-bas.; In the last case it doesn't make sense to use Y to replace 'there'. The verb AIMER must be connected to the object (le climat). What we really mean is that we like the climate 'over there'.

question: I am looking forward to the concert. + I am looking forward to being there.
answer: J'ai hâte ('hat') de le concert. + J'ai hâte d'Y être.; Use pronom Y to replace an event (the concert) even though the pronom DE is in play.

question: I have not gone to the Netherlands.
answer: Je ne suis pas allé(e) aux Pays-Bas.; Use ALLER instead of ÊTRE.; NE always comes directly after the subject (before any pronouns). PAS goes between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé.

question: I have not gone there.
answer: Je n'Y suis pas allé(e).; Use pronom Y to replace À + location.; Use ALLER instead of ÊTRE.; NE always comes directly after the subject (before any pronouns). PAS goes between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé.

question: I have never gone there.
answer: Je n'Y suis jamais allé(e).; Use pronom Y to replace À + location.; NE always comes directly after the subject (before any pronouns). JAMAIS replaces PAS (between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé).

question: I have never gone to Japan or Vietnam.
answer: Je ne suis jamais allé(e) au Japon et au Vietnam.; You can use ET (and) or OU (or) here - they are both correct.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.

question: I have never BEEN to the Netherlands.
answer: Je n'étais jamais allé(e) aux Pays-Bas.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.; This is NOT passé composé! Use plus que parfait (past perfect; 'had been doing something') tense. Plus que parfait: être conjugated in imparfait + aller past participle.

question: I have never BEEN there.
answer: Je n'Y étais jamais allé(e).; Use pronom Y to reference À + location. NE always comes directly after the subject (before any pronouns). JAMAIS replaces PAS.; This is NOT passé composé! Use plus que parfait (past perfect; 'had been doing something') tense. Plus que parfait: être conjugated in imparfait + aller past participle.

question: I would install it. + I would like to install it.
answer: J'Y installerais. + J'aimerais Y installer.; INSTALLER uses À so 'it' is replaced by pronom Y.; Both sentences use the conditionnel.; The second phrase is a slight exception because pronom Y comes after one of the verbs (instead of before the verb which is generally the rule).

question: It's ONLY 30 minutes.
answer: Ce N'était QUE 30 minutes.; QUE replaces PAS to give emphasis... ONLY a friend. This does not negate the phrase. Generally if you omit PAS then negation does not occur.

question: He/she is ONLY a friend.
answer: Ce N'est QU'un ami.; QUE replaces PAS to give emphasis... ONLY a friend. This does not negate the phrase. Generally if you omit PAS then negation does not occur.; Use CE instead of il/elle. This is an idiomatic phrase.; NB: qu'un is pronounced 'kahn' not 'koon'

question: When do the standard rules for possessive adjectives not apply? ...what are the exceptions?

question: a professor (masc + fem)
answer: un professeur / une professeure; The feminine version is an exception. Given the spelling of the masculine version we would expect the feminine version to end in -euse instead of -eure.

question: a teacher (masc + fem)
answer: un enseignant / une enseignante; a person who teaches young children in school = professeur(e) de primaire.

question: the faculty
answer: le fac

question: a student (masc + fem)
answer: un étudiant / une étudiante (t is not pronounced in masculixne version but is pronounced lightly and upward in the feminine version) OR l’élève for male or female student

question: an alumni
answer: un ancien / une ancienne élève; literally: old student

question: a translator (masc + fem)
answer: un traducteur / une traductrice; the verb 'to translate' = traduire

question: an architect (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) architecte; When the masculine version ends in E then the feminine version is the same form.

question: a police officer (masc + fem)
answer: un policier / une policière

question: a fireman (masc + fem)
answer: un pompier / une pompière

question: a citizen (masc + fem)
answer: un citoyen / une citoyenne

question: How are these words pronounced differently? toy + player + day + toy
answer: a toy = un jouet ('zshoo-AY'; compound vowel sound); a male player = un joueur ('zshoo-EHR'; compound vowel sound); a day = un jour ('zshOOR'; one vowel sound); A compound vowel sound is like how the word 'our' is pronounced in English. The word is one syllable but you actually hear two vowel sounds. The vowels run together a bit but you hear them both.; If you pronounced jouer as a single syllable then it would be indistinguishable from the word for day (jour).

question: a dancer (masc + fem)
answer: un danseur / une danseuse

question: an actor (in a film) + an actor (of the stage)

question: He/She was a writer.
answer: Il/Elle êtait écrivain(e).; Use the imparfait (instead of passé composé) because we are describing the setting or telling a story instead of describing a discreet action.

question: a painter (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) peintre; When the masculine version ends in E then the feminine version is the same form.

question: an artist (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) artiste; When the masculine version ends in E then the feminine version is the same form.; an artisan: un(e) artisan(e)

question: an archeologist (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) archéologiste; When the masculine version ends in E then the feminine version is the same form.

question: a mayor (masc + fem); Specify pronounciation.
answer: un(e) mair(e); Pronounced 'mer' which is the same as mère (mother).

question: a government worker (masc + fem)
answer: une(e) fonctionnaire; When the masculine version ends in E then the feminine version is the same form.

question: a customer + a consumer (masc +fem)

answer: un(e) commercial(e) + un(e) commerçant(e); When a french word ends in -CIAL pronounce it the same as the word for sky: ciel.

question: an industry
answer: une industrie OR un domaine (more idiomatic); e.g. J'aime mon domain.

answer: un(e) propriétaire; When the masculine version ends in E then the feminine version is the same form.

question: caretaker + superintendent

question: to own
answer: posséder; The literal translation is 'to possess' and so this verb can be used more broadly in french compared to english. e.g. La maison ne possède pas de cave. = The house does not have a basement.

question: to rent an apartment + the rent (that you pay)

question: a place

question: a building
answer: There are two words: 1) le bâtiment is any structure including a house + an apartment building + a store... it is the larger category; 2) un immeuble ('ee-mobl') only describes a structure where multiple families live or where there are multiple offices. ...it is the smaller category; immeuble is pronounced 'ee-mobl' (instead of 'uh-mobl') because there is a double consonant following the I.

question: the housing

answer: un studio ('stoo-deeoo'; two deep U sounds); une studette is a studio apartment that is very small (typically for students); Suffixes -ET (masculine) and -ETTE (feminine) indicate a very small version of the noun.

question: a house

answer: une villa; Pronunciation is an exception. LL is pronounced like an english L (instead of Y). Same exception as une ville (a city).

answer: une peniche

question: a tent
answer: une tente ('tont')

question: the bedroom

question: the office

question: a business + business (in general)

question: an event/case

question: a service + customer service
answer: une service + le service clientéle

question: the cellar / the basement

question: gender-neutral

question: Do adjectives come before or after the noun they describe?
answer: Generally adjectives follow the noun that they describe. But there are many exceptions. Some categories of adjectives are always placed before the noun. For example: Salutations like Bonne week-end! Bonne nuit. For example: Adjectives that indicate order/class (premier/première + dernier/dernière + etc) are placed before the noun they describe.; It is also true that some adjectives can be used on either side of the noun and the placement changes the meaning.

question: Which adjectives come before the noun they are describing (instead of after it as expected)?
answer: autre + long + court + jeune + nouveau + vieux/vielle + petit(e) + grand(e) + gros(se) + joli(e) + mal/mauvais + beau/bel/belle/beaux (beautiful) + bon/bonne/bons/bonnes (good) + meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meilleures (better) + le meilleur/ la meilleure/ les meilleurs/ les meilleures (best); NB: Adjectives that indicate order/class (premier/première + dernier/dernière + etc) are also placed before the noun they describe.; NB: The masculine singular versions of these adjectives may change spelling if the noun begins with a vowel or silent H.

question: What changes when an adjective is placed before a noun instead of after it (as is the general case)?
answer: When an adjective is placed before a noun then the spelling of that noun becomes important. If the noun starts with a vowel then it may change the spelling of the adjective. This is most common for adjectives that end in -eau and -eux. For example: The masculine singular version of 'old' is vieux. But an old man = un vieil (not vieux) homme because H is treated as a vowel.

question: What is the general rule for adapting adjectives to gender and number?
answer: Add E to form feminine singular - this will force the pronunciation of the final consonant (that was silent in the masculine singular form) but it's a light touch on the consonant...it's not hard or heavy; Add S to form masculine plural; Add ES to form feminine plural; No change in pronunciation from the singular to plural forms of the same gender because the S and ES are generally silent.; There are many different variations of adjectives but this is the most basic transformation.

question: When do adjectives have the same spelling and pronunciation for masculine and feminine and plural?
answer: Generally any adjective that ends in an E or S or X in the masculine form is spelled the same in the feminine form.

question: What is the difference in pronunciation between bon (good/masc) + bonne (good/fem) + beau (beautiful/masc)?
answer: The first two have an extreme nasal quality: 'boh' and 'bohn'. Shoot the sound up at the roof of the mouth and out the nose. The third (beau - like beaucoup) is not nasal and sounds exactly like the word 'bow' in English.

question: What is the difference in pronunciation between beau (beautiful/masc) + beaucoup?
answer: No difference. The first (or only) syllable of both sounds like the word bow in English. It does not have the nasal quality of bon.

answer: There are three different words depending on the scenario: 1) vieux ('vyuh')/vieille ('vee-yay') can apply to people or things. question: What are the four forms of the negative word for 'old' (masculine singular + feminine singular + etc)? Specify the pronunciation.

question: What are the two major rules (not exhaustive) for transforming an adjective to an adverb (e.g. blind to blindly)?
answer: 1) If the masculine adjective ends in vowel (e.g. vrai + absolu + probable): Add -MENT (e.g. vraiment).; 2) If masculine adjectives ends in consonant (e.g. amical + heureux + long): Select the feminine adjective and add -MENT (e.g. amicalement + heureusement + longuement).; These 2 rules ensure that adverbs have a vowel immediately preceding the -MENT ending. Sometimes (no rule of thumb) we add an accent to that E (e.g. obscur = obscure; obscurÉment = obscurely).; NB: Adverbs do not change form to agree with gender/number because they modify verbs - not nouns.

question: How do you transform an adjective that ends in -ANT or -ENT to an adverb?
answer: Replace -ant with -AMMENT. Replace -ent with -EMMENT.; e.g. apparENT becomes apparEMMENT; NB: This is a group of exceptions from the general two rules for transforming adjectives to adverbs.

question: How do you avoid ending a phrase with a preposition (which would be grammatically incorrect in both french and english)?
answer: Use the word DONT at the beginning of the phrase.; This is roughly translated as from/with/of which OR from/with/of whom.

question: Here’s the family. I’m talking about this family. Here’s the family I’m talking about.
answer: Voici la famille. Je parle de cette famille. Voici la famille DONT je parle.; Use DONT to avoid ending the phrase with a preposition.

question: I have all the books that I need.
answer: J'ai toutes les livres DONT j'ai besoin.; Use DONT to avoid ending the phrase with a preposition.

question: I told you about my friend.
answer: J'ai parlé DE mon amie.; Use DE in this context when you mean 'about'.

question: She is the friend that I told you about.
answer: Elle est l'amie DONT je t'ai parlé.; Use DONT to avoid ending the phrase with a preposition.

question: She told me to wait.
answer: Elle m'a dit D'attendre.; The formula for telling someone to do something: DIRE + DE + INFINITIVE (of whatever you are telling them to do)

question: I agree to go.
answer: J'accepter DE aller.; accepter = agree to; When you use two verbs together you often connect them with DE.

question: You decide to run.
answer: Tu décide DE courir.; When you use two verbs together you often connect them with DE.

question: We ask to leave.
answer: On demande DE partir.; When you use two verbs together you often connect them with DE.

question: I’m suspicious of him. That is the man of whom I am suspicious.
answer: Je me méfie de lui. C'est l’homme DONT je me méfie.; Use DONT to avoid ending the phrase with a preposition.

question: I’m looking for a house. The house’s door is yellow. I’m looking for the house with a yellow door.
answer: Je cherche une maison. La porte de la maison est jaune. Je cherche la maison DONT la porte est jaune.; Use DONT to avoid ending the phrase with a preposition.

question: I have a lot of friends. Two of my friends are poets. I have a lot of friends - two of whom are poets.
answer: J’ai beaucoup d’amis. Deux de mes amis sont poètes. J’ai beaucoup d’amis - DONT deux poètes.; Use DONT to avoid ending the phrase with a preposition.

question: As a... / Speaking as a...

question: She is working as an engineer. + She works on a book.
answer: Elle travaille EN TANT QUE ingénieur. + Elle travaille un livre.; NB: There is no preposition (de + sur + etc) after the verb travailler when you want to describe working 'on' something.

question: It might not work. + It cannot not work.
answer: This is really interesting because the difference in these two meanings occurs only by re-ording the words: Ça peut ne pas marcher. (I might not work. - 50/50 chance) + Ça ne peut pas marcher. (It cannot work. - 100% negative; This is the standard way to negate where NE comes directly after the subject.)

question: Perhaps her efforts will not work.

question: at your disposal

question: What are les relatifs (relative pronouns)?
answer: Pronouns that introduce a relative clause (a phrase that gives more information about the subject). Relative pronouns are a way to connect phrases that have the same subject to avoid repitition.; Example: A hat is on the table. This hat is blue. ...becomes... The hat THAT is on the table is blue. THAT is the relative pronoun.

question: What are the les relatifs (give examples) in English and French?
answer: Examples of relative pronouns in English: that + which + who + + whom + whose + where + when. Examples of relative pronouns in French: qui + que + lequel + auquel + duquel + dont + où.; NB: The choice of word is more flexible in English than it is in French.

question: the woman who is walking by
answer: La femme QUI passe.; Use relative pronoun QUI because 'who' in this case represents the person/thing that is doing the action. Hint: Use QUI when the relative pronoun is followed directly by a verb.

question: the hat that I am wearing
answer: Le chapeau QUE je porte.; Use relative pronoun QUE because 'that' in this case represents the person/thing that is the object of the action. Hint: Use QUE when the relative pronoun is followed directly by the subject of the phrase - the person/thing doing the action.

question: the woman who arrived
answer: La femme QUI arrive.; QUI does not contract when followed by a vowel (unlike que)!; Use relative pronoun QUI because 'who' in this case represents the person/thing that is doing the action. Hint: Use QUI when the relative pronoun is followed directly by a verb.

question: the man that she likes
answer: Le homme QU'ELLE aime.; QUE contracts when followed by a vowel (unlike qui)!; Use relative pronoun QUE because 'that' in this case represents the person/thing that is the object of the action. Hint: Use QUE when the relative pronoun is followed directly by the subject of the phrase - the person/thing doing the action.

question: the dress that is interesting + the dress that he loves
answer: La robe QUI est intéressant. La robe QU'IL aime.; Use QUI when the relative pronoun (that) refers to the thing doing the action.; Use QUE when the relative pronoun (that) refers to the thing that is the object of the verb.; Remember QUI never contracts but QUE contracts when followed by a vowel.

question: you (formal) who look at yourself in the mirror
answer: Vous QUI vous regardez dans le miroir.; The relative pronoun 'who' represents the subject of the phrase so we use QUI instead of QUE.; This is a case where a conjugated verb does not follow QUI directly. That is because the verb (SE REGARDER) is reflexive. So 'vous' in this case is just another pronoun. It is not the subject of the phrase.

question: When do you use Qu'est-ce que...? vs Qu'est-ce qui...?
answer: The que and qui relative pronouns work the same in questions as they do in statements. So Qu'est-ce que... is followed by a subject + verb. Qu'est ce qui is followed by a verb. Generally you use the latter when the subject has been dropped from the question. The subject could be dropped out of necessity for meaning or it may be dropped when someone is talking in a very casual and familiar way. In both cases one must use Qu'est-ce qui...? instead of Qu'est-ce que...?

question: How do you ask 'What happened?' in two ways? 1) using Qu'est-ce que...? 2) using Qu'est-ce qui...?
answer: 1) Less familiar (no dropped subject): Qu'est-ce qu'il (QUE + il) s'est passé? 2) More familiar (dropped subject): Qu'est-ce QUI s'est passé?; In the latter example we must use QUI (instead of QUE) because we follow with a verb - the subject is omitted. This is a requirement even though the subject is dropped as an informality.

question: What is harder?
answer: Qu'est-ce QUI plus dur?; We must follow Qu'est-ce with QUI (instead of que) because there is no explicit subject in this question. Use QUI when what follows is a verb.

question: the person who you (formal) are watching
answer: La personne que vous regardez.; The relative pronoun 'who' represents the object of the verb so use QUE instead of QUI.; In this case the verb (REGARDER) is not reflexive because one thing is watching another thing. So the 'vous' that follows the pronoun is the subject pronoun - the person/thing that is doing the action in the phrase.

question: When does one use lequel/laquelle/lesquels/lesquelles?
answer: These are the french relative pronouns that mean 'the one which'. They reference indirect objects. They follow the prepositions à + de + pour + avec.; Rule of thumb: If in English you are tempted to end a sentence with a preposition (which you should not) then this is generally the time when lequel/... is used. Example: the pen that I write with (should be 'the pen with which I write') = le stylo avec LEQUEL j'écris ; NB: These pronouns CANNOT be used to represent people - only things.

question: When do you use quel vs lequel?
answer: QUEL/quelle/quels/quelles is an adjective. e.g. Quel chapeau... ? = Which hat...?; Lequel/laquelle/lesquels/lesquelles is a pronoun so it can stand on it's own. e.g. Lequel...? = Which one...?

question: the book for which she is famous.
answer: le livre pour lequel elle est connu(e); lequel because livre is masculine singular; When you use a relative pronoun (which) with an indirect object (the book) - often with a preposition à or de or pour - then you must use the indirect pronoun that agrees with the noun: lequel (masc sing) + laquelle (fem sing) + lesquels (masc pl) + lesquelles (fem pl)

question: the table I put my bag on
answer: la table sur laquelle j'ai mis mon sac; laquelle because table is feminine singular; When you use a relative pronoun (which) with an indirect object (the book) - often with a preposition à or de or pour or SUR - then you must use the indirect pronoun that agrees with the noun: lequel (masc sing) + laquelle (fem sing) + lesquels (masc pl) + lesquelles (fem pl)

question: the spices with which I cook
answer: les épices avec lesquelles je cuisine; lesquelles because spices is feminine plural

question: the best restaurant that we went to
answer: le meilleur restaurant dans lequel on est allé; lequel because restaurant is masculine singular

question: The problem of which I am thinking is complex.
answer: Le problème auquel il pense est complexe.; aqeul because à + lequel (masc sing) = auquel

question: The woman of which I am speaking is my neighbor.
answer: La femme à laquelle il parle est ma voisine.; à laquelle because à + laquelle (fem sing) does not contract

question: Which one is the least expensive?
answer: Lequel est le moins cher?; lequel = the one which. It stands on it's own as a pronoun.

question: I don't know which one (to choose).
answer: l'un des deux (one of the two) is a good way to express this.; Technically you could say: Je ne sais pas lequel. But this is not idiomatic french in this case.

question: It is a painting in the center of which we see a child.
answer: C'est un tableau au centre duquel on voit un enfant.; duquel because de + lequel (masc sing) = duquel

question: the city-center + the city center of Barcelona
answer: au centre ville + au centre de Barcelone; There is no à or article in front of the city in this case.

question: This is a story that has been talked about a lot.
answer: C’est une histoire à propos de laquelle on a beaucoup parlé.; de laquelle because de + laquelle (fem sing) does not contract

question: the season when it is hottest
answer: la saison OÙ il fait plus chaud; Use the relative pronoun OÙ to represent a time or place (where or when).

question: the moment when I realized
answer: le moment ('momo') OÙ j'ai réalisé; Use the relative pronoun OÙ to represent a time or place (where or when).

question: It was good to be there at that time.
answer: C'etait bien d'Y être à moment lá.

question: I worked at X company.
answer: J'ai travaillé chez X.; You can use 'chez' in this way.

question: the company that I work for / the company for which I work
answer: l'enterprise pour/dans laquelle je travaille; pour laquelle = for which; dans laquelle = in which; Use laquelle to prevent a phrase from ending in a preposition - cannot do this in french.

question: the primary/largest reason (for something)
answer: The idiomatic way to say this: la raison pour laquelle (the reason why).; Technically you could translate directly to: la plus grosse raison (the biggest reason) but this sounds weird in french.

question: a reason
answer: une raison OR un motif; The S in raison sounds like Z because single S and it is between two vowels.; Make sure you make the strong closed 'ohn' sound for last syllable.; This differentiates it from the word for grape - une raisin ('ray-suhn'; in like ingénieur)

question: Is it possible to say...?
answer: C'est possible DE DIRE...?

question: everything that I know
answer: tout CE QUE je sais; Use CE QUE in a statement where you are referencing something in an undefined way that is the recipient of the action ('what').

question: I forgot what I wanted to say.
answer: J'ai oublié CE QUE je voulais dire.; CE QUE is an indefinite direct object to represent 'what' you forgot.; Use QUE when asking a question. Use CE QUE in a statement where you are referencing something in an undefined way that is the recipient of the action ('what'). In a question you only need QUE.

question: ...what you (informal) were just saying
answer: ...CE QUE tu viens de dire; Use CE QUE to reference the indefinite object - the thing that you were just saying.; Use passé recent tense: VENIR conjugated + DE + INFINITIVE

question: The book you are buying is interesting. + What you are buying is interesting.
answer: Le livre que tu achètes est intéressant. + CE QUE tu achètes est intéressant.; CE QUE is an indefinite direct object ('what' you are buying; You is the subject. What is the object.).

question: I read the message she wrote. + I read what she wrote.
answer: J’ai lu le message qu’elle a écrit. + J’ai lu CE QU’elle a écrit.; CE QUE is an indefinite direct object ('what' I read; I is the subject. What is the object.); que + elle = qu'elle because QUE contracts (though QUI does not contract)

question: I forgot what makes the difference.
answer: J'ai oublié CE QUI fait la différence.; CE QUI is an indefinite subject that comes directly before a verb. 'that which' does something. that which makes a difference (in this case). Use CE QUI in a statement where you are referencing something in an undefined way that is the doer of the action ('that which'). In a question you only need QUI.

question: The color is in it. + I do not know what is in it.
answer: La couleur est dedans. + Je ne sais pas CE QUI est dedans.; CE QUI is an indefinite subject ('what' is the subject directly followed by a verb)

question: The car hit me. + I did not see what hit me.
answer: La voiture m'a heurté. + Je n’ai pas vu CE QUI m’a heurté.; CE QUI is an indefinite subject ('what' is the subject directly followed by a verb).

question: What I like... it's The Ballet or The Theater.
answer: Though not common in english this is a very idiomatic pattern in french: CE QUE j'aime` c'est le Ballet ou le Théâtre.; CE QUE represents an indefinite direct object.; The idiomatic pattern: CE QUE + SUBJECT + VERB` + C'EST + NOUN OR INFINITIVE

question: That which I deteste... it's laying out in the sun.
answer: Though not common in english this is a very idiomatic pattern in french: CE QUE je deteste` c'est prendre le soleil.; CE QUE represents an indefinite direct object.; The idiomatic pattern: CE QUE + SUBJECT + VERB` + C'EST + NOUN OR INFINITIVE

question: To read... that is what I prefer.
answer: Though not common in english this is a very idiomatic pattern in french: Lire` c'est CE QUE je préfère.; CE QUE represents an indefinite direct object.; The idiomatic pattern: NOUN OR INFINITIVE` + C'EST CE QUE + SUBJECT + VERB.

question: That which is good.... it is to get married.
answer: Though not common in english this is a very idiomatic pattern in french: CE QUI est bien` c'est se marier.; CE QUI represents an indefinite subject. (hint: It is followed by a conjugated verb.); The idiomatic pattern: CE QUI + VERB` + C'EST + NOUN OR INFINITIVE

question: To travel... that is what is pleasing to me.
answer: Though not common in english this is a very idiomatic pattern in french: Voyager` c'est CE QUI me plaît.; CE QUI represents an indefinite subject. (hint: It is followed by a conjugated verb.); The idiomatic pattern: NOUN OR INFINITIVE` + C'EST CE QUI + VERB

question: It's only ... (e.g. It's only one day.)
answer: Ce n'est que... (e.g. Ce n'est qu'un jour.); This is a very idiomatic way of speaking. It looks like QUE replaces PAS but that is not what is happening because this is not a negative statement.; que + un = qu'un because QUE contracts.

question: What I need now - is an apartment.
answer: CE DONT j'ai besoin maintenant -  c'est d'un nouvel appartement.; The verb for talking about needing something is AVOIR BESOIN DE. So in a more staightforward case we would use the pronon EN. This is a scenario for 'ce que' but - because we are dealing with an object of DE - we must use CE DONT (instead of ce que).

question: Do you remember what I talked to you about?
answer: Est-ce que tu te souviens CE DONT je t'ai?; The verb for talking about something is PARLER DE. So in a more staightforward case we would use the pronon EN. This is a scenario for 'ce que' but - because we are dealing with an object of DE - we must use CE DONT (instead of ce que).

question: What are some common verbs that are always followed by DE? Why is it helpful to memorize these?
answer: boire de + parler de (to speak about something) + avoir besoin de (to need something) + jouer de (to play an instrument) + se souvenir de (to remember) + partir de (to leave) + penser de (to have an opinion about); Knowing whether or not a verb requires the preposition DE determines which pronoun you can use to replace the object of the verb. Use Y to replace à + object. Use EN to replace de + object.; e.g. I speak at it. = J'en parle (PARLER + DE).

question: the last time we saw eachother / met
answer: la dernière fois QU'on s'est vues revenir (idiomatic)

question: She is the person IN WHOM I trust.
answer: Elle est la personne À QUI je fais confiance.; À QUI is a relative pronoun that is used to reference a noun that is not doing the main action. It means something like in whom / to whom. Use it when the relevant verb triggers À.

question: He is the person TO WHOM I tell everything.
answer: Il est la personne À QUI je dis tout.; À QUI is a relative pronoun that is used to reference a noun that is not doing the main action. It means something like in whom / to whom. Use it when the relevant verb triggers À.

question: They are the friends WITH WHOM I spend the most time.
answer: Ils sont les amis AVEC QUI je passe le plus de temps.; AVEC QUI is a relative pronoun that is used to reference a noun that is not doing the main action. It means with whom. Use it when the relevant verb triggers AVEC.

question: Who is the pencil from? + Who is the pencil for?
answer: DE QUI est le crayon? + À QUI est le crayon?; DE QUI is a relative pronoun that means from whom. Use it when the relevant verb triggers DE.; À QUI means in whom / to whom. Use it when the relevant verb triggers À.

question: The woman for whom I work is very nice.
answer: La femme POUR QUI je travaille est très gentille.; POUR QUI is a relative pronoun that means for whom.

question: What is a demonstrative article?
answer: this/that e.g. this cat + that whale; Demonstrative articles precede a noun. In french they generally do not stand on their own because there is a different set of words (demonstrative PRONOUNS) that reference entire entities.

question: What are the demonstrative articles (this/that X) in french and how are they pronounced?
answer: There are three: Ce 'suh' (masculine singular) + Cette 'set' (feminine singular) + Ces 'sayz' (plural regardless of gender)

question: this bra
answer: ce soutein-gorge (masculine)

question: this baseball hat
answer: cette casquette (feminine)

question: these gloves
answer: ces gants (plural)

question: these pajamas
answer: ce pyjama (masculine); pyjama is singular in french but plural in english

question: this article (article is spelled the same in french but is masculine)
answer: cet article ('suh-tar-teecl') is masculine singular; Normally we use CE for masculine singular but here the noun starts with a vowel so we change CE to CET.; cette and cet are pronounced exactly the same because the T sound is required in cet to manage the following noun that starts with a vowel.

question: this summer
answer: cet été ('set-a-tay'); Êté (summer) is masculine so we would normally choose CE. But the noun starts with a vowel so we change CE to CET.; cette and cet are pronounced the same. The T sound is required in cet (even though an E does not follow the final T) in order to manage the following noun that starts with a vowel.

question: this island
answer: cette île ('se-teel'); Île (island) is feminine. Use CETTE regardless of whether or not the noun starts with a vowel.; Cette and cet are pronounced the same.

question: this apartment + this house
answer: cet appartement (masculine but use cet because starts with vowel) + cette maison (feminine)

question: What is ça?
answer: ça ('sah') is a demonstrative that stands on its own. e.g. This (does something). That (does something). - not like this cat.; ÇA is a simplification of both ceci (this here) and cela (that there).; Use ceci and cela in very formal communication. Use ça for all other times when you are referring to a stand-alone item.

question: What do ceci and cela mean?
answer: Both are stand-alone demonstratives. CECI = this here. It is a contraction of ce (this/that sing masc) + ici (here). CELA = that there. It is a contraction of ce (this/that sing masc) + là (there).; Use ceci and cela in very formal communication. ÇA replaces both of these for all other times when you are referring to a stand-alone item.

question: Casual form: This is... +  These are...
answer: C'est... ('say') + Ce sont... ('suh-son'); Grammatically this is likely incorrect because CE is the masculine singular (default) demonstrative article. It should precede a noun (e.g. ce chat). Perhaps ÇA or CECI or CELA are better choices than CE. But using CE in this situation is common.

question: Casual form: This is not... + These are not...
answer: Ce n'est pas... + Ce ne sont pas...; Grammatically this is likely incorrect because CE is the masculine singular (default) demonstrative article. It should precede a noun (e.g. ce chat). Perhaps ÇA or CECI or CELA are better choices than CE. But using CE in this situation is common.

question: What is a demostrative pronoun? What are the forms in French?
answer: A demonstrative pronoun references an entire specific item that was mentioned previously (e.g. this one + that one).; There are four forms in French: celui (masc sing) + celle (fem sing) + ceux (masc pl) + celles (fem pl); NB: In French demonstrative pronouns CANNOT be used to represent people - only things.

question: After talking about hats... How do you say?: the one that is on the chair
answer: celui qui est sur la chaise; CELUI is the masculine singular pronoun that means 'the one' (a demonstrative pronoun).

question: After talking about dresses... How do you say?: the one that is on the bed
answer: celle qui est sur le lit; CELLE is the feminine singular pronoun that means 'the one' (a demonstrative pronoun).

question: After talking about hats... How do you say?: the ones that on the couch
answer: ceux qui sont sur le canapé; CEUX is the masculine plural pronoun that means 'the ones' (a demonstrative pronoun).

question: After talking about dresses... How do you say?: the ones that are on the table
answer: celles qui sont sur la table; CELLES is the feminine plural pronoun that means 'the ones' (as demonstrative pronoun).

question: After talking about a person... How do you say?: the one over there
answer: cette personne là; DO NOT USE demonstrative pronouns (celui/celle/ceux/celles) to reference people!

question: When you are pointing out something... This one (here). (m/f)
answer: The thing is singular: celui-ci (m) / celle-ci (f); We are just adding 'here' (ici) to the pronouns that mean 'the one'.

question: When you are pointing out something... These ones (here). (m/f)
answer: The things are plural: ceux-ci (m) / celles-ci (f); We are just adding 'here' (ici) to the pronouns that mean 'the ones'.

question: When you are pointing out something... That one (there). (m/f)
answer: The thing is singular: celui-là (m) / celle-là (f); We are just adding 'there' (là) to the pronouns that mean 'the one'.

question: When you are pointing out something... Those ones (there). (m/f)
answer: The things are plural: ceux-là (m) / celles-là (f); We are just adding 'there' (là) to the pronouns that mean 'the ones'.

question: When do you use voilà vs voici?
answer: The suffixes change the meaning. -là (there) vs -ici (here). Voilà is more general like a conclusion e.g. There it is. There you have it.; Voici is tangible like something you have in your hand that you are showing or giving e.g. Here he/she/it is. Here they are. Here you go.

question: What do you say when you come to a conclusion. e.g. There you have it.
answer: voilà; If you are instead displaying or giving over something tangible like change or a document then use voici instead of voilà.

question: What do you say when you hand over a document (le document)?
answer: LE voici or voici; Literally: Here he is.; Use voici (instead of voilà) because you are showing or handing over something tangible that is right there.

question: What do you say when you hand over a carte vitale (la carte vitale)?
answer: LA voici or voici; Literally: Here she is.; Use voici (instead of voilà) because you are showing or handing over something tangible that is right there.

question: What do you say when you hand over some objects (des objets)?
answer: LES voici or voici; Literally: Here they are.; Use voici (instead of voilà) because you are showing or handing over something tangible that is right there.

question: It's difficult to anticipate.
answer: C'est difficil d'anticiper.; Use DE to construct these kinds of phrases. C'est difficil + DE + INFINITIV

question: a field (of work) - like a type of work
answer: une branche (same as for a tree)

question: France is a good place to live.
answer: La France est un bon endroit où vivre.

question: an epidemic (e.g. covid)
answer: une épidémie

question: in the long term + in the short term
answer: sur le long terme + sur le court terme; le terme = the term (like a word or a condition)

question: all at once
answer: d'un coup; coup = cut

question: military coup
answer: coup d'état; coup = cut; état = state; Literally: a cut of the state

question: It depends. + It depends on...
answer: Ça dépend. + Ça dépend DE...

question: It's a hard life.
answer: C'est une dure vie.

question: You went exploring.
answer: Tu es partie en exploration.

question: It was good to learn about a new city.
answer: C'était bien d'en apprendre plus sur une nouvelle ville.

question: It allows me to see new things. (like when you travel to see someone and you want them to feel that it was not a chore)
answer: Ça me permet devoir DE nouvelle chose.; verb: permettre is like 'to allow' or 'to facilitate' (in addition to the literal 'to permit')

question: to allow
answer: autoriser OR permettre

question: to forgive
answer: pardonner; unforgiveable = impardonnable

question: the touristy things
answer: les choses touristiques

question: silly
answer: bêta; This can be used in a positive or negative context.

question: smiling + a smile
answer: souriant(e) + un sourire

question: to laugh + to smile
answer: rire + sourire (rire is the root); Rire (and its related verbs like sourire) is conjugated similar to lire. e.g. je ris + tu ris + il/elle/on rit...

question: idiomatic way to say: dying of laughter
answer: mort de rire

question: idiomatic way to say: I struggle with X.
answer: J'ai du mal avec X.

question: She wants to work until she dies.
answer: Elle veut travailler jusqu'à sa mort. Elle veut travailler jusqu'à qu'elle meurt.

question: I don't see myself (doing something).
answer: J'ai du mal (i struggle) à me projeter.; se projeter = to project; se projeter can mean literally to project (like in a movie theater) or to forecast something.

question: There is more to see. + There are many museums to see.
answer: Il y a plus à voir. + Il y a beaucoup de musées à voir.

question: They were preserved well.
answer: Ils ont été bien préservés.; In french passé composé is the better way to express this. In English it is literally: They have been preserved.; But there is a verb for to preserve: préserver.

question: a skeleton
answer: un squelette

question: a joke + a riddle
answer: une blague (or une plaisanterie) + une devinette; NB: Use la énigme if you mean a riddle that is more like a mystery instead of a question.

question: I tried to make a joke.
answer: J'ai essayé de faire une blague.

question: to make it by hand + custom-made
answer: faire à la main + sur-mesure

question: an artifact
answer: un artefact

question: the supply (as in supplies for making something)
answer: l'approvisionnement

question: The train has been cancelled.
answer: Le train a été annulé.; To express that something 'has been' done: use être in passé composé (AVOIR conjugated + ÉTÉ) + PAST PARTICIPLE of the action verb (annulé in this case).

question: The book has been taken.
answer: Le livre a été pris.; To express that something 'has been' done: use être in passé composé (AVOIR conjugated + ÉTÉ) + PAST PARTICIPLE of the action verb (pris in this case).

question: pronounce the city of Rennes
answer: 'rhen' The E sounds more like an english E in this word because it is followed by a double consonant (nn) which changes the pronunciation of the preceding vowel.

question: What is the difference between en province and Provence?
answer: en province ('pro-vuhns' like ingénieure) = in the provinces; Provence is the region of France with this name.

question: How do you suggest that the person you are speaking with uses 'tu' instead of 'vous'?
answer: On se dire 'tu'/'vous'.

question: How can you guess if two similar words mean the same in french/english or if they are 'false friends'?
answer: If the word has anything to do with government/administration/culture/etc then it is likely the same in french/english. e.g. administraTION + secTION + government + bueaucracy + president + docteur/doctor + culture.; This is because in 1066 the Normans (of Normandy in present-day france) invaded England and dominated the administration and culture there. So french words were used for these subjects.

question: What are the french equivalents of these english syllables/word endings: tion + able + ible?
answer: They are exactly the same in french. e.g. portion + capable + impossible

question: What are the french equivalents of these english syllables/word engings: ty + ism + ology + ous + ate + ize?
answer: ty-&gt té (e.g. université) + ism-&gt isme (e.g. socialisme) + ology-&gt ologie (e.g. technologie) + ous-&gt eux (e.g. fabuleux) + ate-&gt er (e.g. tolerate-&gt tolérer) + ize-&gt iser (e.g. privatiser)

question: given that
answer: étant donné que

question: rather than / instead of
answer: plutôt que

question: a compliment (when you flatter someone) + a complement (something additional)
answer: un compliment + un complément; Adjective meaning complementary/additive: complémentaire (same m/f); complimentary information = des informations complémentaires

question: a fossil fuel + a green/renewable energy
answer: une énergie fossile + une énergie verte

question: a greenhouse effect
answer: un effet de serre

question: the recycling + the carpooling
answer: le recyclage + le covoiturage

question: glass/plastic/paper recycling
answer: le recyclage du verre/plastique/papier

question: the gas + the gasoline + the diesel oil
answer: the gas (state of matter + natural gas): le gaz + the gasoline (for a consumer car): l'essence + diesel oil: le pétrole

question: the coal
answer: le charbon

question: bad faith
answer: la mauvaise foi

question: to be plagued by
answer: en proie ('uhn-prwa'); e.g. Je suis en proie à tomber malade. = I am at risk of falling ill.

question: by the way
answer: soit dit en passant

question: I live at XX Bond Street. + I live at XX Park Boulevard.
answer: J'habite` XX Rue Bond. + J'habite` XX Boulvard Park.; This is how you give your address. Use the same structure regardless of whether you live on a rue (feminine) or a boulevard (masculine).

question: I live on Bond Street. + I live on Park Boulevard.
answer: J'habite DANS la Rue Bond. + J'habite AU Boulevard Park.; Use dans for a street. Use au for a boulevard.

question: I live on that street. + I live on that boulevard.
answer: J'habite DANS cette rue. + J'habite AU ce boulevard.Use dans for a street. Use au for a boulevard.

question: It's easy for him to say.
answer: C'est facile pour lui DE dire.; When you use être to describe an action (e.g. It is easy to do something.) then you must use DE between the conjugated être and the infinitive of the action.

question: It's difficult to eat the entire meal.
answer: C'est dificil DE manger tout le repas.; When you use être to describe an action (e.g. It is easy to do something.) then you must use DE between the conjugated être and the infinitive of the action.

question: It's easy for us to leave earlier.
answer: C'est facile pour nous DE partir plus tôt.; When you use être to describe an action (e.g. It is easy to do something.) then you must use DE between the conjugated être and the infinitive of the action.

question: When I wear my headphones I still hear your music. Please turn it down.
answer: Quand je porte mes écouteurs j'entends toujours ta musique. S'il vous plaît baissez-le.

question: It is going to be a place to discover together.
answer: Ça va être un endroit à découvrir ensemble.; This is a very casual/improvised way of speaking.

question: They do their best.
answer: Ils font de leur mieux.

question: the schedule (e.g. my calendar)
answer: There is no direct translation. Typically a plural word is used to express this: les emplois du temps

question: idiomatic way to say: I will make room in my schedule.
answer: J'ai besoin de m'organiser.

question: idiomatic way to say: It warms my heart.
answer: Same saying in french: Ça me réchauffe le coeur.

question: idiomatic way to say: Good to know.
answer: Bon à savoir.; Same as in English.

question: old school (meaning old-fashioned)
answer: à l'ancienne OR de la vieille école ('vee-yay')

question: a drama (theater)
answer: un drame; This word is reserved for the type of performance/theater. It is not used to describe gossip/drama in the American sense.

question: It was chaos.
answer: C'était le chaos.

question: shenigans
answer: un conneries; This is slang. It roughly translates to 'a bullshit'.; It can mean a mistake that you made or some silly happenings.; e.g. Je fais un conneries.

question: shit / fuck (the expression) + literal shit/manure
answer: putain + la merde

question: idiomatic way to talk politely about how families are difficult / always some drama
answer: Il y a toujours des histoires.

question: idiomatic way to say: It's a mess/shitshow.
answer: C'est le bordel.; le bordel = brothel; bordélique = messy with a very negative connotation.; Bordel is commonly used to refer to disorder.

question: idiomatic way to say: a shitty day + a shitty weekend ...a shitty whatever
answer: jour du merde + weekend du merde; la merde = the manure (literal shit); e.g. J'ai passé une journée du merde. = I had a shitty day.

question: idiomatic way to say: It was a tragedy. (when you are exagerating - e.g. This morning was such a mess - it was tragic.)
answer: handicap; In this case it does not mean disability.

question: idiomatic way to say: I can't take it any more.

question: idiomatic way to say: the whole picture + the big picture (the big idea)

question: idiomatic way to say: She has a hidden side / more to her than meets the eye.
answer: Elle a une face caché.; cacher = to hide; face means side and - like in English - can be interchanged with visage (literal translation of face).

question: idiomatic way to say: the apple of my eye
answer: la prunelle de mes yeux

question: idiomatic way to say: I don't use German (the language) much.
answer: Je n'utilise pas l'allemand tant que ça.

question: idiomatic way to say: It can be seen.. / One can see...
answer: On peut voir...; Use this structure for any general statement about what can be seen/done/eaten etc.

question: idiomatic way to say: everything you need

question: idiomatic way to say: It doesn't matter which one you use.
answer: Peu importe celui que tu utilises.

question: idiomatic phrase to use when you've learned something new
answer: Je me coucherai moins bête ce soir.; Literally: I will go to bed less stupid tonight.

question: idiomatic way to say: all over the place / saying lots of things but not making sense

question: idiomatic way to say: to each their own
answer: à chacun son goût

question: idiomatic way to say: to live vicariously
answer: vivre par procuration

question: idiomatic way to say: it's moving forward
answer: Ça avance.

question: idiomatic way to say: I'm not very good at remembering names.
answer: Je ne suis pas très doué(e) pour retenir les noms.; The literal translation of doué(e) is 'gifted' but the meaning is not as specific in french as it is in english. In french doué(e) means something closer to 'good at something'.

question: idiomatic way to say: Someone needs to work.
answer: Certaines personnes doivent travailler.

question: idiomatic way to say: I'll see what I can do.
answer: Je regarderai ce que je peux faire.

question: idiomatic way to say: It struck me. (like an idea)
answer: Ça m'a interpellé.; SE INTERPELLER is the verb.; It can mean: It occured to me. It became evident to me. It called out to me.

question: idiomatic way to say: a big breath of fresh air
answer: un bol d'air frais

question: idiomatic way to say: in order to make up for this... I propose..
answer: Afin de excuser... je propose...; afin de + infinitive = in order to do something

question: idiomatic way to say: It simply was not possible.
answer: Ce n'était tout simplement pas possible.; This is a common french expression.

question: The french version of 'It's a double-edged sword'.
answer: C'est à double tranchant.

question: The french version of 'kill two birds with one stone'

question: The french version of 'to be gentle as a lamb'

question: The french version of 'when pigs can fly'
answer: quand les poules auront des dents; literally: when the chickens have teeth

question: The french version of 'it costs an arm and a leg'
answer: Ca coute les yeux de la tête.; You can use any object as the subject. e.g. Mon ordinateur coute les yeux de la tête.

question: The french version of 'It's like nails on a chalkboard.'
answer: J'ai les oreilles qui saignent. (I have ears that bleed.); The structure is AVOIR + les oreilles qui saignent... e.g. J'ai les oreilles qui saignent quand j'entends ça. = I have the ears that bleed when I hear that.

question: A french saying that tranlates to: The bottle doesn't matter as long as you're drunk.
answer: Qu'importe le flacon pourvu qu'on ait l'ivresse.

question: slang for a woman (a chick) + a dude
answer: une nana + un mek

question: slang for a good environment (like a party with a good vibe)
answer: bon enfant; This might be slang from 1980s/1990s.

question: slang for: to tell someone off
answer: faire de leçon

question: to 'do it cold' (e.g. to watch a movie without knowing the plot)
answer: passé du froid

question: I need backup/help in the kitchen.
answer: J'ai besoin de renfort dans la cuisine.

question: idiomatic way to say: cooking in the kitchen
answer: derrière les forneaux (literally: behind the furnaces); le fourneau is an old word for stove/oven (similar to kiln). In this expression it is always used in the plural.

question: What does à la base mean?
answer: It is a transition that you use to make a tangential point when you are in the middle of a longer story. It can also be used to summarize (similar to 'long story short').

question: superficially
answer: superficiellement

question: a martial art
answer: un art martial

question: the anonymity
answer: l'anonymat; e.g. leur anonymat = their anonymity

question: an individual
answer: un individu

question: a personality
answer: la personnalité OR une individualité; individualité is very close to personality - the qualities that make a person or thing different from others.

question: a good mentality
answer: une bonne mentalité

question: a vicious cycle
answer: un cercle vicieux

question: the gossip + the rumor
answer: les potins + la rumeur

question: What word do you use to contradict an assumption?
answer: si; This word is almost always used when responding to a question phrased in the negative.

question: Respond to: Tu n'aimes pas les films d'action?
answer: Si mais je préfère les films d'horreur.; Si is like 'yes' but only if you are contradicting a negative question or statement.
